Finally, a MLP with three fully-connected layers (16-, 8, 1-sized) is used for the classification of the feature representation vector as either a rockfall or non-rockfall volume.
In the PointNet++ SSG model (Fig. 7
), the set abstraction process includes the sampling of 32 points from each of 256 local regions of the shape at the first level, and their 16-dimensional encoding using PointNet. Subsequently, the second level samples 64 points from each of 128 local regions and encodes them into a 16-dimensional embedding too. In the PointNet++ MSG model, three increasing sampling scales are employed in each abstraction level. The first level samples 16, 16, and 32 points locally from 256 regions at each scale, while the second level samples 32, 32, and 64 points from 128 regions at each of the three scales. The mini-PointNet models used within Rockfall Detection PointNet++ include two convolution layers of 16 neurons each. As in PointNet, all the layers in PointNet++ implementation incorporate ReLU activations except the final sigmoid activation.


2.2.3
Pre-processing
It is crucial in ML that the project is structured appropriately during the pre-processing step. For the development of our rockfall detection models we formed four subsets of the change detection database; one for training, one for development, and two for testing on different real-world scenarios within the monitoring program. The setup of the tests is one of the most important components since it represents a real instance of the problem that the model is designed for. The clusters from the last two data acquisition campaigns (ID: 23, 24) were kept out for the testing of the models on a real-world example of this monitoring program. The remainder of the clusters were divided for each class into 70% for training and 30% for development based on the change volume distribution. This logic is based on the observation that the larger the change volumes are, the more discrete the shapes become between rockfall and non-rockfall events, and thus, the easier the labeling is for a human. As such, the datasets were compiled to make sure that both training and development sets come from the same distribution and no such bias is induced in the training process. Specifically, equal number of training and development data were sampled from each of the bins of the volume histogram. Since rockfall and non-rockfall volume distributions are very similar, this also resulted in an approximately 40–60% class proportion between rockfall and non-rockfall clusters for each bin.
Another important pre-processing step is the preparation of the data as inputs to the neural network. A neural network architecture has explicit design with predefined input tensor size. In a rock slope monitoring program, there are multiple parameters that affect the point cloud density and subsequently the number of points in a detected rock slope deformation cluster. Also, within our rock slope deformation database, there is great variability in the cluster volume. As such, the individual rock slope deformations point clouds include a few to thousands of points - depending on the magnitude of the event. To comply with this and provide a fixed n-dimensional input to the neural network, without modifying the shape of a cluster, the input points are directly sampled uniformly from the triangular surfaces of the CAD model generated by meshing the raw data as shown in Fig. 8
. The meshes are produced via surface reconstruction methods built on computational geometry described and used in DiFrancesco et al. (2021). The reconstructions were guaranteed to produce watertight manifold geometry, and were able to approximate the input clusters well, to be used for the generation of the 1024 × 3 input tensor.

where TP, TN, FP, and FN standing for true positive, true negative, false positive, and false negative predictions, respectively.
In general, there is an inversely proportional relationship between loss and accuracy. In interpretation, the loss defines how well the model “understands” the problem and the confidence it has in the predictions it is making while the accuracy defines the real-world implications. Table 2
 summarizes the train-dev-test scores after 1000 epochs of training the models on the Mile 109 dataset. It is observed that PointNet achieves the highest score on the test set, however, the test loss values are slightly higher compared to the PointNet++ models. The overall loss values indicate that rockfall detection based on the shape is a complex problem.
The visualizations of the results in Fig. 9
 illustrate that there is also difference in the distribution of the errors. By a visual assessment, the spatial pattern of predictions by PointNet in Fig. 9b seem to match the reference pattern (Fig. 9a) and the errors are associated mostly with small volume clusters. However, both the PointNet++’s (SSG and MSG) seem to be making incorrect decisions for large volume clusters as well (Fig. 9c, d).
To increase the probability of working with single-event clusters, the second testing dataset was composed of clusters coming only from the data acquisition campaigns ID: 3, 5, and 8 which have inter-scan intervals of 10, 6, and 6 days, respectively (see Table 1). Due to the fact that these data were obtained more frequently, they are more likely to exclude accumulated clusters. The best-performing PointNet model achieved a 83.9% accuracy on the second test dataset. Since no large magnitude events occurred during the corresponding time-intervals, the relatively lower PointNet accuracy achieved is likely due to the dominance of small volume clusters.
The next evaluation step was to test the generalization capabilities of our AI. This includes the application of the trained weights of the best-performing PointNet model from Mile 109 to the WCW clusters. However, the model trained with the Mile 109 database clusters failed to solve the problem for the new site, identifying almost all the change clusters as rockfall events. This result was expected, due to the different scale of the changes between the two sites, in particular in the non-rockfall event data, and also due to the different rockmass structure and geometry. As a result of this finding, the architecture developed for the problem was applied to learn the shape characteristics of the WCW rock slope deformations. Table 3
 summarizes the train-dev-test scores after 1000 epochs of training the models on the WCW dataset. PointNet and PointNet++ MSG achieved an equivalently high accuracy of almost 93% on the test dataset. The loss values on the train and dev phase for PointNet indicate a smooth learning process while PointNet++ MSG loss increases by approximately 60% from training to development. This means that the model becomes less confident with its predictions which is reflected as a 1.5% accuracy decrease.
The WCW result visualizations in Fig. 10
 illustrate similarities with the erroneous predictions at Mile 109. PointNet predictions match the reference pattern (Fig. 10a) with the majority of non-rockfall clusters being sourced from the debris material within the channels and the rockfall events from the steep rock outcrop sections. On the other hand, both the PointNet++ (SSG and MSG) models make some obvious incorrect decisions in the channels (Fig. 9c, d). The above observations for both sites are quantified by the error analysis presented in the next section.


3.2
Error analysis
Error analysis was conducted to provide insights regarding the models' ability to learn from the given data, what they can learn better, and what type of deformation clusters they struggle to understand. The analysis was carried out based on the confidence the models have on their predictions (expressed as loss) with respect to the volume of the input clusters. The volume spectrum was divided into four classes with clusters <0.01, 0.01–0.1, 0.1–1, and > 1 m3 and the median loss was calculated for the predictions corresponding to each class.
The error analysis results are provided in the two bar charts in Fig. 11
 for Mile 109 and WCW, respectively. The distributions validate the visual observations on Figs. 9 and 10. The PointNet++ models are significantly less confident in their predictions than PointNet for both sites. Usually, loss values >0.1 do not represent an optimum learning and values over 1 are not acceptable. In the WCW case most of the errors are between 0.1 and 1 m3 of volume. On the other hand, median loss shows that PointNet predictions increase their confidence as the volume increases for at least 50% of the corresponding clusters. The latter is clearly evident in the Mile 109 case and follows the expected confidence trend of the human level performance in identifying rockfall clusters from volumetric optical material.



4
Summary and discussion
LiDAR technology has been widely used for rockfall monitoring worldwide. It is implemented to extract valuable information regarding rockfall source and deposition locations as well as their volume and shape derived from surface reconstructions. In addition, it opens new prospects for further advancements in rockfall risk management like AI development. Ideally, an AI may be able to project future potential new rockfall locations based on the continuous decoding of spatio-temporal rockfall patterns, as the monitoring operates. Such a model must first be able to understand what a rockfall looks like and detect it within 3D optical material such as point cloud data. Rockfall detection is a challenging task. To “teach” a model what is a rockfall, it must be provided with examples of both rockfall and non-rockfall events. For this purpose, we examined state-of-the-art DL models that have previously proven able to detect instances among 40 classes of every-day objects. In the rockfall detection case however, we get algorithms to accomplish a task for which human level performance has not been assessed. Disagreements on identifying what represents a rockfall by inspecting multi-temporal optical material may exist even between experts, especially for the tiny clusters. Therefore, it is rather challenging to set a performance threshold for an acceptable model.
Inspired by the advancements in other industries such as automotive, this research investigated the potential of DL and computer vision algorithms to complement LiDAR monitoring programs and provide support towards the development of AI-based rockfall risk management solutions with sequence models in the – near(?) – future. However, this effort has to keep up with the fact that classification problems in engineering geology require deep understanding of the phenomena and the semantics involved – which may not be universally accepted in all cases – in comparison to the automotive industry where almost any human being can perceive what a traffic light looks like. Thereafter, in this case it is challenging even to claim that a training dataset is perfect. After manual expert-based classification, two large rock slope deformation databases from geologically and geomorphologically different sites were used for the purposes of this research. The goal was to initially define the suitable learning architecture and train a model based on the data of one site and subsequently test the generalization ability of the trained model as well as the site-specific training of the same architecture. Although unique in size and duration, one limitation that might exist in these databases is the uncertainty on whether each cluster represents a single event. This comes from the fact that the sites are not monitored continuously and there might be instances where a cluster is essentially an accumulation of deformations sourced from the very same location. The data were therefore curated accordingly to make sure that the models are evaluated at real-world scenarios of these two rockfall monitoring setups. All the neural networks were trained on a NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2070 GPU with Tensorflow 2 deep learning framework in Ubuntu 18.04 operating system.


5
Conclusions
The outcome of this research is promising regarding the potential for AI to be applied to attempt to prevent property and life loss from rockfalls in the future. Rockfall detection comprises the cornerstone for the development of an AI-based early-warning system and LiDAR and DL can be the building blocks. Three point-based learning architectures with different characteristics were evaluated. The first architecture (PointNet) aims to understand rockfall shape characteristics by “looking” at the shape of each cluster as a whole and learning global feature representations. The other two architectures, PointNet++ SSG and PointNet++ MSG, focus on the understanding of the texture of each cluster by learning feature representations from local regions of the shape. The difference is that SSG groups local feature representations from one sampling scale at each level, while MSG can group features from multiple sampling scales imitating convolutional operations.
The Rockfall Detection PointNet architecture was proven suitable for the task at both the examined sites with accuracies fluctuating around and above 90%. It is concluded that rockfalls can be better separated from non-rockfall clusters by learning their overall shape characteristics instead of focusing on the local texture. Since the non-rockfall volumes represent rockfalls that were once detached, they are composed of the same material and thus the texture does not provide any discriminating value. Instead, global shape encoding of rockfall clusters inherits signs of the failure mechanism. This is also validated by the fact that PointNet errors are dominantly related to small volumes while the PointNet++ models make incorrect decisions on large volume deformations too, which might lead to an underestimation of the hazard. Rockfall detection, therefore, is not a straightforward classification problem and a balance between accuracy and error volume distribution should be considered when training DL algorithms for rockfall detection.
Furthermore, the study shows that it is challenging to achieve generalization in rockfall detection even with DL, which has proven its strengths in vision problems for other types of datasets. There might be a need for more and diverse training data to tackle the generalization challenge. However, site-specific DL-based rockfall detection with PointNet is highly encouraged by the results of the current study over two geologically and geomorphologically different rock slope databases. In addition, the study shows that a dataset of around 6000 events could be sufficient to provide good learning of the problem with the proposed neural network. Although human labeling variability in the task is not known, PointNet results with >90% accuracy and errors within the lower part of the volume spectrum, are anticipated to be very close to human-level performance.
Text.3:
1
Introduction
Rockfall is a frequent natural hazard in steep, mountainous environments endangering settlements and infrastructure (Guzzetti, 2000; Loew et al., 2021). Its occurrence is affected by many uncertainties and thus hardly predictable. For this reason, together with the generally high impact intensities, rockfall causes high costs compared to other landslide types (Arnold and Dorren, 2015; Ferrari et al., 2016). A realistic quantification of rockfall risk is crucial for an effective and efficient prevention of economic damages and loss of lives. Although rockfall trajectory models allow for an increasingly precise calculation of rockfall runout zones and the kinetic energies of blocks (Agliardi and Crosta, 2003; Bourrier et al., 2009; Dorren et al., 2006; Christen et al., 2012), the estimation of realistic block and event volumes as well as their release frequencies remain a major challenge. They are often based on one or several scenarios which represent estimates of different event magnitudes (release volumes) and return periods, based on geological surveys of the rock cliff and (scarce) inventory data. In the past, a few analyses of rockfall frequencies based on long-term historical inventories have been published (e.g., Hungr et al., 1999; Dussauge-Peisser et al., 2002; Eckert et al., 2020; Melzner et al., 2020). De Biagi et al. (2017) combined the analysis of available historical data with a survey of detached blocks in a probabilistic method to determine the rockfall magnitude-frequency relationship. The problem with inventory data is that i) observation periods are often short and thus the statistical representativeness is questionable (Hantz et al., 2020) and that ii) they are usually registered at the element at risk and often only in case of damages and, thus, rather represent the occurrence frequency at the element at risk than the release frequency. However, release frequencies are required to realistically quantify the rockfall risk for a specific element at risk and for a variation of propagation settings (e.g., with or without protection measures) (Lari et al., 2014; Moos et al., 2018). Other approaches are based on the analysis of remotely sensed data (e.g., Guerin et al., 2014; van Veen et al., 2018; Umili et al., 2020) or dendrogeomorphological analyses (Mainieri et al., 2019; Stoffel et al., 2005). Farvacque et al. (2021) proposed a method to estimate rockfall release frequency combining field-based data from rockfall protection barriers and tree-ring records of past rockfall activity with process-based modeling approaches. They found a good agreement between release frequencies determined from tree-ring analyses and obtained from rock deposits in the protection barriers. However, the mentioned approaches are often very cost- and time-intensive and/or rely on a large amount of (often unavailable) data and are, thus, not applicable in current practice. Engineering consultancies in charge of hazard assessments are generally limited in time and resources and thus rely on straightforward approaches and methods to determine rockfall release frequencies. These, however, often sacrifice in accuracy and objectivity.
Based on the analysis of the rockfall frequency and magnitude in a range of rock cliffs, Hantz et al. (2020) and Loew et al. (2021) proposed a power law based model for the determination of rockfall magnitude-frequency relationships aiming at a more objective approach for practitioners. It assumes that both, the releasing masses of rockfall events as well as the individual blocks of a rockfall event resulting from first fracturing follow a power law distribution. The parameters of these distributions are determined using a simple classification of rock structure in combination with field measurements of blocks. In this study, we applied and tested the proposed rockfall frequency model (RFM) at 8 different sites at 7 locations in the Swiss Alps. The calculated frequencies of rockfall events and the derived block volumes were compared to release scenarios of official hazard assessments. Additionally, the sensitivity and uncertainty of the derived rockfall scenarios regarding the parameters of the RFM were assessed.


2
Rockfall frequency model
The frequency of the detachment of rockfall events (hereafter called “release frequency”) is subject to a wide range of uncertainties and can hardly be predicted in a deterministic way. Thus, statistical models are often used to approximate the onset frequency of a rockfall event of a given size. Power law distributions have been proven to fit well the magnitude-frequency relationship of the released rockfall events and the released blocks, respectively (Hungr et al., 1999; Dussauge-Peisser et al., 2002). The spatio-temporal release frequency of rockfall events (introduced by Hantz et al., 2003a) can be expressed as:

The volume of a rockfall can be determined by comparing the pre-failure and post-failure surfaces in the cliff or by estimating the volume of the deposit of an event. A rockfall event is defined as the detachment of a rock volume between two different points in time. Van Veen et al. (2017) and Williams et al. (2019) pointed out that neighboring events occurring within a single monitoring interval are often recorded as one. Thus, the volumes of the rockfalls occurred in a cliff and their distribution depend on the monitoring interval, which must be considered by the users of a rockfall volume-frequency relation.
A rockfall event is generally composed of fragments. The volume distribution of these single blocks can also be approximated with a power law distribution (e.g., Hantz et al., 2016; Ruiz-Carulla et al., 2017; Moos et al., 2018):

Frequency distribution of blocks

The above explained model allows for characterizing the frequency distribution of block volumes. It is an “overall frequency” including the blocks theoretically falling during all potential rockfall events. It is obvious that the large number of blocks in the very big and rare events strongly influence the block volume frequency. This exemplifies that block releases are not independent events, and their onset probability cannot be modelled using a Poisson or binomial distribution (Hantz et al., 2021).


2.2
Frequency of rockfall events and maximum block volumes
Besides the overall release frequency of blocks, the frequency of rockfall events including at least one block of a given minimum volume or, inversely, the maximum block volume for a given rockfall frequency are of particular interest in hazard management. For this, it is necessary to determine the maximum probable block volume (and the number of blocks of this volume) as a function of the rockfall event volume.

3
Methods

3.1
Parameter estimation

3.1.1
Maximum possible rockfall volume and maximum block volume
The maximum possible volume of a rockfall V

max
 has to be considered if the rockfall volume-frequency relationship is extrapolated to rare events. It depends on the size of the rock wall (height, width), its morphology (slope angle and aspect) and on the structure of the rock mass (dips, dip direction, size and spacing of the discontinuities). Corominas et al. (2018) presented two standard approaches to assess the maximum possible (or credible) rockfall event, which can be bigger than the largest event of a potentially available historical inventory. The first one (inductive) consists in searching morphological evidence of passed rockfall events (deposits and scars left at the source). It allows for considering a period that is longer than the one covered by the historical inventory, but which is nevertheless limited. The second approach (deductive) consists in defining the maximum rockfall volume from the available data on the topography and internal structure of the rock cliff. The structure can be considered either statistically (identification of discontinuity sets) or deterministically (identification of individual potential sliding planes). Examples are given in Jaboyedoff et al. (2009), Mavrouli et al. (2015), Corominas et al. (2018) and Jaboyedoff et al. (2020).
Here we propose a simple method based on Hoek and Bray (1981) to be used when the geological structure is barely known. The model assumes a critical plane (or wedge) that outcrops at the base of the slope and a simplified geometry of the slope to determine the maximum possible volume of a slide. The critical sliding surface can be determined from a structural analysis of the rock mass (Fig. 2a). When there is no structural analysis, we assume that sliding may occur on a plane having the minimum dip (to maximize the sliding volume), but which is sufficient for sliding to occur (Fig. 2b). We propose values of this “minimum slide dip” based on the surface condition of the potential sliding plane (or wedge) as defined by Hoek and Marinos (2000), Marinos and Hoek (2001) and Hoek et al. (2005) (Table 1
). It can be adjusted based on expert judgment. It is important to note that for sliding planes with low dips (10°- 20°), the hypothesis of an infinite extension is too conservative because a tension crack usually bounds the sliding mass. The width of the biggest possible slide is assumed to equal the rock wall height, since a plane slide is rarely much wider than height (Frayssines and Hantz, 2006). Rockfall may also result from a topple. However, it can be assumed that the maximum rockfall volume resulting from a topple is smaller than the maximum rockfall volume resulting from a slide. It has to be noted that the simple method proposed here is conservative and may also include rockslides in the scenarios. The latter typically show another behavior compared to rockfall and, thus, should be treated separately in risk assessments. However, the maximum event volume predominantly influences the overall block frequency in the proposed model (Eq. 4–6), but it does not influence the calculation of the rockfall event volumes of a given return period and the associated number of blocks (Eq. 8–9) as it was applied in this study.
The maximum block volume was estimated by expert judgment based on the block volume samples measured in the field and inventory data of past rockfall events. It could also be estimated based on the structure of the rock mass (Mavrouli et al., 2015).


3.1.2
Parameters Ast and B
The parameter A

st
 shows the activity of the cliff and B determines the uniformity of the rockfall volume distribution and depends on the rock wall structure. It was determined following the classification proposed by Hantz et al. (2020), who analyzed the rockfall frequency in anaclinal limestone cliffs and a gneissic cliff in non-permafrost areas of the Alps. The rockfall frequencies in these cliffs were at such a low level that very few neighboring events were recorded as one with a monitoring interval of one year. In the classification, six main structure types are distinguished (Fig. 3
). The parameter A

st
 depends on the spacing of the main joint set of the rock wall (Hantz et al., 2020). The analyses of inventory data imply that a metric distance of the spacing corresponds to a A

st
 value between 0.01 and 0.1 and a decimetric distance to a A

st
 value between 0.1 and 1. Ast can be estimated using the following equation (Hantz et al., 2020):

(10)

whereas s is the average spacing of the main joint set in the rock wall.


3.1.3
Parameter b
The uniformity parameter b of the block volume distribution was determined based on block volume samples collected in the field. For each case study site, we sampled blocks along transects in the deposition area. Depending on the size of the deposition area, one or several down-slope transects following the mean trend of trajectories with a length of 20 m were determined, aiming at a realistic representation of the block size distribution including areas with smaller and larger blocks (following Ruiz-Carulla et al., 2015; Fig. 4
). Along this transect, all blocks with a volume ≥ 0.05 m3 were measured for a transect width of 2 m. To calculate the volume of a block, we measured three edges of the block and determined a correction factor (f) for the block volume compared to a perfect cube. For Orvin and Täsch, we used already available block samples from a recent study (Moos et al., 2018). We then fitted a power law distribution to the measured volumes based on least squares to derive parameter b. The degree of precision of the estimates of the parameter b was determined through a bootstrap analysis (Bengoubou-Valérius and Gibert, 2013; De Biagi et al., 2017). We fitted the parameter b for 10′000 bootstrap samples of the block volumes and determined the 95%-confidence intervals of the estimates.



3.2
Test sites
The RFM was elaborated and tested for eight rock cliffs at seven locations in Switzerland (Fig. 5
). The sites were selected based on the following criteria:

i)
The rock cliffs have different lithologies;


ii)
There are block deposits on the slope;


iii)
There are existing official hazard assessments available and if possible, inventory data on past events.



Three of the sites are in the canton of Valais (Swiss Western Alps), one in the canton of Bern (Jura), one in the canton of Grisons (Swiss Eastern Alps) and two in the canton of Ticino (Swiss Southern Alps). The main characteristics and available data are summarized in Table 2
. The scenarios of the official hazard assessment are mainly expert based with large differences in the underlying data basis. Images of the release areas can be found in Appendix A.


3.3
Sensitivity and uncertainty analysis
We quantified the uncertainty and sensitivity regarding the parameters A

st
, B, b, V

MAX
 and v

MAX
 and the surface of the cliff S for the calculated release scenarios based on a Monte Carlo approach. We determined the following “error margins” for the parameters based on expert judgment:
Ast: variation by a factor 2 (1/2*Ast - 2*Ast).
B: variation by +/− 0.2 (one class width; Fig. 3).
S: Variation by +/− 20%.
b: variation between lower and upper bound of the bootstrap confidence intervals (see section 2.3.3).
vMAX: variation by +/− 30%.
VMAX: variation by – 50% (calculated Vmax is regarded as the upper possible limit).
At each iteration of the Monte Carlo analysis, parameter values were randomly sampled from these ranges following a uniform distribution and the rockfall volume (V(F

t

)) and the maximum block volume v

max

(F

t

) were calculated. This was repeated 10,000 times. Finally, we calculated the mean, median and standard deviation of the derived rockfall event and block volumes.
To determine the contribution of each parameter to the overall output uncertainty, we used the least square linearization (LSL; Lei and Schilling (1996)). LSL splits output uncertainty into its sources based on a multiple regression between the parameter deviation from the mean and the output (Verbeeck et al., 2006). It enables calculating uncertainty coefficients of all parameters, based on which they can be ranked regarding their influence on the overall output uncertainty.


3.4
Comparison to hazard scenarios
A major challenge of implementing the RFM is its validation since data on past events is generally missing or of insufficient quantity or quality. The rockfall release scenarios determined in this study were compared to i) release scenarios of official hazard analyses determined by engineering consultancies; ii) release frequencies determined based on a combination of dendrogeomorphological analyses and rockfall deposits published in a recent study for the sites Orvin and Täsch (Moos et al., 2018). The available data and applicable validation approaches per site are summarized in Table 2.



4
Results

4.1
Parameter estimations
The parameter A

st
 was estimated between 0.05 yr−1 ha−1 (Bodio; Table 3
) and 0.3 yr−1 ha−1 (Fläsch 1 & 2; Nax). The parameter B ranged between 0.5 (Bodio) and 0.9 (Nax). The maximum possible volumes were estimated between 8000 m3 (Morcote) and 680′000 m3 (Nax; Table 3).
The block size distributions of all sites were well captured by the power law distributions (R2 between 0.82 and 0.98). The fitted b values vary between 0.69 (Bodio; Table 3 and Fig. 6
) and 1.69 (Nax). The uncertainty associated with the b estimates, as represented by the bootstrap confidence intervals in Table 3, substantially increases with decreasing block sample size (e.g., Morcote and Nax). There seems to be a tendency that b values are higher for limestone and dolomite compared to gneiss. Furthermore, b tends to increase with increasing B (Fig. 7
).


4.2
Release scenarios
The calculated block and event scenarios are reported in Table 4
 and Fig. 8-10


 for the different return periods. For the small return periods, the block sizes are usually in a comparable range with the scenarios of the official hazard assessment, but generally slightly larger. The difference increases with the return period (Fig. 8). For all sites, the standard deviations calculated by means of the Monte Carlo simulations are relatively high, indicating a large parameter sensitivity (Table 4). The variability of the event and block volumes also substantially increases with the return period (Figs. 9 & 10). For certain sites, the maximum possible block volume is already reached for return periods of 30–100 years, leading to an “asymptotic” trend in Fig. 10 (e.g., Fläsch 1 or Bodio). Tthe highest sensitivity of the block volumes was found to parameter B and partially the parameter Ast as well as the cliff size for return periods of 100 and 300 years. The event volumes are also most sensitive to parameter B except for the sites of Morcote and Orvin (Fig. 11
).



5
Discussion and conclusion
Determining realistic rockfall release frequencies is crucial for an adequate assessment of rockfall risk. Practitioners derive rockfall release scenarios often rather subjectively and uniform approaches and concepts are generally missing. The rockfall frequency model (RFM) applied in this study provides an objective and transparent approach to derive magnitude-frequency relationships of rockfall events and individual blocks even if historical inventories are missing or insufficient. It also allows for the determination of the frequency of rockfalls with at least one block with a minimum volume. It is a promising alternative to merely expert-based approaches for the following reasons: i) It requires only few parameters that are estimated based on simple schemes. This is a perfect precondition for its practical implementation; ii) the RFM assumes that the magnitude-frequency relationships for rockfall events and the individual blocks of an event can be characterized by a power law distribution. A wide range of studies evidence that this assumption is rather realistic (e.g., Hungr et al., 1999; Dussauge-Peisser et al., 2002; Ruiz-Carulla et al., 2015; Hantz et al., 2016), implying that the resulting frequencies are reliable. The comparison to the official hazard assessments in this study showed that this is not necessarily the case for the expert-based rockfall scenarios, where volume distributions were partially rather arbitrary; iii) the RFM provides an explicit quantification of the release frequency, whereas approaches based on inventories at the element at risk (e.g., De Biagi et al., 2017) only allow for the determination of the occurrence frequency at the elements at risk. Knowing the release frequency enables evaluating rockfall risk for different propagation scenarios, which is particularly relevant for hazard and risk assessments evaluating protection measures.
The block volume distributions of all study sites were well represented by power law distributions, indicating the scale invariant character of rock fragmentation (Turcotte, 1986). The fitted b values lay in a range that is similar to the range reported by Hantz et al. (2020) (0.47, 1.37), except the b value for Nax that is significantly higher (1.69). This suggests that dolomite gives a more uniform block volume distribution than the other rocks reported by Hantz et al. (2020). Two sites (Nax, Fläsch 1) have higher b values compared to the range (0.63–1.29) obtained by Lanfranconi et al. (2020), who also found a different trend in the lithology dependence. The value of the parameter b depends mainly on the geology of the cliff, and fragmentation is often caused by fracturing along pre-existing weak joint planes (e.g., Lin et al., 2022). Additionally, the fall height of the blocks plays a role (De Blasio and Crosta, 2015; Ruiz Carulla et al., 2016). Surprising is the large difference of the b values of the two neighboring sites Fläsch 1 (b = 0.77) and 2 (b = 1.45). They, however, differ in their lithology, which could explain the differing fragmentation behavior. While Fläsch 1 is composed of siliceous limestone (with partly marly rocks), Fläsch 2 is composed of limestone breccia and marly rocks. Furthermore, the block sample size of Fläsch 1 is distinctly smaller than for Fläsch 2, which could have led to a bias in the estimation.
The method used in this study for taking block samples in the field is a simplification of the approach proposed by Ruiz-Carulla et al. (2015). It is little time-consuming, easy to implement and requires only a couple of hours per site, depending on the site characteristics and accessibility and assuming that a sufficient number of deposited blocks is available. The comparison of fitted b values for different transects at two sites (Appendix B) exemplifies that the representativeness of the selected transects for the total block size distribution is more important than the number of measured blocks. It is thus difficult to indicate a minimum number of blocks to be measured. In case of large screes, measuring multiple transects representing different homogeneous deposition zones (cf. Ruiz-Carulla et al., 2015) is required. The comparison of the b and B values indicates a positive relationship between the two parameters, meaning that an increasing fracturing of the rock mass (increasing B) also results in a stronger fragmentation of the released volumes. Pursuing the systematic assessment of b values for other sites and for different geologies will possibly underpin potential relationships between the parameters and the main geological units.
The temporal frequencies and the volumes for different return periods depend on the release area and they increase with the considered cliff width. The comparison with the scenarios of the hazard assessments shows that the latter not always considered or underestimated the influence of the cliff size, since the difference between the RFM scenarios and the scenarios of the hazard assessments increase with increasing cliff size. The temporal frequencies and the volumes for different return periods depend on the height and the width of the considered cliff. Usually, the entire height of the cliff has to be considered, whereas the width to consider depends on the element at risk, which is not necessarily affected by the entire width of the cliff. For example, it may be the length of a road that run under the cliff. The occurrence frequency for different block volumes at the element at risk finally depends on their spatio-temporal release frequencies and their probabilities of reaching the element at risk (e.g., Corominas et al., 2005; Hantz et al., 2016, 2017, 2021; Moos et al., 2018).
In case the RFM takes rare events into account or if the long-term erosion rate of a cliff shall be estimated, it is further necessary to estimate a maximum possible rockfall volume. We here used a rather simple approach since little data on the cliff structure was available. Mavrouli and Corominas (2020) proposed a probabilistic methodology to assess the penetration of sliding planes into the slope, which is expected to deliver more precise results.
The sensitivity and uncertainty analysis revealed a high variability of the release scenarios with respect to the parameters of the RFM, increasing with the return period. Both, the rockfall event volumes and the block volumes, are particularly sensitive to the parameter B. Only the sites of Morcote and Orvin had the largest uncertainty coefficients for the parameter A

st
 for return periods between 10 and 100 yrs. This can be explained by the relatively small cliff sizes of these sites and thus an increasing V(F

t

) with increasing B for small return periods (see Eq. 9 and Appendix C).
Variations in the range of one or half a class width in the structure classification scheme for the determination of parameter B can result in large variations of the rockfall or block volume, especially for rare events (return period >100 yrs.; Appendix C). A more unambiguous and simple applicable method to determine parameter B is required for a practical implementation of the RFM. Additionally, the B parameters have to be further tested for their validity, since the classification scheme was developed based on inventory data from different sites in France, mainly limestone cliffs (Hantz et al., 2020) and might not be equally valid for the considered sites.
The main drawback of the here proposed rockfall frequency model is the difficulty to validate it properly since long-term measurements of release frequencies are generally rare. The expert-based release scenarios used for comparison in this study are themselves subject to many uncertainties and thus cannot be regarded as “true value”. A comparison to inventory data is also difficult since the rarely available data series are generally short and incomplete. Furthermore, information on block/event volumes is often unprecise (i.e., only estimated in classes or unclear whether block or event volume). Finally, rockfall inventories usually cover only events in the deposition area (or even only events that caused damages) and are thus rather representative for the occurrence frequency at the element at risk and not the release frequency. Nevertheless, the RFM is a promising and straightforward method to determine rockfall release scenarios where inventory data is scarce. Further testing at a wide variety of sites and for long-term observations (in the best case) could help increasing its robustness.


Funding
This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
Text.21:
1
Introduction
China is a mountainous country with a large population (Liu et al., 2015). In mountainous areas, geological hazards, such as rockfalls and rockslides, occur frequently that cause extensive damage to not only human lives and properties but also important infrastructure projects (Wang et al., 2012; Chai et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2017; Xu et al., 2020). Among these hazards, rockfalls are a type of hazards that occur frequently in mountainous areas and have the characteristics of high energy and mobility, which is difficult to predict and is prone to cause disasters (Ferrero et al., 2016). In the present study, we carry out analysis of the rockfall under special engineering geological conditions while combining a Chinese major engineering project “Sichuan–Tibet Railway” in operation.
The Sichuan–Tibet Railway is a railroad connecting Chengdu City, Sichuan Province and Lhasa City, Tibet Province in China with a total length of 1800 km (Wang et al., 2020). This transportation corridor runs through the Tibetan Plateau, with an overall geological performance of high seismic intensity, high ground stress, and high influences by freezing weathers as well as high and steep slopes (Zou et al., 2017). This study focuses on features with extremely high and steep rock slopes to analyze rockfalls in this particular area. Specifically, the tunnel portal of the Sichuan–Tibet Railway is threatened by rockfalls above it when crossing canyons. The tunnel portal is extremely high, which is unreachable for investigators, not to mention the initiation area of rockfalls above. Consequently, the characterization of the investigated rock slopes and subsequent rockfall analysis become much more challenging than traditional methodologies (Ma et al., 2014; Fanos and Pradhan, 2019).
Rock slopes encountered along the Sichuan–Tibet Railway are particularly different from common slopes, and their extreme height makes the investigations of topographies and collections of discontinuities rather difficult. To overcome the problem mentioned above, recent developments on non-contact measurements, such as close-range photogrammetry, terrestrial laser scanning technique, and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) photogrammetry, have provided the ability to obtain the georeferenced information of terrain data and discontinuities from reconstructed 3D point clouds. However, the inaccessibility of high and steep slopes results in the difficult deployment of instrumentations for the aforementioned methods, making UAV photogrammetry the only way to conduct photogrammetric surveys with characteristics of easy-operation and timesaving (Salvini et al., 2011; Spreafico et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2016; Martin et al., 2019). In previous works, UAV photogrammetry technique integrated with structure from motion (SfM) was efficiently utilized for discontinuity analysis and unstable block (discontinuity as the boundary) interpretation (Bordehore et al., 2017; Riquelme et al., 2017; Menegoni et al., 2019; Francioni et al., 2020), with applications to rockfall analysis (Macciotta et al., 2015; Ruiz-Carulla et al., 2017; Corominas et al., 2018; Sarro et al., 2018). However, the photography direction and large task distance of photogrammetry techniques currently used prevent the application along the Sichuan–Tibet Railway. In this research, a new remote sensing technique, nap-of-the-object photogrammetry (Liang et al., 2020), was used to perform photogrammetric surveys and rock structure analysis with features of close task distance and variable shooting direction.
The tunnel portal of the Sichuan–Tibet Railway is threatened by the rockfalls above. Therefore, understanding the trajectories of rockfalls and acquiring kinematic parameters, including velocity, kinetic energy, and jump height, are crucial for providing railway construction advice (Hibert et al., 2017). Existing research proposes an empirical method, a physical model experiment method, and a modeling with numerical simulation methods to perform rockfall analysis. However, the empirical method is based on a probabilistic approach, and it should be used as a guideline, rather than a precision tool (Alejano et al., 2008). The physical model experiment method is limited by the scale of the experiment and the inability to simulate real topographies; therefore, the kinematic parameters acquired sometimes differ significantly from the real values (Tan et al., 2018). Modeling with a numerical simulation method, including 2D and 3D modeling, can calculate accurate kinematic parameters on the basis of real topographies (Dorren, 2003; Wang et al., 2012; Kim et al., 2015; Li and Lan, 2015). However, interpreting the large number of unstable blocks as simulated disaster sources is extremely time consuming, and some unstable blocks do not pose threats to infrastructures. Some researchers determined the characteristics of rockfalls from historical information and triggering events to ascertain the associated risk along transportation networks. However, the investigated areas are mostly located in human settlements, which are inapplicable for uninhabited areas, where the history of rockfall is difficult to count (Guzzetti et al., 2003; Guzzetti et al., 2004). Therefore, determining critical unstable blocks, which threaten the tunnel portal, and conducting rockfall simulations are crucial to provide a statistical rockfall risk analysis.
The Sichuan–Tibet Railway's features, which include extremely high and steep rock slopes, make the characterization of rock slopes with potential rockfall hazards and the rockfall analysis more difficult than usual. Therefore, we employ the UAV nap-of-the-object photogrammetry technique with the characteristic of close flight distance to reconstruct a 3D geological model by acquiring high-resolution images of high and steep slopes. This method is clear and qualified for collecting information of discontinuities and interpreting unstable blocks. Then, we propose a methodology to perform well-directed rockfall simulations and a risk analysis by using 3D modeling and simulation software Rapid Mass Movement Simulation (RAMMS)::Rockfall (Glover et al., 2012). This methodology significantly narrows down the survey area by determining the potential-risk region and further utilizes designed simulations to guide us in locating critical disaster source areas and interpreting unstable blocks for well-directed simulations. It drastically reduces the effort to identify unstable blocks while providing a rockfall hazard risk analysis on the tunnel portal with few simulations.


2
Study area

2.1
Regional engineering geological settings
This railway connects the Chengdu City, Sichuan Province and the Lhasa City, Tibet Autonomous Region (Fig. 1
). The Sichuan–Tibet Railway, with a total length of 1800 km, was initiated in 2014. However, it has not been completed until today. As one of the important railway projects of China, it will greatly promote economic development, tourism development, and the infrastructure construction of the areas along the railway (Wei et al., 2018).
The study area is characterized by high altitudes and large elevation differences. The regional average elevation is >4000 m, with the lowest point located in Chengdu City with an elevation of 512 m and the highest point located in the peak of Mira Mountain with an elevation of 5018 m. A wide variety of landforms, such as mountains, rivers, and valleys, is developed in this area. Mountain ranges, such as Nyainqntanglha, Hengduan, and Himalayas, are characterized by highness and steepness features, with mountain summits reaching elevations >4000 m. The rivers are widely distributed throughout this area, such as the Nu, Jinsha, Lancang, Yarlung–Zangbo, Yigongzangbu, Dadu, and Ya-lung Rivers. Numerous valleys are developed with an average elevation difference of over 3000 m from the water surfaces to their respective summits (Zhao et al., 2021).
The collision between the India Plate and the Eurasia Plate induces active neotectonic movements and the intermittent uplift of Tibetan Plateau. Adjustments to the movement within the Tibetan Plateau have resulted in deep, active, and concentrated faults (Hu et al., 2019). (Fig. 2
). The railway runs through a number of well-developed faults, such as the Lancang River, Salween, Jiali, and Deqin Faults. These active faults severely endanger the security of bridges and tunnels along this railway. As a result of active tectonic movements, high-intensity earthquakes have occurred frequently. According to statistics, 150 earthquakes with Ms. ≥ 5.0 occurred in this area from 1950 to 2013 (Xue et al., 2020). Many geological hazards resulting from earthquakes, such as rockfalls and rockslides, constitute major threats to the construction and working of this railway.
The geological map demonstrates that lithologies of the study area are characterized by sedimentary, volcanic, and metamorphic rocks from the Quaternary to the Sinien. Sedimentary rocks are dominated by Mesozoic conglomerate, sand mudstone, sand shale, and tuff. Magmatic rocks are predominantly granite, amphibolite, and porphyry. Metamorphic rocks contain schist, slate, gneiss, and dacite, which have developed primarily in the Proterozoic Eonothem stratigraphy (Li et al., 2019).
The temperature in the study area changes with the season and altitude. The annual average temperature is between 7 °C and 10 °C, with a maximum temperature of 40 °C in July and a minimum temperature of −32 °C in January. The temperature decreases quickly as the altitude rises. In May, the temperature is measured at −8 °C at 5029 m and − 22 °C at 5944 m on the Mount Everest Precipitation, which is the spatially and temporally variable in the study area (Xu et al., 2017). Spatially, the annual precipitation in the area is between 450 and 1200 mm, and it is characterized by a gradual decrease from northeast to southwest. In 2017, the annual rainfall at Chengdu Station in the northeast of this area was 966.9 mm and at Lhasa Station in the southwest of this area was 550.6 mm. Temporally, precipitation is concentrated between May and September with 90% of it occurring during this period (Wu et al., 2020).


2.2
Geological settings of a case study – Kangyuqu area
This study takes the Kangyuqu area in the Changdu–Linzhi section of the Sichuan–Tibet Railway as the study object. The Kangyuqu area is laid on the west of the Luolong County, Changdu City, Tibet Autonomous Region. The Kangyuqu area is named after the Kangyuqu River flowing through here, with extremely high and steep slopes on both sides of the river, and the bridge built in this area is known as the Kangyuqu Bridge. The Kangyuqu Bridge, with a length of almost 400 m, crosses the river and connects both banks with two tunnel portals (respectively, the Changdu end of the Kangyuqu Tunnel and the Linzhi end of the Chada Tunnel), which are set in the intermediate part of the slopes with an elevation of 3433 m (Fig. 3a).
Characterized by typical mountain–canyon geomorphology, the left bank of the studied Kangyuqu area is lower than the right bank. The elevation of the left bank ranges from 3281 m to 4100 m in terms of distance from the river surface to the peak, whereas the range on the right bank is from 3281 m to 4600 m. The valley exhibits a “V” shape, where the Kangyuqu River flows in a direction of approximately 330° northwest with a river level elevation of approximately 3281 m.
Two main types of lithology from the Mesozoic Cretaceous have developed in this area. Fig. 3b and c illustrate that the rock masses on the right bank of the valley, where the Kangyuqu tunnel portal is located, are mainly gray slate interspersed with homogeneous metasandstone and coal seam. By contrast, the lithology of the left bank of the valley, where the Chada tunnel portal is located, is predominantly granodiorite. Located along the tectonically active Sichuan–Tibet Railway, compressive fault sets trending northwest–southeast are mainly developed near the Kangyuqu area. The large-scale and active fault zone is Basu, of which the closest fault is approximately 7 km from the Kangyuqu area. These active faults of the Basu fault zone are large in scale, with extension lengths of >100 km and widths from tens to hundreds of meters, intersecting at large angles with the tunnel alignment in the Kangyuqu area and controlling the distribution and development of adverse geology phenomena in the region.
Under the influence of extreme climatic conditions and complex geological structures, the high and steep slopes in this area are commonly characterized by poor rock integrity and extremely developed unstable rock masses, which pose significant threats of rockfalls to the tunnel portal.
According to the site investigation, the right bank of the Kangyuqu area is 1200 m in height, with bedrocks developed in the upper and lower parts with heights of 750 and 268 m as well as slope angles of 35° and 50°, respectively (Fig. 4a). Rockfalls occurring in the upper bedrock area formed the colluvial deposits with a width of 800 m, a height of 200 m, and a slope angle of 16° between two parts of the bedrock areas (Fig. 4b). The rockfalls also result in the accumulation of numerous boulders on the deposit surface, with small sizes staying on the deposit's upper part and large boulders resting on the deposit's front edge (Fig. 4c). The tunnel portal will be located 300 m from the deposit edge, within the lower bedrock area. As a consequence of the considerable distance between the tunnel portal and the colluvial deposits, the falling rocks may not be able to approach the tunnel portal, and even if they do, they will be halted by the developed bedrock that functions as a barrier behind the tunnel portal.
A field investigation reveals that the left bank of the Kangyuqu area is 500 m high (Fig. 4a), and the joints and fractures are greatly developed due to climatic and tectonic conditions in the bedrock area, which is 230 m in height with a slope angle of 55°, resulting in a large number of unstable blocks. These unstable blocks are detached from the bedrock and accumulated beneath it to form the colluvial deposits, which are 540 m in width, 350 m in height, with a slope of 26° (Fig. 4d). The accumulated boulders of various sizes are on the deposit surface, most of which are gathered on the intermediate segment of deposits, where the left bank tunnel portal is designed to be built (Fig. 4e). Considering that the tunnel portal is planned right below the bedrock area and within the movement of rockfalls, it is more susceptible to the threat of rockfalls, and the left bank slope is chosen to perform the rockfall analysis.



3
Methodologies

3.1
UAV nap-of-the-object photogrammetry

3.1.1
Introduction
UAV is a remote-controlled aircraft equipped with a self-contained program control device. With the development of unmanned aerial systems and digital cameras, the UAV platform has become more accessible and easier to be operated, and the equipped digital camera can perform the photography process, allowing UAV with a camera to be employed to perform the field surveys of photogrammetry (Tuckey, 2022).
Conventional UAV photogrammetry methods comprise vertical and oblique types. UAV vertical photogrammetry employs an on-board camera photography vertically downward, and all shooting positions are in a horizontal plane, which covers the survey area. The resolution of images varies greatly because the task distance from the camera to the ground is inconsistent for each image (Fig. 5a); for example, the slope foot images that do not have higher resolutions than those obtained at positions with close distances from slope top. Therefore, vertical photogrammetry technique enables the generation of DEM and DSM (3D surface model) (Kršák et al., 2016), and it is unsuitable for discontinuity extraction and unstable block interpretation due to the large variation in resolution (Roncella et al., 2005).
Oblique photogrammetry utilizes five on-board digital cameras to acquire images, with the middle camera shooting vertically downward and the four remaining cameras spread around to capture oblique images at a fixed angle (Fig. 5b) (Yang et al., 2022). A predefined route planning enables the UAV to maintain an approximately consistent task distance from the ground, resulting in images with slight variation in resolution. Compared with vertical photogrammetry, oblique type provides images in more directions with higher resolutions. However, the redundant images acquired by the five on-board camera system are more than the useful images, resulting in excessive inefficiency. The large size of the adopted UAV of oblique photogrammetry allows flight distance to be set to a large number to prevent crashing with obstructions. Therefore, the 3D model reconstructed from oblique photogrammetry is insufficient to identify small-sized discontinuities (Wang et al., 2022).
The 3D model rebuilt from vertical and oblique types with inadequate accuracy and quality is insufficient to identify small-sized discontinuities and acquire associated information. Nap-of-the-object photogrammetry was proposed in 2018 by Zhang Zuxun, Professor of Wuhan University, to take images of objects by using portable UAV with a close distance (Liang et al., 2020). Then, DJI implements UAV flight continuously to the slope orientation with a task distance between 5 and 100 m by adopting 3D flight route planning (DJI, 2020). Compared with vertical and oblique types, nap-of-the-object photogrammetry uses the slope surface of a small area as the photographic object, and the photography angle is set to be perpendicular to the slope. Finally, based on the short flight distance and variable camera angles, the image resolution is sufficiently high to represent the actual terrain more delicately and realistically due to the close flight distance (Fig. 5c).
Nap-of-the-object photogrammetry employs precise 3D route planning to allow UAV to photograph a limited area of slope with a close flight distance. The initial terrain information obtained using conventional photogrammetry methods is used to divide the complicated terrain into several terrain units. Then, along a parallel direction with a close distance, several spatial planes are created to cover these units. Some flight characteristics, such as the flight path, speed, and overlap, are predefined and included in the 3D route planning to direct UAV in acquiring high-resolution images of the survey area. Finally, based on these images, the SfM and multiple view stereo (MVS) techniques are used to reconstruct the survey area in 3D.
The procedural steps of the UAV nap-of-the-object photogrammetry employed in this work are depicted in Fig. 6
. The new photogrammetry approach can be divided into four components: initial terrain information acquisition (step a), 3D flight rouge planning (step b), and automatic flight with image collection (step c) are the three steps of field work. The photogrammetric processing (step d) is the major focus of indoor work.


3.1.2
Field works
The field activities of nap-of-the-object photogrammetry consist of three steps: initial terrain information acquisition, 3D flight route planning, and flight operation, including automatic flight and photography. To work in the plateau with harsh circumstances and obtain high-resolution and quality images, a portable UAV with great performance and a high-quality on-board camera are necessary.
In this study, we employ a quadcopter DJI M300 RTK with DJI Zenmuse P1 to perform photogrammetric surveys. DJI M300 RTK has the characteristics of being operated in the work environments with an altitude reaching 7000 m and a temperature ranging from −20 °C to 50 °C, which make it suitable for surveys in the study area. The camera DJI Zenmuse P1 produces 45-megapixel format (8192 × 5460) images. The sensor size of the camera is 35.9 × 24 mm, and the smallest size of the image point is 4.4 μm (Riordan et al., 2021). The detailed specifications of UAV and the on-board camera are shown in Table 1
.
The initial terrain information is obtained by conventional photogrammetry methods with a resolution that may not be high enough for the 3D flight route planning. The oblique photogrammetry method is appropriate to acquire low-resolution images with preset flight parameters, including the flight distance, speed, and overlap along the path and between two parallel paths. As a result, all images covering the survey area are acquired for the generation of a DEM, which is used to perform the 3D flight route planning.
The 3D flight planning can effectively direct UAV to photographing positions with specific planning parameters (Hernandez-Lopez et al., 2013). It is the most significant part of the field activities and has a great influence on the accuracy and quality of the following generation of georeferenced data, such as 3D point clouds, DEM, and orthophotos (Jimenez-Jimenez et al., 2021). Based on the initial terrain information, the survey area is divided into several terrain units based on their occurrences, and the coordinates of the triangle vertices contained within each terrain unit are subsequently used for spatial plane fitting, as illustrated in Fig. 7
. Then, by setting a certain flight distance from the fitted spatial planes that is typically between 5 and 100 m, multiple flight planes are created. Finally, the 3D flight planning is designed as flight lines that are parallel to one another and located on the flight planes. The camera angle is automatically set to be perpendicular to the fitted planes. The flight and shooting speeds are crucial parameters for the influence on image quality and power consumption, which should be predefined cautiously to avoid motion blur and short flight (Di Franco and Buttazzo, 2016). The image overlap allows the photogrammetric processing of images to utilize the resulting redundancy to ensure the 3D point cloud generation from dense multi-image matching (Martinez-Martinez et al., 2017). By importing the flight planning into the UAV flight control system, UAV takes off and automatically performs the photographing process to collect images on the basis of the planning parameters.
In the flight operation, the survey is carried out with a flight planning implemented to cover the survey area with a task distance between 5 and 100 m, an appropriate flight speed, and an automatic triggering of images. The minimum overlap between image frames is suggested to set at 90% along the flight path and 70% between two parallel flight paths. As a result of field work, high-resolution images are collected and used in the subsequent 3D model reconstruction and georeferenced data generation in Section 3.1.3.


3.1.3
Lab works
After acquiring high-resolution images from field works, the SfM technique uses pseudo-random redundant images from multiple photographing positions and angles to recover the 3D model of an object (Vanneschi et al., 2019). Various kinds of software are proposed and have been developed in recent years for the 3D reconstruction combining with the SfM technique, such as ContextCapture, Pix4D, Agisoft, VisualSFM, and DJI Terra.
In this study, DJI Terra was applied to process images, and a general workflow containing some sections of data processing would be followed by DJI Terra. First, the images were uploaded into the software, and the associated photographing positions information was imported. Second, the scale-invariant feature algorithm was adopted to match the key features of images (Lowe, 2004), and sparse cloud point was generated by the SfM technique (Westoby et al., 2012). Third, the MVS algorithm was employed to densify the sparse point cloud (Wang et al., 2021), and Delaunay triangulation algorithm and texture mapping were used to reconstruct the 3D model on the basis of the dense point cloud generated before (Zhou and Xiao, 2017). Finally, some georeferenced data, such as DEM and DOM, could be created with same resolutions as the images.



3.2
Well-directed rockfall simulations considering critical disaster sources

3.2.1
Rockfall simulation approaches
Certain rockfall simulation and modeling approaches have been presented and developed in order to provide a statistical and realistic analysis for the rockfall problem.(Lan et al., 2007). In comparison to 2D simulation and modeling, 3D approaches, such as RocPro3D, RockyFor 3D, CRSP-3D (Colorado Rockfall Simulation Program), STONE, and RAMMS::Rockfall, have proven to be helpful tools for assessing rockfall hazards with the capability to offer a spatial distribution of rockfall trajectories (Agliardi and Crosta, 2003; Moon et al., 2014; Corona et al., 2017).
RAMMS::Rockfall is a new module for estimating rigid body movements of falling rocks in the RAMMS program (Vick et al., 2019). It constructs a valid computational model for simulating rockfall trajectories in 3D terrain using a hard-contact, rigid-body technique. The hard-contact technique accounts for the influence of rock shape on rock-terrain interaction and allows for the representation of major motion modes, such as sliding, rolling, skipping, and jumping (Leine et al., 2014) (Fig. 8
). It differs from previous rockfall simulation programs in that the interaction between the rock and the terrain is governed by the frictional interaction, rather than by simple rebound mechanics. Previous researches show that RAMMS::Rockfall is a good tool for numerical simulation and rockfall analysis (Wendeler et al., 2016).
Before the simulation, the following parameters must be prepared: (1) digital elevation data with a matched orthophoto of the study area in an appropriate resolution; (2) simulated rock characteristics, such as the locations of disaster sources and rock volumes; and (3) simulated terrain properties, such as terrain materials and forested areas.
The distribution of rockfall trajectories and the prediction of the run-out distance can be achieved by combining these parameters. It also allows for the calculation and observation of kinematic parameters, including velocity, kinetic energy, and jump height in the 3D trajectory model. To obtain precise information for a rockfall risk study, a statistical analysis of several trajectories that reach a specific location is provided. Profile views, which show the current parameters, may also be used to evaluate a single trajectory in depth.


3.2.2
Procedures to perform well-directed rockfall simulations
Unstable blocks, as disaster sources of rockfall hazards, are widely distributed along the Sichuan–Tibet Railway, resulting in a large number of potential rockfalls. Identifying all of them and performing rockfall simulations are difficult and time consuming. Therefore, we propose a methodology, including a series of procedures to locate unstable blocks that threaten the tunnel portal and conduct well-directed rockfall simulations. It narrows down the source areas by determining the potential-risk region and reduces the workload of the unstable block identification by determining critical disaster source areas.
The procedures comprise four steps as shown in Fig. 9
: (a) potential-risk region determination; (b) critical disaster source area determination; (c) well-directed rockfall simulation process; and (d) statistical analysis of rockfall risk on a tunnel portal.

(a)
Potential-risk region determination.



The field investigation indicates that the rockfall source region can be classified into risk-free and potential-risk regions on the basis of slope aspects that have significant impacts on rockfall propagation. According to the aspects of the slope where the infrastructure is located, the rockfalls occurring on the slopes with specified aspects will not pose threats, and these areas can be considered risk-free regions. However, we are more concerned about the potential-risk region, which contains critical disaster source areas that is determined in step (b).

(b)
Critical disaster source area determination.



The potential-risk region determined in step (a) still has a large number of unstable blocks that must be identified. Therefore, critical disaster source areas containing unstable blocks that threaten the tunnel portal should be identified. Designed rockfall simulations are performed to locate the critical disaster source areas in the potential-risk region.
Designed rockfall simulations are conducted to investigate rockfall trajectory distributions, and the simulation processes are described as followed: First, DEM data with appropriate resolutions are selected to represent the 3D terrain. Second, the entire potential -risk region is divided into several areas with specific dimensions, and the center point of each area is selected as the release point. Then, terrain materials and forested areas as terrain properties can be defined by drawing or importing polygon shapefiles with various terrain and forested types according to the information collected from the field investigation and terrain property specifications. Finally, the simulations are performed by launching a hundred rocks for one release point with the same volume parameter, and the trajectories of each rock are calculated and observed on the 3D rockfall model.
After acquiring the trajectory distribution of each point, a new variable—reach probability—is subsequently calculated as the proportion that the total number of rocks reaching the tunnel portal accounts for the full number of simulated rocks. If the probability value of a release point is greater than a critical value, then it means the risk to the tunnel portal from the rockfall developed in the area indicated by a center point is large, which can be regarded as a rockfall critical disaster source area.
The unstable blocks developed in critical disaster source areas pose significant threats to the tunnel portal, and they must be identified and interpreted for subsequent simulations. The detailed method to determine volume of potential rockfall and the persistence of the discontinuities will be discussed in Section 4.2. The associated characteristics of rockfall from critical disaster source areas are used in step (c) for well-directed simulations.

(c)
Well-directed rockfall simulation process.



In step (b), the reach probabilities of each release point representing a small area are utilized to determine the critical disaster source areas. The release probability is also necessary for risk analysis. The release probability is also necessary for risk analysis. The probability of release for unstable block is not considered because the mean frequency of the occurrence of rockfall events cannot be obtained from historical catalogues in such an uninhabited area (Hantz et al., 2021). In view of the influence of rockfall on tunnel portal in this study, the final result tends to show an important impact on the tunnel portal without considering the release probability, which is more suitable for providing protection suggestion of major railways.
This step follows a well-directed rockfall simulation process on the basis of the identified unstable blocks to investigate kinematic parameters, and the simulation process is the same as the method in step (b). Finally, fully considering the simulated parameters, kinematic parameters, including velocity, kinetic energy, and jump height, are calculated and can be seen for rock trajectories, which provide the capability to perform a statistical kinematic analysis.

(d)
Rockfall disaster analysis on the tunnel portal.



The statistical analysis is performed after all of the results each unstable block have been collected, including trajectory distributions and kinematic parameters. By understanding the positions of the tunnel portal on the model, the trajectories that reach or halt at the tunnel portal are collected.
The statistical function of the simulation program aids us in the subsequent kinematic analysis. As a consequence, the rocks hitting the tunnel portal will have a kinetic energy range, a velocity range, and a maximum jump height, which can be used to provide recommendations for railway and tunnel portal construction.




4
Generation of 3D slope model and feasibility of unstable block detection

4.1
3D slope model generation by nap-of-the-object photogrammetry
As discussed in Section 2.2, the left bank slope of the Kangyuqu area was selected as the survey area, and its initial terrain information was then obtained by an oblique photogrammetry survey, as stated in Section 3.1.2 with a flight distance of 200 m, speed of 2 m/s, and an overlap along the path and between two parallel paths of 75% and 65%, respectively. As a result, a total of 700 images were acquired for the generation of initial terrain data, including DEM and orthophotos, which were subsequently used to perform the 3D flight planning.
The 3D flight planning was created using the initial terrain information that had been collected previously. In this study, the detailed flight planning implemented to cover the left bank slope of the Kangyuqu area was determined with a distance between UAV and a slope of 50 m, a flight speed of 6 m/s, and an automatic triggering of images every 2 s (Fig. 10
). The minimum overlap between image frames along the flight path was 90%, and the minimum overlap between two parallel flight paths was 70%.
The automatic flight operation and image collection were performed after importing the whole 3D flight planning into the flight control system of DJI M300 RTK, which was employed for the nap-of-the-object photogrammetric survey. As a result, a total of 2500 images with a resolution range of 0.005–0.046 m were collected and used for subsequent 3D model reconstruction and georeferenced data generation.
The photogrammetric processing software DJI Terra was used in this study, and 2500 images previously captured were imported with interior orientations and photographing position parameters, as describe in Section 3.1.3. Finally, a 3D geological model of the left bank slope was reconstructed with a same resolution range as the above images. Various DEM with different resolutions were created for the terrain modeling in the rockfall simulation.


4.2
Unstable block analyses

4.2.1
Discontinuity analysis
With characteristics of high accuracy and quality, the discontinuities developed in rock masses can be easily identified in the established 3D model. We adopted the way of manual interpretation to perform the discontinuity analysis. Discontinuity is exposed as planes and linear traces can be clearly observed on high-resolution model, and no evident orientation change occurs, conforming to the characteristics of discontinuity. The coordinates of each selected point on the discontinuity can be acquired. The fractures were determined from the model by manually extracting three of more points and fitting spatial planes to individual discontinuities. The discontinuity persistence is basically the spatial extent of the fitted planes. For planar discontinuity, the persistence can be calculated as the distance between the two most distant points of the fracture within the exposed range. For linear discontinuity, the persistence is the distance between two end points. Discontinuity orientations, including dip directions and dip angles, are obtained based on a series of mathematical calculation steps of the normal vectors of the fitted planes (Sturzenegger and Stead, 2009).
In this section, we identified and interpreted 2434 discontinuities developed on the left bank slope with a dip direction of 60°. The analysis shows the five dominant groups of discontinuities of the left bank slope with homogeneity, including J1 (307°/82°), J2 (30°/77°), J3 (153°/12°), J4 (123°/57°), and J5 (89°/82°). J1, J3, and J4 are sets of relevant discontinuities, together with random fractures form unstable blocks. Fig. 11
 shows the identification of discontinuities in a small area above the tunnel portal.
Given the high resolution of the 3D model, we used automatic discontinuity extraction based on the calculation of normal vector of point clouds to represent a comparison between automatic measurement and manual measurement. An example is given in Fig. 12
, the result shows that large-scale discontinuities exposed as planes are well identified and delineated with calculation of dip directions and dip angles. However, they are unsuitable for discontinuities exposed as linear traces, which are an important part of unstable blocks. They can easily identify linear fractures in 3D model and point cloud, but the automatic extraction technique overlooked them. This finding can be explained by the application of the plane-based algorithm, and non-plane features were untreated. In addition, small-scale discontinuities were often neglected in automatic extraction in fractured rock mass area, especially structurally complex areas (Kong et al., 2021). Therefore, we used expert-based extraction in this research to perform discontinuity and unstable block analysis.


4.2.2
Unstable blocks analysis
In Section 3.2.2, we discussed how to locate areas containing unstable blocks as critical disaster sources for targeted rockfall simulations. This section discusses the feasibility of geometric and mechanical analyses of unstable blocks by using block theory and a 3D geological model.
The unstable blocks failure modes are mainly toppling and sliding types. As shown in Fig. 13
, type A belongs to the toppling unstable blocks, which are developed in steep slope. Under the cutting action of multiple groups of fractures, blocks are formed on the slope surface. Once the control fracture of the trailing edge is penetrated, it produces a toppling failure. Type B belongs to the sliding unstable blocks, which lose bottom support. The influence of gravity or rainwater reduces the rock mass strength. When the sliding force exceeds the anti-sliding force, once the control fracture is penetrated, it produces a sliding failure.
The stability analyses are on the basis of discontinuity acquisition and understanding of failure mode. Block theory was proposed by R. E. Goodman and G. H. Shi in 1981 (Shi and Goodman, 1981); they assumed rock mass as a rigid body and that the damage comes from self-weight or external load, rather than from block strength.
