Several recent studies propose a substantial link between road related landslides in Nepal and the investment of time, knowledge and funds in road construction (Dahal et al., 2006; Lennartz, 2013; Froude and Petley, 2018; Sudmeier-Rieux et al., 2019). Froude and Petley (2018) found that 43% of the fatal landslides that were triggered by construction in Nepal occurred along roads compared to only 7% in China. The failure of these roadside cuttings, along formal and informal roads, can have devastating economic and social consequences (Froude and Petley, 2018; McAdoo et al., 2018).
Most practitioners in Nepal use guidelines for road cuttings that are published by the Government of Nepal Department of Roads e.g. Department of Roads (2007, 2013, 2016). These guidelines do not include the excavation history of the road, nor do they include user inputs for a specified FoS.
We conducted qualitative data collection to find out about the consistency of the knowledge of practitioners that are in charge of the design of road cuttings with one another. Questionnaires were sent via email to four different engineering organisations/companies based in Nepal. 14 completed questionnaires from practitioners were received. The questionnaires were short (five questions) to encourage completion and they were answered anonymously as they were not aiming to test the individual participants' knowledge. The participants were asked to use the resources that they typically employed to determine rock cutting inclinations for new cuttings. Each question included a picture of a roadside cutting in Nepal alongside characteristics for the cutting including: cutting height; weathering grade; hardness; rock type; road type; and cutting history. The participants then had to select one of three possible cutting inclination ranges that would be appropriate for that cutting. The answers included the most appropriate range according to a key Nepali design manual Department of Roads (2007), and the two other ranges which either both sat above, both sat below or one sat above and one sat below the most appropriate range. The second part to the question asked the practitioner to outline what characteristics they used to make that judgement. The questionnaire outcomes were processed and analysed using NVivo (QSR International Pty Ltd., 2020) to find the common relationships between the characteristics and inclination, in addition to assessing what characteristics are typically used. We reviewed the answers to the questions selecting the appropriate cutting angle range against the guidelines given in Department of Roads (2007). Across all questions 29% to 93% of participants chose the most appropriate inclination range. On average, 50% of participants chose the most appropriate answer with a standard deviation of 25%. ‘Rock type’ was the most prevalent characteristic chosen to be prioritised in selecting a stable cutting inclination. Whilst the ‘height of the slope’ was stated alongside the greatest proportion of correct ranges of inclination.
The results of the questionnaires suggest that among the practitioners in Nepal there is considerable variability in their knowledge and the resources that they use. The rigor of the Department of Roads (2007) guidelines is discussed further in Section 4.1. Based on the findings of this qualitative data collection, we argue that there is a need for new guidelines for roadside cutting inclinations that are clear and that can be easily used by a wider range of practitioners.


2.7.2
Background to road cuttings in Ethiopia
Ethiopia has extensive highlands that range from 1500 to 3500 m above sea level. Plateaus formed from successive basalt lava flows are a common feature in the landscape. These plateaus have been cut by river channels resulting in several valleys exhibiting cliffs and benches (Hearn and Massey, 2009). Ethiopia's road network has expanded from 20,000 to 110,000 km over the last three decades so exposure to cutting failure hazard has also grown with road construction and widening projects often triggering cutting instabilities (Hearn, 2018). As with other LIC/LMICs in mountainous areas, the stabilisation of road cuttings can be inhibited by poor understanding of landslide processes (Hearn and Shakya, 2017). As Ethiopia looks to expand its road network further, with an aim of totalling 201,750 km by 2028, slope stabilisation is critical to minimise future losses (Hearn, 2018).


2.7.3
Nepal specific methodology
Common Nepali rock types, identified by field observations and literature, were categorised into six groups (‘Very weak’ to ‘Extremely hard’) with discrete ranges of UCS based on the Brown (1981) hardness scale. Values for m

i
 and γ for common rocks in Nepal were identified using Marinos and Hoek (2000) and Fine (2021) respectively. We were able to corroborate and amend these values using published literature for rocks in Nepal (Khanna and Dubey, 2021; Panthee et al., 2016) for the majority of the metamorphic rocks. The midpoint of each UCS range is assigned to each rock group, whilst the mean of m

i
 and γ values are assigned. As the values for UCS, γ and m

i
 are assigned to the rock groups, they do not have to be chosen by practitioners. The values for UCS, γ and m

i
 were, therefore, not included in the tables to keep the tables as concise and user-friendly as possible. Instead, the ranges of reported values for each rock group and their assigned value are stated in Table 1, in addition to the values chosen to represent GSI.
The L, I and H values for GSI for each rock group were assigned by evaluating Marinos and Hoek (2000), as discussed in the methodology. These values are outlined in the resulting set of tables, alongside guidance for the practitioner on how to select the GSI category. For residual soils we determined L, I and H strength combinations of c

'
 and ϕ

'
 based on those outlined in Table 1 of Ray et al. (2019).
We included four values for the height of the cuttings that capture the typical range of cutting heights along roads in Nepal: 5, 10, 20, and 30 m based on field observations conducted in 2019 along local and strategic roads in the Nepali provinces of Bagmati and Province No. 2.
Blasting in Nepal is currently primarily planned and executed by the Nepali army in a controlled manner. A pneumatic drill is used to drill holes of 32–36 mm diameter to a depth of 1–3 m (Directorate of Development and Construction, Nepali Army, 2020). The standard depth of excavation to achieve a specified cutting is 300 mm deep into a rock face (Department of Roads, 2018). Given that excavation to this depth will cause negligible disturbance, we assumed a D value of zero to the entire cutting where these modern blasting methods are used. A D value of zero is also imposed where only mechanical excavation has taken place (consistent with recommendations of Hoek et al. (2002); Hoek (2012)). Older roadside cuttings excavated >30 years ago, are more likely to have been subject to uncontrolled blasting that would disturb the cutting. To account for the different disturbance scenarios, we include two tables of guidelines for roadside cutting inclinations in Nepal: (1) for young (< 30 year old) or mechanically excavated cuttings (Table 2) and (2) for historically blasted cuttings where blasting may have been uncontrolled (Table 3). Following the aforementioned methodology we found that eight layers were optimal to represent disturbance in the PLM.
A check was carried out to see if each cutting inclinations presented in the guidelines is compliant with Eurocode 7 Design Approach 1 Combinations 1 & 2. It was found that they all had an Over Design Factor of greater than one, thereby, being compliant.
Hillslope inclinations of 15 and 30∘ were chosen to represent hillslope topography for roadside cuttings in Nepal. The analyses were only performed for undisturbed cutting as there is great complexity in setting up a model that incorporates a PLM with an inclined upslope boundary. For disturbed cases with non-horizontal topography, it is recommended that numerical analyses are conducted on a slope-by-slope basis. We then used the methodology presented above to develop guidelines for undisturbed road cuttings with upslope boundaries inclined at 30∘ (Table 4) and 15∘ (Table 5). In some cases for cuttings in ‘Very weak’ and ‘Weak’ geomaterial with inclined topography of 30∘ (Table 4) it was not possible to determine cutting angles to generate the required FoS. In these cases, the cutting angle and upper slope angle were too similar (typically within 10∘ of one another), and the failure surface extends far upslope resulting in a low FoS. In these instances an ‘X' is placed in the table.
By following the method outlined in Section 2.6, we conducted seepage and stability analyses to identify the seepage conditions under which our tables are valid. The resulting seepage guidelines are displayed as Tables 6, 7, 8, and 9. A symbol (†) was used in the table to denote cases where l

w
 was calculated or l

w
 = 0 and h

w
 = 0.


2.7.4
Ethiopia specific methodology
The methodology presented in Sections 2.1 - 2.4 was followed to develop guidelines for road cuttings in Ethiopia. The common Ethiopian rock types to characterise the rock groups in these guidelines were taken from the ‘typical rock and soil types’ outlined in Table 5 of Hearn and Pettifer (2016). Hearn and Pettifer (2016) included these rock types based on field observations and from those outlined in Ayalew et al. (2009). Only five groups were included in the undisturbed guidelines for Ethiopia, as compared to six for Nepal. This is because Ethiopian geomaterials that would fit into the ‘Extremely hard’ group are less common. The G-H-B parameter values were then estimated for each group using the methododology presented. Values of UCS, GSI and m

i
 were determined for the Ethiopian geomaterials using Marinos and Hoek (2000). The majority of values of γ were taken from Fine (2021). Estimates of γ for Tuff were taken from Asniar et al. (2019) who evaluate the properties of Tuff from around the world (values specific to Ethiopia were not found). As with Nepal, we included four values for the heights of the cutting that cover the majority of typical cutting sizes along roads in Ethiopia: 5, 10, 20 and 30 m. Blasting in Ethiopia is currently carried out in a controlled manner along roads by the Ethiopian army (personal communications in 2020). In the past, uncontrolled blasting may have been used to excavate roads. Therefore, two tables are developed for Ethiopia to account for: (1) mechanical excavation or controlled blasting (Table 10) and (2) uncontrolled blasting that may have taken place in the past (Table 11).




3
Results

3.1
Set of guidelines
In this section we present guidelines for Nepal and Ethiopia using the methodology introduced in this paper.
The following tables are included in the guidelines for road cuttings in Nepal, with associated tables for acceptable seepage scenarios in parentheses:

•
Flat topography:

−
Mechanically excavated: Table 2 (Table 6)


−
Excavated through historical blasting: Table 3 (Table 7)





•
Topography inclined at 30∘ over the horizontal: Table 4 (Table 8)


•
Topography inclined at 15∘ over the horizontal: Table 5 (Table 9)



The following tables are included in the guidelines for road cuttings in Ethiopia:

•
Flat topography:

−
Mechanically excavated: Table 10



−
Excavated through historical blasting: Table 11







To derive a cutting inclination from the resulting guidelines, a practitioner should: (1) determine the excavation method of the cutting and select the appropriate table to represent the disturbance, (2) select the hardness group for the cutting by carrying out the field tests outlined in the table; (3) decide on the appropriate level of safety required based on the consequence of failure along the road, (4) select the cutting height; and (5) select a L/I/H GSI (or c

'
, ϕ

'
 combination) category for the cutting using the descriptions in the table for guidance. Further guidance on how to use the guidelines is given in Appendix A.3.












3.2
Nepali applications
To demonstrate use of the guidelines, three cases exhibiting differing slope conditions along roads in Nepal are presented in Tables 12, 13 and 14


. The cases are all of a post failure cutting. The guidelines are used to demonstrate what inclination the cuttings would need to be cut to for stability of the desired FoS.


3.3
Trends
Here we discuss the trends observed in the guidelines developed for Nepal and Ethiopia. Across all tables the following trends can be observed: (1) steeper inclinations with increasing hardness; (2) steeper inclinations with higher GSI values (and combinations of c

'
 and ϕ

'
); (3) steeper inclinations with decreasing cutting height; and (4) steeper inclinations with lower FoS. These trends reflect well known physical principles of slope stability: a higher strength of the slope geomaterials and lower slope height are beneficial to slope stability so the cutting can be made steeper; likewise a lower requirement in terms of FoS allows a more aggressive cutting.
In Table 2, there is great variability in the inclinations outlined in the ‘Very weak’ category (e.g. residual soils) from the low to high strength combinations of c

'
 and ϕ

'
 due to the significant difference in the values of c

'
 and ϕ

'
 from Ray et al. (2019) in each category. It can be noted that some of the cutting inclinations prescribed for high strength residual soils are close to vertical. The higher strength residual soils are likely to be weathered ‘Hard’-‘Extremely hard’ rock, reflected by their M-C parameter values (Wesley, 2010).
Many of the tables (Tables 2, 3, 5, 10 and 11) include prescribed inclinations that are below 30∘ in the strength categories of ‘Very weak’ and ‘Weak’. Cuttings of such shallow inclinations could require the removal of significant volumes of material. Where this is not feasible, the construction of additional slope stabilisation measures (e.g. walls or anchors) may be adopted to allow a steeper cutting inclination.
The steepest possible (i.e. vertical) cutting inclination is recommended for slopes made up of ‘Hard’, ‘Very hard’ or ‘Extremely hard’ rock across all tables. Even uncontrolled blasting (Tables 3 and 11) makes no difference to the cutting inclination for the hardest (i.e. ‘Very hard’ and ‘Extremely hard’) rocks independent of GSI; nor for ‘Moderate’ or ‘Hard’ rocks, if they have experienced little weathering (GSI=H). This is true irrespective of cutting height and choice of FoS and is likely because these materials can all sustain vertical cuttings. When blasting disturbance is limited (e.g. Tables 2, 10, 4 and 5) they are likely even more stable (higher FoS) than in the case of cuttings with blast disturbance (Tables 3 and 11); however, in both cases they could sustain an overhang at the FoS values examined here. Because overhangs are not considered, blasting has no observable effect.
In non-vertical cases, blasting can have a very large impact on the cutting angle. For the cutting inclinations in Nepali ‘Weak’ rock with flat topographies, blasting reduced the angle by 11–44∘ and 25∘ on average; for the inclinations in ‘Moderate’ rock the range was 6–47∘ and the mean 27∘ (excluding cases that remained vertical). Such large reductions would have very significant implications for the cost (and even the feasibility) of implementing a cutting.
We compared the guidelines developed for Nepal and Ethiopia by evaluating the absolute differences in cutting inclinations for each equivalent scenario in the ‘Very weak’-‘Moderate’ groups of the tables for mechanically excavated cuttings in flat topography. We ignored ‘Hard’-‘Extremely hard’ groups since they can sustain vertical cuttings in all cases. The mean difference in cutting inclinations across all scenarios was 4∘, whilst the maximum was 39∘. The greatest difference in cutting inclination was in the ‘Very weak’ group with a median of 15∘ whilst the median for the ‘Weak’ group was 3∘ and for the ‘Moderate’ group was 0∘ (implying no functional difference).
In comparing the Nepal table with flat topography (Table 2) to those with inclined topography (Tables 4 and 5), the following can be stated: (1) the scenarios with vertical inclinations were unchanged, (2) for non-vertical scenarios, the cutting inclinations in Table 2 are up to 4∘ higher than than those in Table 4 (30∘ inclined) and, (3) for non-vertical scenarios, the cutting inclinations in Table 2 are up to 1∘ higher than in Table 5 (15∘ inclined). Based on these results, it may not be necessary to perform stability analyses to develop guidelines for an inclined upslope.

Tables 6, 7, 8 and 9 present h

w
 values which are used to describe the threshold level of slope saturation where seepage starts to affect the stability of the cutting, i.e. the resulting FoS deviates from the values obtained in the dry case. The higher h

w
, the lower the height of the phreatic line that affects the stability of the cutting (i.e. the greater affect that seepage has on the stability of the cutting). The tables indicate that the largest h

w
 values are in the weakest rock group. Within a rock grouping (row in the table), the largest h

w
 values tend to be in the taller cuttings and for lower GSI values. Therefore, as expected, the weaker and/or taller the cutting, the greater the influence of seepage on stability. Also the largest h

w
 values are in the tables for the cuttings with an inclined upslope boundary (Tables 8 and 9). This relationship is a reference frame effect created by measuring the depth of the phreatic surface at the upslope. Some of these relationships can be observed in Fig. 5
, which displays the results of the seepage and stability analyses on a 30 m high cutting made up of ‘Very weak’ and ‘Extremely hard’ geomaterials for both flat and inclined upslope topographies.
Across all tables, the majority of vertical cutting designs are not affected by seepage (l

w
 = 0 and h

w
 = 0). Only a small number of vertical cutting cases at the lowest GSI and 30 m height are affected by seepage conditions, albeit with h

w
 being very small, in Tables 7, 8 and 9.


3.4
Failure mechanisms
The failure mechanisms observed in the results of the stability analyses typically originate from a distance of 0.2–1 times cutting height upslope of the cutting crest and daylight at the toe of the cutting. Generally, the weaker the material, the shallower the failure (this can be observed in Fig. 5a compared to 5c). The non-circular failure mechanisms observed in the results of the disturbed cuttings (with PLM) were very shallow for the weaker rocks, with the failure planes being at the intersection of the second to third layer (1–2 m) or third to fourth layer (3–4 m) of the PLM. This is expected given the strong sensitivity of the G-H-B strength envelope to D, reflecting the decline in rock strength with disturbance caused by excavation, and since D declines from the surface, the surface rock assigned has a very weak G-H-B strength envelope. The failure occurs along the intersections of the layers, as these are the points of maximum depth within a weaker material.
For cuttings excavated in inclined topographies, the failure mechanism originated slightly further upslope than those in horizontal topographies at a distance of 0.4–2 times the cutting height back from the crest and daylight at the toe of the cutting (this can be observed in Fig. 5 by comparing 5a to 5b). For some of the vertical cuttings with inclined topographies, the critical failure mechanism originated much further upslope (see Fig. 5d). As with the horizontal topography, the weaker the material, the shallower the failure mechanism (observed by comparing Fig. 5c to 5d).
The circular failure mechanisms observed in the stability analysis of undisturbed cuttings with seepage were consistent with those of undisturbed cuttings without seepage. For cuttings excavated by uncontrolled blasting (represented with a PLM), seepage conditions responsible for a change in FoS caused non-circular failure mechanism at the toe of the cutting. When the phreatic surface reaches a certain height the failure mechanism daylights at the cutting surface close to the toe. The failure mechanism then changes from being a shallow failure that encompasses the entire cutting to a failure that remains shallow affecting only the lower part of the cutting, near the toe. The failure mechanism that extends beyond the cutting is most critical under dry conditions because it maximises the volume to failure surface area relationship for the sliding mass. However, the phreatic surface is closer to the ground surface at the toe of the cutting and as a result material strength is lower and the failure surface daylights on the cutting face rather than the upslope topography. This does not happen for all phreatic surface configurations, but only once the phreatic surface reaches the weakest layers within the PLM, because the gradient in rock strength imposed by blasting damage forces the failure surface to remain close to the ground surface.



4
Discussion
Here, we test the rigor of the Nepal guidelines against other published stability charts (see Section 4.1.1) and use case studies to test the usability of the guidelines relative to both existing guidelines and published stability charts (see Section 4.1.2). We then discuss the sensitivity of the Nepal and Ethiopia guidelines to input and model uncertainties (see Sections 4.2.1 and 4.2.2, respectively). We then go on to test the adaptability of these guidelines to interpolation (Section 4.3) and discuss whether the guidelines could be use globally (Section 4.4). Finally, the limitations of the guidelines are outlined (Section 4.5).

4.1
Comparison of the Nepal guidelines to other charts and guidelines

4.1.1
Rigor relative to other charts and guidelines
Here, we compare the rigor of the Nepal guidelines against other published stability charts (Li et al., 2008; Shen et al., 2013; Wyllie, 2017) by evaluating the same parameter sets and comparing the predictions. A high degree of consistency between predictions from different methods will give confidence in the rigor of the methods.

Li et al. (2008) use limit analysis to develop a series of stability charts using G-H-B criterion for undisturbed (i.e. D = 0) dry cuttings. The charts are organised by either cutting inclination or GSI, with each plotting m

i
 against the slope stability number (i.e. N = σ

ci
∕γHF, where σ

ci
 is the rock unconfined compressive strength), with contours indicating slope inclinations or GSI values. Shen et al. (2013) use LEM to develop a series of charts that satisfy G-H-B criterion for a dry cutting with β = 45
o
 (β: slope inclination). They present a set of charts organised by m

i
 and a so-called strength ratio: SR = σ

ci
∕γH. The charts organised by m

i
 plot SR against FoS, whilst the charts organised by SR plot m

i
 against FoS. Wyllie (2017) use LEM with a circular failure mechanism and the M-C failure criterion to develop a series of charts for cuttings with different levels of saturation, though we use only the dry charts here (Fig. 9.6, p. 247). These charts relate the FoS to γ, ϕ

'
, c

'
, H and β. Li et al. (2008); Shen et al. (2013); Wyllie (2017) are for cuttings with horizontal upslope topography, therefore we use our set of guidelines made for cuttings in horizontal topography. Li et al. (2008) and Wyllie (2017) charts do not account for disturbance, therefore, we considered an undisturbed cutting.
We tested our guidelines against stability charts from the literature for three slope scenarios (Table 15
). The parameter combination for these scenarios are outlined in Appendix B. Only Scenario 1 included results from Shen et al. (2013), since their charts are only applicable to cuttings of 45∘.
The outcomes of our guidelines were further corroborated by the Carranza-Torres and Hormazabal (2018) method (discussed in Section 4.2), with the predictions always within 1%.
These comparisons demonstrate that our guidelines predict cutting inclinations that are consistently very close to those of Wyllie and Mah (2004); Shen et al. (2013); Wyllie (2017); Carranza-Torres and Hormazabal (2018), but considerably different from those of Li et al. (2008). Shen et al. (2013) highlighted the differences between their stability numbers and those of Li et al. (2008), attributing this to a different definition of FoS purportedly employed by Li et al. (2008) in deriving their charts. However, we find this explanation unlikely because Wyllie (2017); Carranza-Torres and Hormazabal (2018) and our own study all use the same FoS definition as Li et al. (2008) but report different results. Whatever the reason for the discrepancy, the very close agreement of our results with Shen et al. (2013); Wyllie (2017); Carranza-Torres and Hormazabal (2018) provides a robust validation for our method and lead us to recommend not to use Li et al. (2008) stability charts as a design tool for cuttings.


4.1.2
Usability relative to other charts and guidelines
We tested the usability of our guidelines for Nepal by comparison with existing guidelines of the manual produced by the Nepali Department of Roads (Department of Roads, 2007) and stability charts of Li et al. (2008); Shen et al. (2013); Wyllie (2017) utilising case studies for the Nepal cases outlined in Section 3.2. Department of Roads (2007) presents several tables from different sources to recommend cutting inclinations for different scenarios.
Case one (C1) is 30 m high cutting in broken up siltstone with a desired FoS of 1.5 and inclined upslope topography of 30∘ (see Table 12 for details). Our guidelines prescribe a cutting inclination of 59∘ accounting for inclined topography (60∘ for flat topography). Using Table C3.6 (Annex C, p. 12) in Department of Roads (2007), for cuttings without structural control, C1 can be categorised as blocky with a rough surface, thus the prescribed inclination range is 40–45∘. They give no indication of the associated FoS. The GSI value for C1 (GSI = 15) lies at the midpoint between two of the Li et al. (2008) charts, therefore, we determined the inclination (calculating N) using both charts and took the average; a cutting inclination to achieve a FoS of 1.50 was 71∘. With Shen et al. (2013), we used the chart for m

i
 = 10 (Fig. 5b, p. 214) (m

i
 = 8 in C1). The values calculated for SR (SR = 52.1) was not within the axes of the chart, providing no guidance on the inclination. To use Wyllie (2017), we converted the G-H-B parameters to M-C using the method of Renani and Martin (2020), to approximate a slope inclination of 58∘ for FoS = 1.5.
Case two (C2) is 30 m high cutting in weathered claystone with a desired FoS of 1.3 and inclined upslope topography of 15∘ (see Table 13 for details). On guidelines for this case with horizontal topography prescribe a cutting inclination of 39∘. As with C1, Table C3.6 of Department of Roads (2007) is used, categorising C2 as blocky with a smooth surface to get a prescribed inclination range of 35–40∘. For Li et al. (2008) we used the chart for GSI = 10 (Fig. 10, p. 695). We calculated N = 16.0 to estimate that a 47∘ cutting inclination would achieve a FoS of 1.30. Fig. 5a (p. 214) from Shen et al. (2013), for m

i
 = 5 and a cutting inclination of 45∘ predicts a FoS of 1.10 (SR = 20.8). A cutting inclination of 38∘ was derived from the Wyllie (2017) chart.
Case three (C3) is 20 m high cutting opened by blasting in broken up phyllite with an horizontal upslope and a desired FoS of 1.5 (see Table 14 for details). For this case our guidelines predict a slope inclination of 40∘. However, none of the other charts account for upslope inclination or blasting. Our guidelines prescribe a horizontal unblasted inclination of 67∘. Table C3.6 of Department of Roads (2007) is used, categorising the rock as disturbed with smooth surfaces to get a prescribed inclination range of 35–40∘. As with C1, the GSI for C3 (GSI = 15) is at the midpoint between the Li et al. (2008) charts, so we wanted to take the average from two charts. However, the value calculated for N lies beyond the y-axis of the chart for GSI = 20. From the chart for GSI = 10 a cutting inclination of 70∘ will achieve a FoS of 1.50. We were not able to use the Shen et al. (2013) charts as the values calculated for SR was not within the axes of the most appropriate chart (m

i
 = 10). A cutting inclination of 66∘ was derived from the Wyllie (2017) chart.
The following comments can be made as a result of this exercise: (1) the cutting inclinations from Department of Roads (2007) for the three cases were similar, despite significant differences in rock characteristics and slope geometries; (2) the Department of Roads (2007) do not specify the FoS; (3) Li et al. (2008) can be used to approximate the cutting inclination but N must be calculated with precise G-H-B parameter values to use the charts; (4) since the Shen et al. (2013) charts are only for cutting inclinations of 45∘, they can only indicate whether a cutting should be inclined above or below this angle; (5) the Wyllie (2017) charts can only be used if the M-C parameter values are known; and (6) none of discussed charts/stability charts account for the influence of an inclined upslope section nor of the excavation induced disturbance to the slope. Based on the presented case studies, we suggest that our guidelines for Nepal improve on the usability of the discussed stability charts as no calculations or knowledge of exact parameter values are required to use our guidelines. In comparison to Department of Roads (2007) our guidelines are presented in a concise format, are transparent in the way that they were developed, and offer a choice on the resulting FoS. In addition, our guidelines take the disturbance caused by excavation into account which is not tackled in any of the charts/guidelines other than Shen et al. (2013).



4.2
Sensitivity to uncertainties

4.2.1
Input uncertainties
A key desirable property for the guidelines is the ability to quantify the error resulting from uncertainties. To this end we performed a parameter sensitivity analysis to assess the sensitivity of the Nepal and Ethiopia guidelines to user-defined inputs from field observations (practitioner's choices). This was done by determining the differences in the cutting inclinations of adjacent categories, and thereby estimating the error in cutting inclination that could result from an incorrect category choice.
We determined the differences in cutting inclinations between adjacent hardness groups (rows) in the tables, for given heights and GSI values (e.g. H = 20 m, GSI = L, difference in cutting inclinations from ‘Weak’ to ‘Moderate’). In comparing these differences in each table, the highest median difference is found between the two weakest hardness groups: in Tables 4, 5 and 10 between the ‘Very weak’ and ‘Weak’ categories (26∘, 63%; 13∘, 16%; and 13∘, 28%; respectively) and in Tables 3 and 11 (for blasted cuttings) between ‘Weak’ and ‘Moderate’ categories (24∘, 72%; 38∘, 92%; respectively). Across all the tables, the highest values of absolute difference were in the Ethiopia guidelines for blasted cuttings (Table 11), with 57∘ being the largest difference. A general observation across all tables is the lower the GSI the higher the differences in cutting inclinations between hardness groups.
To reduce the uncertainty between hardness groups, extra groups could be included in the guidelines, particularly between the weaker groups where uncertainties are greater. However, more groups would also make the tables harder to read and use. The groups here employed are already well established in the literature (Brown, 1981; Marinos and Hoek, 2000) whereas greater granularity would require the use of unfamiliar extra categories with increased judgement required by practitioners to determine the appropriate group.
The same sensitivity exercise was carried out to assess the differences in cutting inclinations between adjacent GSI categories, for given cutting heights and hardness categories. Across all the tables, in the majority of cases, there was a larger difference of cutting inclinations between the GSI categories of L and I relative to that between I and H. For example, in Table 2, the midpoint of absolute differences between L and I was 13∘ (17%), and that between I and H was 0∘ (0%). The maximum absolute difference between GSI categories in Table 2 was 62∘ (221%), between L and I for ‘Very weak’ rocks in a 5 m cutting. In the majority of tables (Tables 2, 3, 5, 11), generally the weaker the rock, the greater the difference in cutting inclinations between GSI values.
In comparing the differences in GSI categories between the Nepal and Ethiopia guidelines for mechanically excavated cuttings, there is slightly less variability in cutting inclinations between GSI values within the ‘Very weak’ rock group for Ethiopia (Table 10) than Nepal (Table 2), with median differences of 12∘ and 19∘ respectively. This reflects the different types of material within the ‘Very weak’ group in the two countries: primarily tuffs characterised using G-H-B criterion for Ethiopia; and residual soils characterised using the M-C criterion for Nepal. The parameter values are thus more tightly constrained in the Ethiopian case.
In defining the values for the GSI categories we used the maximum and minimum value of all the rocks in one group. The uncertainty between GSI categories could be reduced by defining the high value as the mean of the maximum GSI values for all the rocks in one group, and the low value as the mean of the minimum GSI values for all the rocks in one group.
In cases where the design cutting inclinations are particularly sensitive to practitioner parameter choices, geotechnical investigation and numerical analysis are highly recommended. For geotechnical engineers who do not have access to an appropriate numerical analysis software, we suggest using a simpler computational tool to conduct the slope stability analysis. For example, the slope stability analyses tool of Carranza-Torres and Hormazabal (2018), which can be implemented in any spreadsheet software, could be used with the M-C to G-H-B parameter conversion method of Renani and Martin (2020). Unfortunately, this tool cannot be used for the cutting cases with disturbance or for any additional complexities (e.g. seepage). More detail is given on this method in Appendix A.2.


4.2.2
Model uncertainties
The stability analyses were performed using rigorous M-P LEM. Nevertheless uncertainties are introduced by the very fact of employing a numerical method. These uncertainties are difficult to quantify, but are certainly small in relative terms.
The methodology used here can be followed to develop guidelines for any location in the world with the caveat that the geotechnical characteristics for geomaterials in the location are known. If these characteristics are not available, they need to be inferred from a similar material type. This is likely to add model uncertainty that is difficult to measure as the difference between the true and inferred parameter values would be unknown.
Overall, we believe that the results (slope inclinations) are more sensitive to input uncertainty than the model uncertainty. However, input uncertainties are less likely than model uncertainties. The greatest potential input uncertainty lies within the weaker categories and to a lesser degree between the lower GSI classes of the tables.



4.3
Interpolation between table entries
Stability analyses conducted for cutting heights at class boundaries (e.g. 7.5 m, between 5 and 10 m) suggest that cutting inclinations can be linearly interpolated between cutting height classes (eight cases were tested in different hardness and GSI categories). For example, for a 15 m high cutting in ‘Weak’ rock with GSI=I using Table 2, the average of the inclinations prescribed for 10 and 20 m cuttings, (i.e. (87∘ + 69∘)/2 = 78∘) will provide the most accurate estimate of cutting inclination. In this case, the stability analysis for the cutting inclined at 78∘ for a height of 15 m returns a FoS of 1.37 (a 5% error in FoS). By conducting an individual stability analysis for this case (H = 15 m), it was found that an inclination of 75∘ would achieve a FoS of 1.30.
We performed stability analyses to examine errors introduced when a GSI value lies on a class boundary and a user must choose one of the adjacent cutting inclinations. These cases resulted in FoS errors of 20–40%. Instead, linear interpolation of cutting inclinations across GSI results in FoS errors of 1–30%; and always reduces error relative to the use of an adjacent class. This suggests that interpolating between GSI values consistently improves the cutting inclination guidance where GSI lies between the categories.
Unfortunately it is not possible to linearly interpolate cutting inclinations between hardness categories since they incorporate multiple parameters (UCS, γ and m

i
) and these are not linearly spaced between categories nor are they guaranteed to follow the same functional form.


4.4
Global guidelines
In comparing the Nepali and Ethiopian guidelines the uncertainty between the tables is relatively small compared to the uncertainties within a table. This raises the question of whether a single global table would be more beneficial. With a universal table, less work would have to be carried out and the guidelines become more widely applicable. However, we have only compared two locations here, and there are many rock types that are not included in these two tables. Wider geographic applicability necessitates inclusion of a wider range of geomaterials, and associated parameter values and thus larger uncertainties.


4.5
Limitations of the guidelines
Our guidelines are not suitable for cuttings that are made up of layers of different rock types as the cutting material modelled was homogeneous except for the PLM. Where material strength varies with elevation, cuttings may need to accommodate multiple profiles at different inclinations.
As discussed in Section 2.1 there is general consensus that D should decrease with depth into the slope. Following the recommendation of Hoek (2012), we incorporated D into our slope models using a PLM. However, a disadvantage of the PLM approach, is that it creates a stepwise strength profile that tends to bound failure at the boundary between planes (as discussed in Section 3.4). In addition, the majority of literature surrounding D is on open-pit mining or tunneling (Hoek et al., 2002; Hoek and Brown, 2019) and, therefore, the size of the PLM zone used in this study is an assumption based on the small amount of literature available for the size of the D zone in road cuttings (Matheson, 1995; Yang et al., 2020).
The guidelines here produced are not suitable to design cuttings in the presence of dominant structural orientations and/or significant anisotropy of the rock mass shear strength. To introduce structural dominance to the guidelines would add unwanted complexity in their development and use. To assess the stability of cuttings controlled by distinct discontinuities, stereographical projections can be used to map the failure kinematics whilst the Discrete Element Method can be used to assess slope stability (e.g. Boon et al. (2014)). Hearn (2011) also outline the conditions which need to be satisfied for discontinuities to cause planar failure in rock slopes.
Another key limitation of our methodology is due to the stability analyses being performed for dry slopes. Most slopes and cuttings will experience some seepage due to periods of rainfall, especially in locations that host monsoon seasons. However, we chose this assumption due to the fact that the position of the phreatic line in a slope is hard to postulate given variable rainfall rate and the large scatter of values exhibited by hydrological parameters. To deal with this limitation, rather than introducing unrealistic seepage conditions, as unfortunately is the case with many stability charts in the literature, we conducted seepage analyses to identify the range of slope saturation conditions for which our guidelines are applicable. We acknowledge there are slope saturation scenarios that the guidelines are less reliable in dealing with.



5
Conclusions
This paper provided two key contributions: (1) a new methodology that can be used to develop user-friendly and rigorous guidelines for road cuttings in LIC/LMIC and (2) a set of guidelines for road cuttings in Nepal. The Nepal guidelines are more robust than guidelines currently provided in manuals and they are in close agreement with published stability charts. This methodology offers transparency, meaning that they can be easily adapted and that the level of uncertainty can be tuned to fit the users needs. We showed that our guidelines provide a user-friendly tool for practitioners tasked with the design of cuttings and the assessment of their stability.
In the process of developing the guidelines and through our analysis of the resulting tables, we have found that the greatest care needs to be taken in designing cuttings in weak material as they are most sensitive to the choices that a practitioner makes, having the largest input uncertainties. In addition, the weaker categories in our guidelines are more sensitive to seepage. We found that inclined upslope topography has only a minor impact on cutting stability. Further stability analyses demonstrated that interpolation improves predictions for cutting heights and GSI values that sit between classes, but cannot be used between hardness categories. In addition, the uncertainty between the same entries in tables for different locations (Nepal and Ethiopia) was relatively small compared to that between adjacent entries in the table for a single location. This introduces the possibility of a single set of globally applicable guidelines, though the reliability and usability of such guidelines remains an open research question.
We suggest that practitioners could use our guidelines to quickly and efficiently determine a suitable cutting inclination based on some key observations (rock state and hardness, and excavation type) and desired cutting characteristics (cutting height and Factor of Safety). These guidelines should be used as a first step in the design of cuttings and help assessing the stability of existing cuttings. We believe they can produce a step change in the safety of road construction in LIC/LMIC.
Text.45:
1
Introduction
Rainfall-induced landslides pose a serious threat to lives and properties around the world. The mountainous country Nepal experiences widespread landslides every year triggered by the concentrated monsoonal rainfall between June and September (Dahal and Hasegawa, 2008; Petley et al., 2007; Upreti and Dhital, 1996). The monsoonal rainfall constitutes ~80% of the total annual rainfall and studies show that >90% of the fatal landslides in Nepal occur during this period (Froude and Petley, 2018; NDRRMA, 2021; Petley et al., 2007). In the last decade, landslides caused the loss of over 1200 lives and economic damage of more than $14 million in Nepal (NDRRMA, 2021).
The proliferation of informal local roads in Nepal has further increased the risk of rainfall-induced landsliding (Dahal et al., 2010; Devkota et al., 2014; Froude and Petley, 2018; Mcadoo et al., 2018; Petley et al., 2007; Vuillez et al., 2018), and this has been attributed to the non-engineered or informal method of slope excavation for road construction, often crossing terrain with steep angles, without suitable planning, design and drainage and protection measures (Dixit et al., 2021; Hearn and Shakya, 2017; Robson et al., 2021; UNDP, 2011; World Bank, 2012). The study by Mcadoo et al. (2018) found that the rainfall-triggered landslides could occur with approximately twice the frequency in areas with poorly constructed roads than in those without, based on the spatial distribution analysis of landslides and roads in Sindhupalchok district, Nepal. Vuillez et al. (2018) also found that within the Phewa watershed in western Nepal, the occurrence of landslides during extreme rainfall events was more prominent in areas intersected by or in close vicinity of the roads.
Although the association between rainfall, road construction and landslides in Nepal has been recognised anecdotally (Dahal et al., 2010; Rosser et al., 2021) and broadly correlated statistically by previous studies (Petley et al., 2007), there is limited understanding related to the physical process by which road cuts influence slope stability during rainfall. The necessity to model this physical process to better understand the combined road-rainfall effect on landsliding has also been emphasised by Mcadoo et al. (2018). Moreover, the need to address landslides related to roads and rainfall extends beyond Nepal to other low- and middle-income countries, where the construction of non-engineered steep slopes as part of road building is common and is known to be a dominant driver of instability (Haigh and Rawat, 2012; Holcombe et al., 2016; Sati et al., 2011; Sidle et al., 2014; UNDP, 2011; Sidle and Ziegler, 2012).
Assessing the physical process of the rainfall-triggered landslides requires understanding how the transient atmospheric process like rainfall influences the unsaturated soil behaviour near the ground surface (Fredlund and Rahardjo, 1993). Rainfall infiltration into the unsaturated zone is known to cause an increase in the soil water content, and reductions in soil suction and shear strength (Brand, 1981; Fredlund, 1987; Godt et al., 2009; Lumb, 1975; Rahardjo et al., 2019; Springman et al., 2003; Tsaparas et al., 2002). The infiltration-induced pore water pressure changes modify the soil stresses, which causes soil deformation, and soil deformation, in turn, modifies the seepage process because the key hydraulic properties like permeability, porosity, and water retention capacity of soil change with the changes in stresses (Song and Borja, 2014; Zhang et al., 2018). Hence, the analysis of the physical process of rainfall-triggered landslides requires powerful numerical modelling methods that can model not only the transient atmospheric conditions but also the interdependence between seepage and stress-deformation in unsaturated soils.
The coupled hydro-mechanical analysis effectively captures this interdependence by allowing simultaneous computation of both hydraulic and mechanical responses of variably saturated soils, which is necessary for the accurate assessment of rainfall-induced landslides (Chen et al., 2018; Hamdhan and Schweiger, 2013; Laloui et al., 2016; Md Rahim and Toll, 2014; Qi and Vanapalli, 2015; Yang et al., 2017, 2019; Yubonchit et al., 2017). Compared to the uncoupled analyses, where the hydraulic and mechanical aspects of soil behaviour are treated separately, the coupled hydro-mechanical analyses have been reported to provide a better prediction of factor of safety and the pore water pressure predictions from coupled analyses have been found to be in good agreement with field-measured pore water pressures (Hamdhan and Schweiger, 2013; Toll et al., 2019). Studies have also shown that the coupled analyses can closely predict actual failure times, in addition to providing a better prediction of seepage and stress distribution (Rahim, 2016; Oh and Lu, 2015; Yang et al., 2017, 2020, 2019).
Thus, addressing the need to understand the physical process of landslides triggered by the combined effect of rainfall and road cut in Nepal, and considering the advantages of the coupled hydro-mechanical analyses, this study utilises the hydro-mechanical approach to investigate a case study of a rainfall-induced landslide on a road cut slope in Sindhupalchok district, Nepal. Using this case study, this paper aims to 1) back-analyse the landslide to understand the underlying mechanism and physical processes involved in the failure and 2) quantitatively assess the effect of the road cut on the occurrence of the landslide during rainfall. Through a series of numerical analyses, this study also attempts to demonstrate the viability of coupled hydro-mechanical analyses to capture the hydrological changes in unsaturated soils due to soil-atmospheric interaction and to predict the occurrence of slope failures. As hydro-mechanical modelling requires a good understanding of the relevant physical, mechanical, and hydraulic soil parameters, comprehensive field and laboratory testing of the soils were conducted during this study. The field and laboratory data were used to define the input material properties for numerical modelling. A field hydrological monitoring program was also undertaken at the study site after the landslide, and the monitored data was utilised to calibrate the numerical model.


2
Study area
The investigated landslide is located in Kanglang village in the Upper Bhote Koshi valley of Sindhupalchok district, Province 3, Nepal (hereafter referred to as the Kanglang landslide) (Fig. 1a). During the widening of the local road from Daklang to Listi (Fig. 1b), the slope was informally excavated to a steep ~70° cut in December 2017 (Fig. 1c). It is common for slopes to be excavated at steep angles during the construction of local roads to minimise earthwork volumes and associated costs (Hearn, 2011). During the following monsoon in July 2018, a translational slide (Varnes, 1958) occurred, affecting a larger area above the road cut (Fig. 1d). With ~1.5 m depth of the sliding surface, the landslide can be categorised as a shallow translational slide. The length and width of the landslide are approximately 25 m (upslope), and 45 m (along slope) respectively. The sliding soil body generally follows Northeast direction, extending from an elevation of 1440 m (toe) m to 1460 m (crown) above sea level (a.s.l.). The elevations were recorded using a hand-held GPS (Garmin 60CSx) which provides an approximate estimation of the elevation with an accuracy of <10 m. Although the exact timing of the landslide is not known, the landowner noted that the landslide occurred before 16 July 2018.
The study area receives an average of 3599 mm of rainfall annually, the second-highest rainfall in Nepal (Karki et al., 2016), based on the 64-year rainfall record (1955–2018) obtained from the nearest weather station in Gumthang, located ~6.3 km from the study site (DHM, 2018). The topography of the region is rugged with steep slopes, narrow gorges and high relief with altitudes ranging from 760 to 4100 m (Tanoli et al., 2017). Geologically, the Kanglang landslide is underlain by a thick colluvial deposit with a mix of gravel-, cobble-, and boulder-sized materials, and is situated near the mid-section of a hillslope which could be an ancient landslide deposit (Fig. 1b). Such deposits encountered on the mountain slopes are formed by progressive downslope transport of materials from gravity-driven mass movement or hill wash processes (Hearn, 2011). The study site is approximately 7.4 km south of the Main Central Thrust (MCT) and the region south of MCT is dominated by sedimentary and metasedimentary rocks including shale, sandstone, limestone, dolomite, slate, phyllite, schist, and quartzite (Upreti, 2001). The majority of the Daklang-Listi road, including the Kanglang landslide, traverses through the Lakharpata formation (DMG, 1994), which includes Malekhu Limestone, Benighat Slate, and Dhading Dolomites of the Upper Nuwakot unit (Stöcklin, 1980; Upreti, 1996). During the 2015 Gorkha earthquake, Nepal, Sindhupalchok district was severely affected by a large number of co-seismic landslides (Kincey et al., 2021; Roback et al., 2018). The consequent post-earthquake landslide activities in this region have been reported to have remained active and evolving by recent studies (Kincey et al., 2021; Tian et al., 2020). Due to the combination of heavy rainfall, rugged topography, proximity to the tectonic fault, post-earthquake landslide activity, as well as ongoing anthropogenic activities like road-building (Mcadoo et al., 2018; Rosser et al., 2021), the study area is susceptible to both natural and anthropogenic landslides.


3
Methodology
There are three key steps in the adopted methodology. First is the detailed geotechnical field investigation, where borehole drilling, standard penetration tests (SPTs), and trial pit excavation were conducted near the landslide crown to investigate and reconstruct the subsoil condition of the slope before the landslide. Soil samples were obtained from the borehole and trial pit for geotechnical characterisation and estimation of their mechanical (shear strength parameters) and hydraulic soil properties (SWRCs and saturated permeability). A detailed description of the methods and results of the field and laboratory testing are presented in section 5. Second is the field monitoring program conducted to assess the in-situ hydrologic changes in the soil using real-time measurements of rainfall and volumetric water content of the soil (section 6). Finally, in the third step, using the estimated soil parameters, the failed slope was reconstructed and a series of hydro-mechanical analyses (or fully coupled flow-deformation analysis) was performed in the finite element code PLAXIS 2D (Bentley Systems Inc., 2018), as illustrated in Fig. 2
.
The first part of the numerical analysis- model calibration, constituted a hydro-mechanical analysis, where the monitored rainfall in July 2019 was imposed as a hydraulic boundary at the ground surface (Fig. 2). The predicted volumetric water content responses were compared to the in-situ volumetric water content measurements to calibrate the numerical model. Since the hydrological conditions of the slope are not known when the landslide occurred, model calibration is the crucial first step necessary to make reliable predictions of the slope behaviour under different rainfall scenarios. As shown in Fig. 2, the calibrated model was adopted for the subsequent analyses to 1) evaluate the stability of the slope from the time when the road cut was excavated in December 2017 to June 2018, before the Kanglang landslide to check if the slope is predicted to remain stable before the main landsliding event in July 2018 (stability analysis before the Kanglang landslide), 2) back-analyse and predict the failure timing and mechanism of the Kanglang landslide (back-analysis of Kanglang landslide), and 3) investigate the influence of the road cut by replicating the back-analysis on an idealised slope model without the road cut, which was subjected to the same rainfall conditions that triggered the Kanglang landslide (slope stability analysis without road cut). The numerical analyses from (1) to (3) were conducted by combining the hydro-mechanical analysis with the safety analysis to estimate the factor of safety (FOS) at different time steps (Fig. 2).


4
Theoretical background

4.1
Coupled hydro-mechanical analysis
PLAXIS 2D was adopted in this study given its proven ability to assess the hydro-mechanical behaviour of slopes under transient hydraulic boundary conditions (Hamdhan and Schweiger, 2013). The formulation of the coupled hydro-mechanical analysis in PLAXIS is based on Biot's 3-dimensional consolidation theory (Biot, 1941), which combines the equilibrium equation and the continuity equation of the soil-water matrix (Galavi, 2010; Galavi et al., 2009). This allows computation of both deformation and groundwater seepage simultaneously under steady and transient flow boundaries in both saturated and unsaturated soil conditions (Galavi, 2010; Galavi et al., 2009). In the coupled formulation in PLAXIS, the mechanical behaviour of unsaturated soil is modelled using Bishop's effective stress concept, where the net stress and suction components are combined into single effective stress, as shown in Eq. (1) (Bishop, 1959). Under this concept, the suction coefficient χ is related to the degree of saturation and can be considered as a scaling parameter determining the contribution of matric suction to the shear strength of the unsaturated soil. In PLAXIS, χ is considered equivalent to the effective degree of saturation, and the pore air pressure is assumed to be negligible (Eq. (2)).

It is recognised that studies have questioned the suitability of Bishop's effective stress concept, particularly the consideration of the suction coefficient (χ) being a function of the degree of saturation (Fredlund et al., 1978; Jennings and Burland, 1962; Khalili and Khabbaz, 1998). However, the use of Bishop's effective stress for modelling unsaturated soil behaviour allows an easier transition between unsaturated and saturated states and studies have provided evidence of its validity, which includes one of the earliest experimental studies by Bishop and Blight (1963) on clayey soils. Toll (2020) also showed that Bishop's effective stress concept is valid for clayey soils when the degree of saturation is ≥75%. For non-clayey soils, Öberg and Sällfors (1997) found that the χ-parameter can be replaced by the degree of saturation when it is greater than ~50%. In agreement with this study, Alonso et al. (2010) and Casini et al. (2011) found that the unsaturated soil behaviour, particularly for granular soils like sands and silts, can be expressed using a single Bishop's effective stress. Hence, whilst the Bishop's effective stress concept may not be valid for all soil types, at all ranges of saturation (Toll et al., 2019), it is reasonable to assume that for non-clayey soils, this concept can provide a realistic prediction of the unsaturated soil behaviour, particularly when the degree of saturation is high and the air phase is discontinuous, as would be the case in the modelling of rainfall-induced landslides.
As for the hydraulic behaviour of unsaturated soil in PLAXIS, the van Genuchten model (van Genuchten, 1980) was used. Based on this model, the relationship between matric suction and volumetric water content of the soil is expressed as Eq. (4) and the permeability function can be expressed as Eq. (5).

4.2
Safety analysis
The safety analysis in PLAXIS uses the strength-reduction method to determine the factor of safety (Brinkgreve et al., 2018). Assuming a Mohr-Coulomb failure criterion, this method entails an incremental reduction of the shear strength parameters (cohesion and angle of shearing resistance) by a strength reduction factor until the slope reaches a failure state (Cai and Ugai, 2004; Griffiths and Lane, 1999; Matsui and San, 1992). The factor of safety is defined as the ratio of the shear strength parameters of soil to those at failure as shown in Eq. (6)
