5
Detailed investigation of subsoil condition and soil properties

5.1
Subsoil condition
To assess the subsoil condition, a borehole was drilled using rotary drilling next to the landslide crown (Fig. 1e). During drilling, boulder- and cobble-size materials were encountered at 5.8 and 6.3 m depths, typical for colluvial soils. SPTs were conducted in the borehole in accordance with BS EN ISO22476-3 (BSI, 2005) at 1 m intervals to a maximum depth of 7 m. At 7 m, the SPT sampler was replaced by a solid 60° cone (SPT (cone)) to prevent damage to the sampler by the coarser materials, as recommended in BS 5930: 2015 (BSI, 2015). The number of blows required for 300 mm penetration with the cone was converted to the corresponding SPT N-value using the correlation proposed by Mohan et al. (1970). The SPTs revealed a uniform deposit of medium dense soil from 0 to 7 m with corrected SPT values ((N1)60) ranging from 11 to 19 (with a mean of 14) (Fig. 3
). The soil samples extracted from the upper 2, 4 and 5 m exhibited reddish-brown colour and sandy to silty texture, and below 6 m, the soil was brownish grey with a sandy texture. Based on the correlation with SPT proposed by Hatanaka and Uchida (1996), the angle of shearing resistance of the soil was estimated to range from 35° to 40° (37° on average) and the elastic modulus of soil was estimated to be between 6 and 8 MPa, based on the empirical correlation given by Bowles (1997).
To obtain disturbed and undisturbed samples, a trial pit (1.5 m × 1.0 m) was excavated to 1.5 m depth as per BS ISO 18400-102:2017 (BSI, 2017) (Fig. 1e). The materials excavated from the trial pit were predominantly fine-grained and indicated the presence of silty and sandy soils. Within the trial pit, the upper 0.25 m layer exhibited a slightly different greyish-brown colour, as shown in Fig. 4
 which could be due to weathering and presence of organic matter. Below this layer, the soil was described as slightly wet, reddish-brown sandy to silty soil. From the trial pit, disturbed bag samples were collected, and core samples were obtained using open-ended steel sampling tubes (ϕ 37 mm), which were driven into the bottom of the trial pit at 0.5, 1, and 1.5 m depths. After extracting the cores, the open ends were sealed with paraffin wax and wrapped in cling film to minimise moisture loss during transport. With permission from the Department of Mines and Geology, Kathmandu, Nepal, all the samples were exported to Durham University, UK for testing.


5.2
Soil properties

Table 1
 presents a summary of the in-situ physical properties of the core samples obtained from the trial pit. The particle size distributions were obtained using the commercial laser diffraction particle size analyser (LS 13320) with a measurement range from 0.04 μm to 2 mm. The soil samples contained ≤12% clay-sized particles, while silt- and sand-sized particles dominated the distribution (SILT to Sandy SILT as per BS 5930:2015 (BSI, 2015)). The samples obtained from the borehole also contained low clay contents ≤8% and higher percentages of silt-sized particles (43 to 70%). The Atterberg limits were determined as per BS EN ISO 17892-12:2018 (BSI, 2018a), where the finer fraction (<0.425 mm) of the soil samples from shallow depths (<1 m) exhibited intermediate plasticity with the plasticity index from 14 to 17% and liquid limit from 37 to 40%. The lower plasticity index and smaller clay fraction suggest a lower potential for swelling and shrinkage due to changes in water contents. Further, the sample near the ground surface was found to be relatively loose with a higher void ratio that decreased with increasing depth. The degree of saturation increased with depth, confirming the observation of a wetter soil layer below 0.5 m within the trial pit (Fig. 4).
A series of consolidated undrained (CU) triaxial compression tests were performed according to BS EN ISO 17892-9:2018 (BSI, 2018b) to estimate the shear strength parameters of the soil. The tests were performed on reconstituted soil samples obtained from 0.5 to 0.75 m depth. The samples were compacted in the laboratory to a dry density of 1.34 Mg/m3 corresponding to the in-situ dry density of the undisturbed soil sample obtained from 0.5 m depth (Table 1). Based on the results shown in terms of the stress path plotted in the two-dimensional p’ (mean effective stress) and q (deviator stress) space (Fig. 5
), the critical angle of shearing resistance was estimated to be 36° (slope of the critical state line M = 1.47), which is much lower than the road cut slope angle at the investigated site (~70°). The estimated angle of shearing resistance is comparable to the empirical estimation of 35° to 40° corresponding to the SPT (N1)60 values, as per Hatanaka and Uchida (1996). There is some evidence of a cohesive component of strength from the tests carried out at confining stresses of 25 and 75 kPa, and the strength envelope shown in Fig. 5 represents a lower bound strength envelope.
The saturated coefficient of permeability was determined using the standard triaxial constant head permeability test as per BS EN ISO 17892-11:2019 (BSI, 2019). The test was performed by consolidating the saturated sample at 100, 200 and 300 kPa and measuring the flow through the sample at each consolidation pressure. A constant water pressure difference of 20 kPa was maintained to allow flow from the top to the bottom of the sample. At increasing levels of the effective consolidation pressure, the saturated permeability of the soil sample was found to range from 1.17 × 10−7 and 1.43 × 10−8 m/s, typical for silts and silty sands (Lu and Likos, 2004).
The soil-water retention curves (SWRCs) were obtained using discrete or staged drying and wetting methods as described by Lourenço et al. (2007). The soil suction was measured using the high capacity tensiometer developed at Durham University, known for its fast response rate and high suction measurements up to 2 MPa (Lourenço et al., 2006; Toll et al., 2013). Direct measurement of suction using tensiometers avoids the calibration errors that may be inevitable in other indirect suction measurement methods (Lourenço et al., 2006; Toll et al., 2013). During the test, the samples were dried and wetted in stages and were left to equalise for at least 24 h in an insulated setting before measuring suction. After equalisation, suction was measured, and volumetric measurements of the samples were made using a digital calliper with ±0.01 mm accuracy. This process was repeated to define both the drying and wetting SWRCs. The wetting SWRC was obtained by air-drying the sample to <1.5% water content before wetting back up to define the primary wetting curve. The wetting-scanning curve was obtained by wetting the sample from the end of the drying phase at a volumetric water content of ~20%. Fig. 6a and b illustrate the SWRCs of the tested samples fitted to the van Genuchten model (VG model) (van Genuchten, 1980) (Eq. (4)). The resulting curves exhibited hysteretic behaviour during drying and wetting where the wetting-scanning curve obtained by wetting the sample after the end of the drying stage reaches the primary wetting curve. The curve fitting parameters for the van Genuchten model are also shown in Fig. 6a and b.



6
Field monitoring program
During this study, a field monitoring station was established ∼10 m west of the landslide crown as shown in Fig. 1e. Three 10HS soil moisture sensors (S-SMx-M005) (ONSET, 2018) were installed horizontally at depths of 0.3, 0.8, and 1.2 m on the undisturbed vertical wall of the trial pit to measure the changes in volumetric water content of the soil. The first sensor was installed at 0.3 m to capture the immediate volumetric water content responses while avoiding the upper layers where the plant roots could create preferential flow paths. Below this depth, the sensors were installed at vertical spacings of 0.4 to 0.5 m. The monitoring station was equipped with a rain gauge (HOBO® S-RGB-M002) (ONSET, 2018) and a data logger and telemetry system (HOBO RX3000) (ONSET, 2019) was installed to record and remotely retrieve the rainfall and volumetric water content measurements. A detailed description of the monitoring station setup is presented by Pradhan et al. (2020).


7
Numerical model set-up

7.1
Geometry

Fig. 7a shows the simplified 2-dimensional plane strain model of the investigated slope before the Kanglang landslide. The finite element mesh consisted of 3399 15-noded triangular elements and 27,515 nodes. A finer mesh was defined closer to the ground surface as higher deformation is expected in this part of the model. Additionally, the finer mesh near the ground surface was crucial to obtain a refined prediction of the volumetric water content changes during model calibration, given the vertical spacing between the 10HS sensors in the field was relatively small (0.4 to 0.5 m). At greater depths, the mesh size was increased to reduce computational time. Similarly, for the slope stability analysis without the road cut, a 2-dimensional plane strain model representing an idealised undisturbed hillslope was created with a finite element mesh consisting of 3623 triangular elements and 29,303 nodes (Fig. 7b). The specification of the mesh was kept identical to that in Fig. 7a so that the resulting factor of safety was comparable between the two models.


7.2
Material parameters

Table 2
 presents the summary of the input soil parameters adopted in the numerical analyses. The four soil layers defined in Table 2, also shown in Fig. 7a and b were differentiated based on their hydraulic soil properties. The rationale for this layering was to capture the different hydrologic responses of the soils observed at the three measured depths of 0.3, 0.8, and 1.2 m during field monitoring, which are related mainly to the differences in their hydraulic properties (Fig. 8a, b and c). As the permeability tests in the laboratory were conducted at higher effective confining pressures (section 5.2), the saturated permeabilities of soil layers at shallow depths were estimated by extrapolating the measured relationship between saturated permeability and effective confining pressures. Further, weathering and plant roots create non-capillary macropores and surficial cracks near the ground surface, which results in a higher in-situ permeability than that measured in the laboratory (Collison et al., 1995; Dixon et al., 2019). To incorporate such effects within the numerical models, Toll et al. (2019) and Gasmo et al. (2000) introduced a surficial soil layer with a higher vertical permeability than the laboratory-measured value. Rouainia et al. (2009) also found a good agreement between model predictions and field-measured pore water pressures when the measured soil permeability was increased by one to two orders of magnitude. In this study, to consider the macroscopic effects near the ground, two times higher permeability than the estimated value was assigned to the top layer from 0 to 0.5 m, which provided a good agreement between predicted and measured volumetric water content responses, which is discussed further in section 8.1.
With regards to the SWRCs, it is debated in the literature whether the wetting or drying SWRC should be implemented for rainfall-induced slope stability analyses when hydraulic hysteresis cannot be taken into account. Considering infiltration corresponds closely to soil wetting, it is rational to adopt the wetting SWRC, which has also been suggested by Kristo et al. (2019) and Kim et al. (2018). Li et al. (2005) also found a closer match between field-measured SWRC and the wetting SWRC obtained from testing. Hence, as hydraulic hysteresis cannot be modelled in PLAXIS, in all the numerical analyses presented in this study, the wetting SWRC parameters were adopted to model the hydraulic soil behaviour in both the drying and wetting phases. An exception to this is the stability analysis before the Kanglang landslide (Fig. 2), which included a prolonged dry period from 1 December 2017 to 28 February 2018, with only a few days of non-zero rainfall (Fig. 9a). For this period, the drying SWRC was used to model the hydraulic behaviour and after the end of this dry period, from 1 March to 30 June 2018, the wetting SWRC parameters were assigned to the soil layers to model infiltration. The drying and wetting SWRCs for layers 1 and 2 shown in Table 2 were measured in the laboratory (Fig. 6a and b). The value of g

a
 for the lower layers (layers 3 and 4) was adjusted to match the initial volumetric water content in the model to that measured in the field at 1.2 m. As the air-entry value tends to increase with the increase in normal stress and decrease in the void ratio (Miller et al., 2008), a lower value of g

a
 than the upper layers can be considered to be a reasonable assumption.
The conventional Mohr-Coulomb model was used to represent the constitutive relationship of all soil layers defined in Table 2. Since a uniform subsoil profile was revealed by the SPT results (Fig. 3) and a similarly uniform subsoil was exposed inside the trial pit with only a noticeable change in colour due to weathering and wetness (Fig. 4), the shear strength properties estimated from the laboratory (Fig. 5) were considered to be uniform. Since the samples did not exhibit a distinctive peak but showed a contractive behaviour indicated by the increase in pore water pressures under undrained conditions, which is typical for loose or normally consolidated soils (OCR ~1) (Fig. 5), the angle of shearing resistance at the critical state was adopted for modelling. As the silt-sized particles dominate the particle size distribution of the soils at shallow depths (Table 1), a residual state created due to clay particles aligning within the shear zone would not be expected (Skempton, 1985). Although at the critical state, the effective cohesion is negligible, a small value of cohesion (3 kPa) was assigned to prevent numerical instabilities mainly near the ground surface where the effective stresses are lower. A smaller value of cohesion predicted localised failure near the steep face of the cut slope, which essentially was modelling surface ravelling, and this prevented the analysis of a deeper failure from proceeding further. A small cohesion of 3 kPa could be justified by the evidence of a cohesive element of strength indicated by the triaxial tests at lower stress levels, which would be relevant for shallow slope failures.


7.3
Boundary conditions
On both slope models shown in Fig. 7a and b, standard fixities were applied, which allowed vertical movement of the two lateral boundaries, free movement of the upper boundary and restrained movement of the bottom boundary. The hydraulic boundaries at the two lateral sides of the model were set to be closed and the bottom boundary was assigned as an open boundary. On the upper model boundaries, a downward positive flux was prescribed to model infiltration, the input values of which are the actual rainfall amounts specified in the unit of length per unit of time. Similarly, to simulate evapotranspiration during the periods with zero rainfall, on the upper model boundaries, an upward negative flux of 0.167 × 10−3 m/h or 4 mm/day was applied based on the study by Lambert and Chitrakar (1989).
For the model calibration, hourly rainfall from 1 July to 11 July 2019 recorded at the monitoring station was applied as positive influx. For the analysis of slope stability before the Kanglang landslide failure, due to lack of access to continuous hourly records, daily rainfall from 1 December 2017 to 30 June 2018 measured at the four nearest rainfall stations located between ~6 and 27 km from the study site was obtained from the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology, Nepal (DHM, 2018). Based on these distances, a weighted mean daily rainfall was estimated and prescribed as influx. The back-analysis of the Kanglang landslide and the stability analysis without the road cut were conducted under the July 2018 hourly rainfall recorded at Bahrabise located approximately 11 km south of the study site.
The infiltration amount varies with time and depends on the infiltration capacity of the soil, which is governed largely by the permeability function shown in Eq. (5) (Galavi, 2010). In PLAXIS, if the rainfall intensity is greater than this capacity, ponding occurs at the surface at a prescribed depth of ψ

max
, which is the water head above the ground surface. If this is exceeded, runoff is simulated. For simplicity, it was assumed that ponding does not occur on sloping ground; hence a small value of maximum pore water pressure head (ψ

max
) of 0.1 mm was assigned on the upper surface boundaries. To prevent unrealistic suction development due to evapotranspiration, a minimum pressure head (ψ

min
) of −30 m was prescribed at the upper surface boundaries. This value corresponds to the minimum volumetric water content of 0.23 m3/m3 recorded at 0.3 m depth during a year-long monitoring period from 27 March 2019 to 28 March 2020.


7.4
Initial conditions
The initial stresses were generated using the gravity loading function in PLAXIS, which is recommended for sloping ground (Brinkgreve et al., 2018). With this loading function, PLAXIS generates initial stresses by the application of soil self-weight. The groundwater table was assumed to be 15 m below the upper model boundary as shown in Fig. 7a and b. The initial pore water pressures were generated by applying a constant influx of 3.3 × 10−8 m/s at the ground surface for five years until a steady-state condition was attained where no further change in the pore water pressure with time was observed. After a steady-state condition was reached, actual rainfall was applied as a downward positive influx and an upward negative flux was applied to simulate evapotranspiration at the ground surface.



8
Results

8.1
Model calibration
The calibration results presented in Fig. 8a, b and c illustrate the comparisons between predicted and measured hourly volumetric water content changes. Since PLAXIS does not produce direct output as volumetric water content, the soil suction predicted by PLAXIS from the fully coupled analysis was converted to volumetric water content using the wetting SWRC. Fig. 8a and b show that at 0.3 and 0.8 m depths, the model predicted a slightly higher increase in volumetric water content during rainfall. At 0.3 m, the starting volumetric water content in the model was ~0.01 m3/m3 higher than that in the field. At 1.2 m depth, the predicted volumetric water content was found to be in close agreement with the field measurement, as shown in Fig. 8c. The discrepancies between model prediction and field measurement may have resulted from soil heterogeneity, the use of a single wetting SWRC to convert the predicted suction to volumetric water content and hydraulic hysteresis that was not incorporated in PLAXIS. Nonetheless, it is evident that the model effectively captured the overall trend of the volumetric water content changes at all depths. The model also accurately predicted the timing of the increase and decrease of volumetric water content at the start and end of a rainfall event. Hence, despite some discrepancies in the magnitude of the changes, given the ability of the model to closely capture the hydrologic changes in the field during this monsoonal period of the year, the calibrated model was considered suitable for the subsequent analyses.


8.2
Slope stability analysis before the Kanglang landslide

Fig. 9a and b present the results of the slope stability assessment before the Kanglang landslide from 1 December 2017 (when the slope was excavated) to 30 June 2018 (before the main landsliding event in July 2018). Fig. 9a shows that the changes in factor of safety during this period are related directly to the wet and dry phases; the wet phases being the days with non-zero rainfall. During the relatively dry period before 28 February 2018, the factor of safety increased to ~3.5. As the wetting SWRC was introduced into the model on 1 March 2018, the factor of safety dropped slightly but remained consistently high until 18 May 2018 when the daily rainfall was 12 mm or less. After 18 May 2018, the factor of safety decreased gradually with the increase in the occurrence of wet phases.
The decrease in the factor of safety shown in Fig. 9a due to the rainfall can be explained in terms of the changes in the effective degree of saturation and relative permeability. Fig. 9b shows that the smaller changes in the factor of safety during the dry period were because of the decreasing effective saturation and relative permeability of the soil so that rainfall infiltration is limited. With the increase in rainfall after 18 May 2018, both the effective degree of saturation and relative permeability increased gradually (Fig. 9b), allowing a greater amount of water to infiltrate into the ground and consequently leading to a drop in the factor of safety. During a few days in June 2018, the factor of safety dropped slightly below 1 but can be seen to recover after a reduction in rainfall. Although this indicates failure conditions were met, it should be noted that variations in rainfall over small distances, such as that between the site and the most local weather station may be significant here. Further, analysis using daily rainfall allows the degree of saturation of soil to rise continuously during consecutive wet days as dry periods during days considered here as ‘wet’ (e.g., hours) are not taken into consideration. Hence, the factor of safety predicted from this analysis is a conservative estimate. Taking this into consideration, it was assumed that the slope was in a stable condition from December 2017 until the end of June 2018.


8.3
Back-analysis of the Kanglang landslide

8.3.1
Factor of safety
The solid line in Fig. 10
 shows the results of the back-analysis in terms of factor of safety changes in response to rainfall from 1 July to 12 July 2018 (271 h). Six major rainfall events accumulating >5 mm rainfall were recorded, whose effects on the factor of safety are evident in Fig. 10. Before the 6th rainfall event, the factor of safety that decreased during rainfall can be seen to recover, although not fully, during the intervening dry periods. During the 6th rainfall event, however, the factor of safety decreased rapidly from 1.2 at 262nd hour (11 July 2018) to 0.97 at 267th hour (12 July 2018) and thereafter remained consistently below 1. This shows that the 6th rainfall event that had a low intensity (4.4 mm/h) and long duration (10h) may have triggered the Kanglang landslide on 12 July 2018. Although the exact time of the actual landslide is not known, this time frame is in line with the landowner's testimony, which confirms that the developed hydro-mechanical model is capable of predicting the time of slope failure.


8.3.2
Soil suction and total displacements
The reductions in the factor of safety during the six rainfall events illustrated in Fig. 10 suggest the effect of the advancing wetting front on the overall stability of the slope. To better understand the failure mechanism, the effect of rainfall infiltration on the soil suction and total displacements were evaluated.

Fig. 11a and b show the changes in suction at sections A-A* and B-B* (Fig. 11c) during the 6th rainfall event from 261 to 271 h which was predicted to have triggered the Kanglang landslide (Fig. 10). Indicated by the reduction of suction with increasing cumulative rainfall, these figures reveal the gradual advancement of the wetting front near the road cut (A-A*) and mid-slope (B-B*) sections. On 12 July 2018, when the factor of safety dropped to <1 (267th hour), the wetting front advanced to ~1.3 and 1.1 m at sections A-A* and B-B* respectively. A uniform reduction of suction that is more prominent near the ground surface can also be seen in the suction contours at the time of failure (Fig. 11c). With further infiltration thereafter, the wetting front progressed to ~1.7 and 1.6 m depths at sections A-A* and B-B* respectively.
The advancing wetting front also resulted in increased slope displacements, as illustrated in Fig. 12a, where the direct association between rainfall and displacement can be seen in the three sections within the slope, near the road cut (C-C*), mid-slope (D-D*) and slope crest (E-E*) (Fig. 12c). Near the road cut (C-C*), larger displacements were predicted at shallow depths (≤1.3 m), which corresponds to the depth of the wetting front at this section (~1.3 m) at the time of failure (Fig. 11a and Fig. 12a). Similarly, near the mid-slope section (D-D*) and slope crest (E-E*), larger displacements were predicted at ≤1.3 m, also corresponding to the wetting front depth of ~1.1 m when the failure occurred (Fig. 11b and Fig. 12a). Both the maximum wetting front depths (∼1.1 to 1.3 m) and the depths at which larger displacements were predicted by the model (≤1.3 m) are close to the sliding depth of ∼1.5 m estimated at the site during field investigation (section 2), which further validates the model prediction.
Further, relatively larger total displacements were predicted closer to the road cut compared to the other sections of the slope and the total displacements can be seen to increase non-linearly with increasing proximity to the road cut (Fig. 12c). The displacement at this section was predicted to increase to 221, 217 and 193 mm at 0, 0.3 and 0.8 m depths respectively with continued infiltration after the failure, although suction at these depths had not fully dissipated (Fig. 11a and Fig. 12b). Such large displacements despite the presence of suction suggest that the landslide was not triggered alone by the infiltration-induced loss of shear strength. Instead, the landslide was induced by a combined rainfall-road effect, where the rainfall infiltration created a weaker zone with low suction at shallow depths of ≤1.7 m above the road cut, and the presence of the steep road cut promoted the failure by allowing the upslope soil mass to slide, resulting in large displacements at the road cut. Similar results were also reported by Guadagno et al. (2003) where the authors found that the presence of discontinuities in the hillslopes created by road cuts promoted shallow landslides by imparting kinematic freedom to the upslope materials. The results of this study are also in line with the study by Holcombe et al. (2016), where the authors revealed that the slope cuttings in the hillslope can shift the failure surface towards the face of the cut, ultimately decreasing the factor of safety and causing slope failures.



8.4
Stability analysis without road cut
To reinforce the back-analysis results which showed that the presence of the steep road cut promoted the landslide during rainfall, the back-analysis was replicated on a finite element model without the road cut (Fig. 7b), and the results in terms of factor of safety are shown by the dashed line in Fig. 10. A comparison between the two plots in Fig. 10 clearly illustrates the effect of the road cut on slope stability. The actual slope with the road cut had a ∼35% lesser initial factor of safety than that for the idealised, undisturbed slope without the road cut. The presence and absence of the road cut can also be seen to influence the temporal fluctuations in the factor of safety in response to the same series of rainfall events; the model without the road cut remained stable with a factor of safety close to 2.6, while in the actual slope with the road cut, the factor of safety decreased during each rainfall event before eventually dropping below 1 on 12 July 2018. At the time of failure, in comparison to the actual slope, the factor of safety of the undisturbed slope was ~170% greater. This suggests that the rainfall events that occurred before, during and after the Kanglang landslide were not sufficiently high to initiate failure in the natural or undisturbed hillslope.
These observations underline two key points: first, the informal modification of the natural hillslopes for road construction, creating steep road cuts, lowers the initial factor of safety by >30%, which increases the likelihood of slope failure when exposed to rainfall. Second, the observation that the undisturbed slope remained stable with ~170% higher factor of safety than the actual slope, under the same landslide-triggering rainfall events, shows that the presence of a steep road cut can lower the minimum level of rainfall needed to initiate shallow slope failure, which further aggravates the landslide susceptibility.


8.5
Relationship between rainfall duration and factor of safety
The back-analysis result presented in Fig. 10 shows that a relatively greater reduction of the factor of safety was observed during longer duration rainfall events compared to that during shorter duration rainfall events. This result was used to explore the relationship between the rainfall durations and the corresponding changes in the factor of safety. A statistically significant correlation (R2 = 0.97, p < 0.001) was obtained (Fig. 13
), which suggests that an increase in rainfall duration from 5 to 17 h could cause an additional ~10% drop in the factor of safety. While the correlation is based on a limited dataset, the relationship between the two variables suggests that a greater decline in the factor of safety can be expected during long-duration rainfall events compared to during shorter duration rainfall events. This observation agrees with the study by Rahardjo et al. (2007) where the authors showed that slopes with low saturated permeability (≤10−6 m/s) are less affected by short-duration rainfall events, regardless of the rainfall intensity. Such a response can be explained in terms of the infiltration-permeability ratio (I

r

/k

sat
) as discussed by Tsaparas et al. (2002). In soils with low permeability, during high-intensity, short-duration rainfall events (high I

r
/k

sat
 ratio), less water can infiltrate into the ground, resulting in smaller changes to the factor of safety. On the other hand, when this ratio is smaller, as would be the case for low-intensity, longer duration rainfall events, a greater amount of water can infiltrate into the soil and influence the stability of the slope, resulting in a greater decrease in the factor of safety. As rainfall duration plays a critical role in the stability of slopes with low saturated permeability, high-intensity, long-duration rainfall events may be able to cause a relatively greater decrease in the factor of safety than low-intensity, long-duration rainfall events. However, this may also be controlled by the infiltration capacity of the soil, which partially depends on the initial conditions of the slope (Tsaparas et al., 2002).



9
Discussion
In low- and middle-income countries like Nepal, roads are considered fundamental infrastructures, expected to contribute to the socio-economic development of local communities. When the poorly constructed roads become one of the landslide causative factors, the consequences present a contradiction to the primary objective of building the roads. In developing parts of the world, hillslope excavation for roads or for creating flatter sites for urbanisation has been associated with significant landslide and erosion problems (Haigh and Rawat, 2012; Holcombe et al., 2016; Sidle and Ochiai, 2006; Sidle and Ziegler, 2012). While the road networks continue to proliferate across many countries to meet the developmental goals, the need to acknowledge and address the adverse impacts of poorly constructed roads becomes more necessary than ever.
Using a case study of a typical landslide that occurred following a non-engineered slope excavation, the numerical analyses presented in this paper demonstrate how such activities can contribute to landsliding during rainfall. The back-analysis of the investigated landslide showed that when the failure occurred in July 2018, the rainfall infiltration in the unsaturated ground caused a gradual reduction of soil suction at shallow depths (≤1.7 m), but not to a point where the suction dissipated completely or positive pore water pressures started to build up. Despite this the landslide occurred, which to a large extent was promoted by the presence of the road cut that allowed the weaker upslope materials with low suctions to slide, resulting in large displacements at the road cut.
Although the consequences of steep slope cutting for road construction on the occurrence of rainfall-induced landslides are generally well understood and there are both supporting anecdotal and statistical evidence, the results of this study provide a valuable reference that quantifies this effect. More specifically, results show that the presence of a steep road cut on a natural hillslope could reduce the initial factor of safety by ~35%, thereby increasing the susceptibility to landsliding during rainfall. Further, the stability of the undisturbed hillslope (without road cut) under the same rainfall conditions that triggered the investigated landslide (with road cut) shows that the presence of a single road cut can lower the level of minimum rainfall needed to initiate slope failure. It is critical to recognise that a significant proportion of landslides in Nepal occurs during the monsoon when almost 80% of the annual rainfall is expected to occur. The lowering of the minimum landslide-triggering rainfall for slopes modified by road construction means that the rainfall-induced roadside slope failures will become more frequent and extensive during the monsoon if the hillslopes continue to be informally excavated without suitable engineering interventions. The proposed empirical relationship between rainfall duration and percentage decrease in factor of safety further suggests that the reduction of the factor of safety or the risk of slope failure is greater during longer duration rainfall events in modified natural hillslopes with similar soil properties as was encountered at the investigated site. The relevance of the findings of this study extends beyond the presented case study to other developing regions globally, where the road infrastructures need to be better planned and constructed, with a particular focus on minimising the risk of slope instabilities that have both short- and long-term cumulative impacts on lives, infrastructures and the environment in general.
Where economic constraints prevent the adoption of engineering design-based slope protection measures, cost-effective retaining structures such as dry stone and mortared masonry walls, gabion walls and crib walls that utilise locally available materials, can help prevent or mitigate roadside slope failures during rainfall (Hearn, 2011). Bio-engineering techniques such as plantation of deep-rooted plant species, turfing and jute netting are other cost-effective slope protection measures (Devkota et al., 2014). Constructing gentler roadside slopes with angles lower than the angle of shearing resistance of the soil, while adhering to the road construction guidelines e.g. DoR (2003), TRL (1997) is another simple approach that can help prevent rainfall-induced roadside slope failures.
On the slopes that have a high landslide potential during rainfall and pose a greater risk to lives and infrastructures, landslide prediction can prevent disasters from occurring. This study demonstrates the abilities of the coupled hydro-mechanical analysis, with Bishop's effective stress and single wetting SWRC to simulate the long-term hydrological changes in the unsaturated soils and most importantly, to predict the failure timing and failure mechanism of slopes under transient wetting and drying conditions. Application of this approach requires comprehensive site-specific field study, laboratory testing of (un)saturated soil properties and meteorological data, acquiring which may not be feasible in all conditions. This also underlines the need for quality geotechnical and meteorological data in developing countries for the prediction, prevention and mitigation of rainfall-induced landslides. Nonetheless, the lack of geotechnical data could be tackled by obtaining information through empirical estimations, published scientific literature or by utilising community knowledge and participation, as employed by Anderson and Holcombe (2013).


10
Conclusions
This paper presented a case study of a typical roadside slope failure (Kanglang landslide) located in Sindhupalchok district in Nepal that was triggered by the monsoon rainfall in July 2018. An integrated approach combining detailed field investigation, laboratory testing, field monitoring and coupled flow-deformation analyses in PLAXIS 2D was used to understand the failure mechanism of the landslide and to assess the role of rainfall and road cut in inducing this failure. From the work presented in this study, the following conclusions can be drawn:

1.
The back-analysis results showed that the Kanglang landslide occurred during a low intensity (4.4 mm/h), long duration (10 h) rainfall event on 12 July 2018, which agrees with the landowner's testimony that the failure occurred before 16 July 2018. The landslide was caused by a combined effect of rainfall and road cut where the infiltration of rainwater created a weaker zone with low suction at shallow depths of (≤1.7 m) and the presence of the road cut promoted the failure by allowing the upslope materials to slide, resulting in large displacements of ~200 mm at the road cut.


2.
Comparison between the two slope models representing the actual slope (with the road cut) and the idealised undisturbed slope (without the road) showed that the presence of a single steep road cut can increase the susceptibility of slope failure in two ways: first, by reducing the initial factor of safety by over 30%; and second, by lowering the minimum level of rainfall needed to initiate slope failure. This implies that the rainfall-induced roadside slope failures will become more frequent and extensive in the future if the slopes continue to be informally excavated for constructing roads or for other developmental activities.


3.
A statistically significant correlation was found between rainfall duration and percentage decrease in the factor of safety. This relationship suggests that in the informally excavated steep road cut slopes underlain by lower permeability SILTS and Sandy SILTS, as encountered at the investigated site, a greater reduction of the factor of safety can be expected during longer duration rainfall events; an increase in the rainfall duration from 5 to 17 h could cause an additional ~10% decrease in the factor of safety.


4.
Using the measured soil properties, site geometry and rainfall records, this study demonstrates the viability of the coupled hydro-mechanical analysis to effectively capture the hydrologic changes in the soil in response to transient atmospheric conditions, and most importantly, to predict the timing of slope failure and to assess the failure mechanism of rainfall-induced slope failure. For slopes with high rainfall-induced landslide susceptibility that pose a serious risk to lives and infrastructures, landslide prediction using this approach can prevent disasters from occurring. Where hydraulic hysteresis cannot be taken into consideration in the hydro-mechanical analysis, this study also shows that the wetting soil-water retention curve can be suitably adopted to model the hydraulic behaviour of unsaturated soils.



The results from this study provide a reference for recognising the detrimental impact of informal slope cutting for road construction on the occurrence of rainfall-induced landsliding. This should be taken into consideration in future disaster mitigation and reduction strategies in areas where increasing rural access through road construction is also a priority.


CRediT authorship contribution statement

Samprada Pradhan: Conceptualization, Methodology, Software, Validation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Writing – original draft, Visualization. David G. Toll: Conceptualization, Resources, Writing – review & editing, Supervision. Nick J. Rosser: Conceptualization, Resources, Writing – review & editing, Supervision. Matthew J. Brain: Conceptualization, Resources, Writing – review & editing, Supervision.
Text.48:
1
Introduction
In underground mines, seismic events are mainly distributed around mine openings (Luo and Hatherly, 1998; Verdon et al., 2018; Woodward et al., 2018). However, geological structural discontinuities such as faults and dykes can also induce high-stress concentrations and contribute to significant dynamic failures such as coal bursts (Keneti and Sainsbury, 2018; Si et al., 2020). The response of rock mass near geological structures to mining activities can vary as the geological features have different characteristics (Abolfazlzadeh and Hudyma, 2016). To better assess dynamic failures around structural discontinuities, seismic monitoring has been widely used for quantitative seismic characterization in mines (Mutke et al., 2020; Xu et al., 2017).
Seismic activities associated with faults have been well studied. Cheng et al. (2019) investigated fault activation at Dongjiahe longwall coal mine in China. The activation process was defined by four stages based on the distance between the fault and the longwall face. The b-value (Gutenberg and Richter, 1956) decreased as the longwall face approached and mined through the fault, indicating the stress re-distribution around the fault. Henderson et al. (1994) characterized a cluster of seismic events in the fault zone by correlating the b-value with the fractal dimension of sources. A weak positive correlation was found between these two parameters and they suggested that the correlation might be related to the pore pressure. Stec (2007) focused on mine tremors in the Upper Silesian Coal Basin (USCB) in Poland and found that they correlated well with the pre-existing local faults. The source mechanism analysis revealed that mining-related tectonic tremors showed distinguished shear components, whereas the seismic events near the longwall face were more related to tensile failures. Furthermore, Mendecki et al. (2020) systematically categorized the seismic data recorded around a fold hinge zone at USCB based on the faulting mechanisms, which better depicted the stress re-distribution processes around the faults during mining for seismic hazard assessment. Leśniak and Isakow (2009) installed four triaxial geophones in the Zabrze-Bielszowice mine in the USCB and identified two clusters of seismic events depicting the orientation of the faults in the mining panel. Hazard functions incorporating event energy or time intervals were developed to evaluate the relationship between specific clusters and high energy events. Cai et al. (2020) investigated the coal burst mechanism associated with faults through laboratory experiments, numerical modelling and field monitoring. They summarized that the high static stress controlled by the geological structures and the dynamic stress induced by mining both contribute to coal bursts.
On the other hand, to the best of the authors' knowledge, there have been few comprehensive studies on the detailed seismic characterization of dykes for coal burst risk assessment. Dykes were often formed in pre-existing fractures (e.g., faults and joints) as consequences of igneous intrusions (Bell, 1983). The mechanical properties of the dyke are different from those of its surrounding rocks and the dyke can influence the failure mechanisms of rock mass in its vicinity. Keneti and Sainsbury (2020) applied numerical modelling to evaluate the seismic hazard near a stiff dyke at the Palabora Mine in South Africa in the absence of seismic data. The results suggested that a stiff dyke can induce more stress concentration which can lead to sudden rock failures. The strain-burst risk near the dyke is higher. However, in-situ seismic data is required for more reliable risk prediction. In order to evaluate the stress state near major geological discontinuities, Shen et al. (2020) analyzed the stress and displacement data acquired near a dyke at an Australian longwall coal mine and correlated them with the seismic data. Numerical experiments were also conducted to investigate the effect of the dyke on the local stress conditions. The results showed that the in-situ stress has a dominant influence on the strain energy in the ribs around the dyke. The seismic data correlated well with the stress and displacement measurements.
To improve the understanding of the failure mechanisms associated with dykes, this study investigates the seismic evolutionary and statistical characteristics near an intrusive dyke at an underground longwall coal mine in the Gunnedah Basin, New South Wales, Australia. The temporal-spatial changes in seismicity, event locations, Es/Ep ratio, magnitude-frequency distributions, and correlations with the released seismic energy around this intrusive structure are presented. The results showed that the dyke intensified seismic activities in its vicinity. The seismic characteristics at the inbye and outbye sides of the dyke were different and the seismic intensity changed as the longwall mining progressed. The temporal-spatial characterization of seismic multi-parameters around this major dyke provides more reliability to mines for assessing and mitigating coal burst risks near such geological discontinuities.


2
Monitoring site and network configurations

2.1
Site characteristics
Gunnedah Basin is in the northeast of New South Wales in Australia (Fig. 1
) and has abundant coal resources (Tadros, 1995). Igneous intrusions (i.e., dykes and sills) have been widely found in the Permian and Triassic strata in the Gunnedah Coalfield and have affected the coal mining (Gurba and Weber, 2001). In 2017, a research project was conducted at an underground longwall coal mine in the Gunnedah Basin to investigate the seismic characteristics near an igneous dyke during mining. This longwall mine had a coal seam of Jurassic and Triassic age. The monitored longwall panel was 400 m wide, 3000 m long and 280 m deep. It had a competent conglomerate roof with a thickness of 15 m to 20 m which had a controlling effect on longwall periodical weighting. The longwall panel was intersected by a major dyke which has a length of >800 m (Fig. 2
). The thickness of this dyke ranged from 0.5 m to 3 m. It dipped towards north at an approximate angle of 75°–80°. As the mining direction of the panel was from north to south, the inbye and outbye indicate the north and south sides of the dyke, respectively. To encourage the overburden to cave and reduce potential seismic hazards, hydraulic fracturing was carried out to weaken the conglomerate roof before the coal seam was mined. However, a number of pressure bumps still occurred near the dyke during roadway development. It was assumed by the mine that the roadway section intersected by the dyke could be a coal burst prone area when the longwall was mining through the dyke. To evaluate and mitigate the coal burst risks, a microseismic monitoring network was installed to monitor the seismic activities in this area.


2.2
Monitoring network
Four triaxial intrinsically safe geophones were installed for this project. The geophone model is GS-20DX, manufactured by Geospace Technologies. Its corner frequency is 10 Hz and sensitivity is 27.6 V/m/s. The geophones were placed symmetrically near the dyke along the longwall maingate roadway. On each side of the dyke, one vertical geophone was installed in the roof and one horizontal geophone in the coal seam. The northern components of the triaxial geophones were directed to the north for correct seismic ray path orientation. All geophones were cemented in the boreholes to be well-coupled with the rock mass. The geophone cables were deployed from the ground surface down to the roadway through a borehole. A 12-channel seismic data logger manufactured by ES&S in Australia was installed on the ground surface. This configuration effectively avoided the electronic noise introduced by the high-voltage power line installed along the roadway. It allowed the data acquisition system to be easily accessed for maintenance. The seismic data was continuously recorded using a 1000 Hz sampling rate. The seismic data recorded from 26 November 2017 to 23 March 2018 was analyzed in this research. During this four-month monitoring period, the longwall retreated approximately 650 m and mined through the dyke.
In addition, one set of stressmeters was deployed in the coal seam at each side of the dyke to monitor the stress changes. Each stressmeter set included a uniaxial and a biaxial stressmeter. The uniaxial stressmeters were installed with an inclined angle of 30° upwards. The biaxial stressmeters were installed horizontally 4 m into the ribs. The uniaxial and biaxial stressmeters were installed approximately 10 m away from the dyke. The detailed layout of the geophones and stressmeters is shown in Fig. 3
.



3
Seismic data processing methods

3.1
Clustered events classification
In this project, two clusters of seismic events were observed. The first cluster of events was around the longwall face and they were mainly associated with the longwall caving induced by the excavation. The second group of events was located within the area of interest as indicated in Fig. 2. To accurately assess the seismic activity near the dyke, a Deep Convolutional Neural Network (DCNN) model was developed to discriminate seismic events clustered around the dyke and the longwall face (Duan et al., 2021b). The complete dataset was processed using the DCNN model. The discriminated events were reviewed manually to ensure the seismic events were accurately classified based on their locations.


3.2
Event location
Because the geophones were installed in different geological units with a dyke in the middle of the microseismic monitoring network, the accuracy of event locations can be problematic if a homogeneous velocity model is used for source location. To accurately locate the seismic events around the dyke, geological data (Table 1
) was collected from the mine to develop a 3D velocity model (Fig. 4
). The velocity model incorporated the local strata and the dyke. A novel shortest path method based on a boundary discretization scheme (SPM-BDS) (Duan et al., 2021a) was applied for source location. The method proposed by Tarantola and Valette (1982) was adopted to evaluate the location uncertainties. The time measurement errors were used for the evaluation and the median location errors were found to be <10 m.

The other endpoint on this segment is treated as the source. By iterating this process, the seismic energy of P and S waves released at the actual source point can be obtained to compute the Es/Ep ratio of the seismic event. 4
Microseismic characterization of the dyke

4.1
Evolution of mining-induced seismicity
In total, 20,526 seismic events occurred near the dyke in the four months of monitoring. The daily seismicity is shown in Fig. 5
. Four stages of variations of seismicity and mining progress are identified (Fig. 6
). The first stage is from 26 November 2017 to 31 January 2018. In this period rock fractures had already initiated around the dyke when the longwall face was 400 m away from the dyke. During this stage, the seismicity was low until the longwall face was 200 m from the dyke. Seismicity continued to increase and reached the first peak when the longwall was 100 m ahead of the dyke on 25 January. After the peak, it gradually dropped and became much less intensive from 28 to 31 January even though the longwall-miner was still mining. The second stage is from 1 to 10 February. The longwall-miner mined the last 50 m of the inbye part of the dyke. Seismicity erupted to the second peak at the beginning of this stage and remained intensive during the entire period. The third stage is from 11 to 28 February. In this stage, the longwall was mined to the outbye side of the dyke. Seismicity was active before 14 February when the longwall production stopped for maintenance. Mining resumed on 26 February and the daily seismicity reached another peak of nearly 1400 events before the longwall mined past the dyke for 50 m. The fourth stage is from 1 to 23 March. The seismicity drastically declined after the peak and gradually decreased towards the end of this period, except for one minor sudden seismicity increase on 16 March.


4.2
Propagations of rock fractures
This section presents the variations of spatial distributions of seismic events during the four stages defined in Section 4.1. In total, 4047 seismic events were located. The detailed three-dimensional evolutions of the rock fractures around the dyke are shown in Fig. 7
.
Stage I shows that rock fractures initiated between Headings B and C at the inbye dyke when the longwall was distant from the dyke. The fractures were mainly clustered in the immediate roof and the conglomerate. There was a weak connection in the siltstone layer between the two clusters. Unlike brittle geological structures such as faults, the dyke was stiff and fractures were not located along the dipping angle of the dyke.
During Stage II, the longwall mined to the dyke and the fractures in the immediate roof and conglomerate significantly intensified. Secondary support was completed before the longwall mined to the dyke to stabilize the roadways. More fractures were concentrated in the pillars at the inbye dyke. Meanwhile, the fractures started to propagate to the outbye side. In cross-section, the events were mainly in the immediate roof and coal seam.
At the beginning of the third stage, the longwall was mined past the dyke for approximately 20 m and stopped for 12 days. After mining resumed, a sudden increase in seismicity was observed. Most of these fractures were in the coal seam and siltstone layers at the outbye side of the dyke. However, no clustered fractures in the conglomerate were identified, indicating an abrupt stress change in the outbye ribs and immediate roof as the longwall mined to the outbye dyke. In the meantime, the rock fractures in the inbye siltstone and conglomerate were connected.
During the last stage, compared with the fracture density at the inbye side while the longwall was mined towards the dyke, it is evident that there was a decrease in seismic events when the mining retreated further away from the dyke. The fractures propagated lower into the coal seam at both inbye and outbye sides. Meanwhile, seismic events clustered in the roof along the outbye roadway (Heading B). At the inbye side of the dyke, a considerate number of seismic events still occurred, indicating continuing rock failures at the inbye side of the dyke even though the longwall had mined past the dyke.


4.3
Distribution of Es/Ep ratios
The distribution of Es/Ep ratios of all located events is presented in Fig. 8
. The seismic events with Es/Ep ratios below 1 and above 10 account for approximately 5% and 10% of the complete dataset, respectively. Because of the distribution, these two types of seismic events were defined as pure tensile and shear events. The distribution also shows the fractures near the dyke were predominantly controlled by shear slips rather than volumetric stress change. As the Es/Ep ratio increases, the seismic events are more related to pure shear failures and exhibit larger magnitude, which is consistent with the characteristics of the seismic events close to faults (Kwiatek and Ben-Zion, 2013).
The 3D distributions of seismic events with different failure mechanisms are shown in Fig. 9
. To better compare the distribution patterns of these events, the 1D probability density and 2D probability density contours of these event distributions were also estimated using a Kernel Density Estimator (KDE) (Rosenblatt, 1956). KDE is a non-parametric method to estimate the probability density function (PDF) of independent samples. The kernel density estimator is expressed as:

where K is the non-negative kernel function and h is the smoothing bandwidth of the kernel function. The KDE can be performed in any number of dimensions. In this analysis, the Gaussian kernel was applied to estimate the PDF. The bandwidth was selected by Scott's Rule as a ‘rule of thumb’ (Bashtannyk and Hyndman, 2001).
As shown in Fig. 9a, the tensile events appeared to be randomly distributed around the dyke. The majority of the pure shear events with Es/Ep ratios of >10 were located at the inbye side of the dyke. In cross-section, looking towards the east (Fig. 9b), they were clustered along the dipping angle of the dyke from the conglomerate to the coal seam in cross-section. A few pure shear events were located at the outbye side of the dyke and concentrated in the coal seam. The seismic events with different failure mechanisms show relatively consistent distributions, looking towards the north. They mainly occurred in the pillars and above the roadway of Heading B (Fig. 9c). The distributions suggest that not many fault-slip events were located along the stiff dyke. Fractures were induced in the rock mass of its proximity. The inbye side of the dyke was subjected to more stress concentration and release. Cracks initiated and propagated in all inbye layers, which resulted in progressively more crack closures and shear failures.


4.4
Variations of b-values
The frequency-magnitude distribution of seismic events located around the dyke is depicted in Fig. 10
. The distribution follows a log-linear relationship. The b-value is 1.44 and the magnitude of completeness M

c
 of this dataset is −2.5.
The temporal variations of the b-value at the dyke were further explored to investigate the correlation with the cumulative seismic energy. A time window of 500 seismic events and a rolling window of 200 events were applied to estimate the variations of b-value. As there were 4047 seismic events located around the dyke, a total number of 18 b-values were estimated for all rolling time windows. To avoid potential computational artifacts, a magnitude unit of 0.5 was applied in the b-value estimation (Nava et al., 2017). The variations of the b-value were correlated with the cumulative seismic energy and number of seismic events (Fig. 11
).
In Stage I, weak fractures initiated at the dyke. The condition for computing the first b-value (recording 500 seismic events) was attained by the end of this stage. In Stage II, the accumulation of released seismic energy started to accelerate and more b-values were obtained because of the more frequent occurrence of seismic events. The b-value and cumulative seismic energy appeared to have an inverse relationship, indicating an increase in the magnitudes of seismic events. When the longwall was being mined in the proximity of the dyke, the b-value was more frequently acquired. It started to increase as the seismic energy accumulation slowed down. It suggested that even though more fractures occurred near the dyke, the released energy of these events was relatively weak as they propagated to the outbye side (Fig. 7). The b-value and seismic energy showed the same patterns in Stage III. There was a slow decrease of b-value from the end of this stage, through to early Stage IV. The b-value became stable after a sudden minor increase of cumulative seismic energy after the longwall mined to approximately 80 m beyond the dyke.



5
Discussions and conclusions
In this project, the longwall location controlled the seismicity recorded by the four geophones. However, even though the longwall was distant from the dyke, mining could still induce seismic events near the dyke. As shown in Fig. 5, the seismicity became active when the longwall was mined to 200 m ahead of the dyke. The rock fractures were mainly at the inbye side of the dyke (Fig. 7a). The fractures continued to develop and led to more significant shear failures as the longwall face approached the dyke. As a result, the cumulation of seismic energy accelerated and the b-value decreased before the longwall face mined through the dyke. After the longwall mined past the dyke, rock fractures propagated to the outbye side of the dyke. It appeared that the outbye coal seam and immediate roof were prone to weak fractures so that the stress was more frequently released. As a result, only a few pure shear failures occurred at the outbye side of the dyke.
As discussed above, it is evident that the seismic characteristics at the inbye and outbye sides of the dyke behaved differently. To further demonstrate their different behaviors, the seismic events were categorized as two groups: the inbye and outbye events. The seismic energy of each group of events was correlated with the changes of vertical stresses in the inbye and outbye roofs (Fig. 12
). The figure demonstrated that as the longwall face moved closer to the dyke, the stress near the dyke was larger and more intensive seismicity was recorded. The changes in seismicity follow a non-linear relationship with the distance of the longwall face to the dyke. The seismic energy responded more sensitively than the stress when the longwall mined the inbye side of the dyke. On the other hand, the outbye vertical stress correlated better with the released seismic energy. Especially during the two periods A and B as marked in Fig. 12, two sudden seismic energy releases were observed, which correspond with the abnormal changes of the vertical stress, respectively.
In conclusion, multiple temporal-spatial seismic parameters including seismicity, event locations, Es/Ep ratio, b-value distribution and correlation with the stress conditions were characterized to analyze the rock mass response to longwall mining near a major dyke at an underground coal mine. The main results are summarized below:

1.
A group of mining-induced seismic events near the dyke was registered. Four stages were defined based on the temporal variations of seismicity. The distance between the longwall face and the dyke controlled the frequency of seismic events. The seismicity was more intensive when the longwall was being mined towards the dyke than the seismicity when the longwall was being mined away from the dyke.


2.
The seismic events were concentrated at the hanging wall of the dyke. They were mainly distributed in the pillar ribs, immediate roof and conglomerate, which correlated well with the orientation of the dyke. The rock fractures propagated to the outbye side when the longwall was mined through the dyke at the end of Stage II. Most of the outbye fractures were in the pillar ribs and immediate roof.


3.
The majority of the seismic events were dictated by shear fractures. As the Es/Ep ratio increased, the event magnitude increased. The seismic events with higher Es/Ep ratios were located at the inbye side of the dyke.


4.
The temporal variations of the b-value near the dyke were evaluated. A reduction of b-value was observed before the longwall mined through the dyke and it indicated higher magnitude seismic events dominated by shear failures occurred at the inbye side of the dyke, suggesting more sudden seismic energy release and escalating seismic risks in this area. When the longwall was mining through the dyke, even though the seismicity was intensive, the energy was more frequently but gently released so that stress was not significantly accumulated to induce any major failures at the outbye side of the dyke.


5.
The released seismic energy was well correlated with the stress measurements from the field in both temporal and spatial domains. It depicted the local stress re-distribution status close to the dyke and its changes were more sensitive than the stress changes, indicating the seismic energy may provide earlier warning on the impending rock dynamic hazards.



The presence of the dyke intersected by the roadway intensified the mining-induced seismicity. The temporal-spatial variations of seismic characteristics revealed that the rock mass responses at the inbye and outbye sides of the dyke were different. The failure mode of the dyke was associated with its geological features (geometry and stiffness) and the mining direction of the longwall face. The comprehensive analysis could provide reliable indicators to the mine for coal burst risk forecast and management near such intrusive geological discontinuities.

1
Introduction
It is an urgent issue to handle high level radioactive waste (HLW) from nuclear power industry. Many countries planned to seal HLW deeply underground, which is designated as deep geological disposal method. In a Japanese deep geological disposal project, a multi-barrier system, including vitrified waste, stainless over pack container, buffer material and host rock, would be constructed ~300 m underground to prevent the leakage of HLW. Bentonites and their based mixtures were selected as candidate buffer materials due to their low hydraulic conductivities (Komine and Ogata, 2004; Komine, 2008).
It is very hard to obtain hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated bentonite with steady state method, since suction control is technically difficult. Instantaneous profiling method (Fredlund and Rahardjo, 1993; Lu and Likos, 2004) was carried out by some investigators to obtain hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated bentonite. This method can be divided into two ways: 1) monitor instantaneous relative humidity. Cui et al. (2008) and Ye et al. (2009) installed several relative humidity sensors in a column permeability-meter to measure hydraulic conductivities of bentonites under wetting; 2) observe instant water content. Water diffusivities of bentonites were studied by Takeuchi et al. (1995) and Wang et al. (2020) by measuring water contents of evenly cut slices from column specimens. Moreover, hydraulic conductivity can be calculated by water diffusivity and soil water retention curve (SWRC). In this study, a new multi-ring was designed to obtain hydraulic conductivities of unsaturated bentonites by instantaneous profiling method following Takeuchi et al. (1995).
Experimental observations already indicated that hydraulic conductivities of soils being affected greatly by their pores systems (Dixon et al., 1999; Gao et al., 2021). Kozeny-Carmen (KC) equation, which was proposed by Kozeny (1927) and later progressed by Carman (1937), Carman (1938) and Carman (1939), is a well-known relation between hydraulic conductivities and pores distributions. Some textbooks (e.g., Demenico and Schwartz, 1997; Corey, 2003) reported that the KC equation applies to sands instead of clays. However, this view was just supported by partial demonstration (Chapuis and Aubertin, 2003). Later studies reported that, KC equation performed well for non-swelling soils (Fig. 1

(a) from Chapuis and Aubertin, 2003) and that equation cannot predict bentonites hydraulic conductivities correctly (Fig. 1
(b) from Chen et al., 2021). Efforts were made by scholars (e.g., Chen et al., 2021) to modifying KC equation for predicting hydraulic conductivities of bentonites by the assumption that: inter-layer pores (Fig. 2
) have limited influence on the flow of waters in compacted bentonites (Ichikawa et al., 1999; Suzuki et al., 2005; Pusch and Yong, 2006). Inter-layer pores can be quantitatively evaluated by basal spacing (Fig. 2) from X-ray diffraction testing results (Likos and Lu, 2006; Holmboe et al., 2012; Sedighi and Thomas, 2014). The new multi-ring can also be applied to XRD tests, furthermore providing experimental data to modify KC equation.
In this study, a new multi-ring was designed to obtain hydraulic conductivities and basal spacings of unsaturated bentonites synchronously. A dual pores system, which can be quantified by basal spacing, was proposed to modify KC equation for predicting saturated and unsaturated hydraulic conductivities of bentonites well.


2
Materials and testing methodology

2.1
Material
This study used three bentonites: 1) MX-80, sodium type bentonite from Wyoming, USA; 2) Kunigel-V1, sodium type bentonite from Yamagata, Japan; and 3) Kunibon, calcium type bentonite from Miyagi, Japan. Physical properties of these bentonites and their values are presented in Table 1
. Soil particle density of each bentonite was obtained by JGS 0111-2009. The percentages of fines (grain size <0.075 mm) in bentonites were determined by passing air-dried bentonites through 0.075 mm sieve. Montmorillonite contents were measured using methylene blue adsorption method (JIS, 2019). CECs (total cation exchangeable capacity) and EXCs (amount of extractable cations) were tested following JGS 0261–2009 (JGS, 2009a; JGS, 2009b).


2.2
Testing methodology for confined wetting with multi-ring and XRD test
The saturation tests were carried out with a wetting apparatus (Fig. 3

(a) by applying a newly designed multi-ring (Fig. 3
(b),
Fig. 3
(d)). The multi-ring comprises five mold rings (~2 mm thickness) and four two-piece rings (~0.25 mm thickness) installed between mold rings (Fig. 3
(c),
Fig. 3
(d)). Herein, each mold ring was numbered as No. 1-No. 5 by the vertical direction (Fig. 3
(b)). To achieve height of ~11 mm and diameter of 28 mm specimen, air dried bentonite powders were put into multi-ring and compressed in a static load device. Then, multi-ring mold together with specimen (Fig. 2(d)) were installed in the wetting apparatus. The parts of the multi-ring in contact with the air were wrapped by plastic film to prevent the evaporation of water in specimen during saturation. Finally, distilled water was supplied by the water inlet from the bottom of specimen.
In each dry density condition, seven specimens were prepared for the wetting duration of 2–240 h. Specimen details are presented in Table 2
. After different wetting durations, water supply was terminated. Multi-ring and specimen were taken out and their vertical deformation was constrained by a clip immediately (Fig. 3
(e)). Later, two-piece rings were removed one by one and specimen was carefully sliced from the tiny gap between mold rings into five slices using a thin saw (~0.20 mm thickness, Fig. 3
(e)). Afterwards, slices were sealed immediately using a Para film (Fig. 3
(e)). Then, slices with Para film were placed under constrained condition at room temperature (25 °C) for at least 48 h to achieve uniform water distributions. Subsequently, these slices were sent to XRD tests (Fig. 3
(f)). A diffractometer, RINT-UltimaIII (Rigaku Corp., Japan), with Cu Kα source was employed. The X-ray scan range was 2.7°-10° with a scan speed of 20°/min under Parallel-Beam geometry. A relative fast scanning speed was chosen for minimizing the possible specimen rebound and water evaporation during XRD scanning. After XRD tests, water content of each slice was measured.


2.3
Testing methodology for wetting with 5-mm height ring and SWRC test
Normally, vapor equilibrium method (e.g., Sun et al., 2007; Sun et al., 2010) was adopted to prepare specimen for soil water retention curve (SWRC). In that method, specimens were putted in salt solution-controlled relative humidity to achieve different water contents. However, the former multi-ring confined wetting tests were infiltered by distilled water. In order to maintain the consistency of testing conditions, the specimens for the suction measurement in this study were wetted by distilled water as well. In this section, a 5-mm height ring (Fig. 4

) was used instead of the above-mentioned multi-ring. Although there were differences in the thickness of specimens, Iyer et al. (2013) reported that the specimen thickness has limited effect on SWRC.
Firstly, specimens were prepared as introduced before. Then, 5-mm height ring and specimen were sandwiched by two stainless plates and their vertical deformations were restricted by bolts. Hereafter, specimens were wetted by immersing them into distilled water (Fig. 4). In each dry density, eight specimens were prepared for wetting duration of 0.5–96 h. Specimen details by using 5-mm height ring are listed in Table 2. After different wetting durations, specimens were taken out and sealed by Parafilm immediately. For achieving as uniformly as water distribution, specimens were placed in confined condition for at least 10 days at room temperature (25 °C). After that, specimens were pushed out from 5-mm height ring carefully and sent to suction measurement with WP4C dew-point potentiometer immediately. Comparing to the previous 2-mm height slice, the 5-mm height specimen was placed for a much longer time to obtain an even water distribution. Therefore, it is necessary to check the loss of water during placement. Herein, specimens (including the 5 mm ring and Para film) were weighed after sealing and before suction measurement. The mass differences of specimens were all less than 0.01 g, indicating that almost no reduction of water occurred during placement. After suction measurement, water content of each specimen was measured.

Additionally, the relation between water diffusivity and hydraulic conductivity can be given as (Corey, 2003; Lu and Likos, 2004):

 shows hydraulic conductivity changing with volumetric water content of bentonites. It is apparently from Fig. 11 that, hydraulic conductivity exhibits a “Ո” shape with the change of volumetric water content. A “Ո” shape was also reported by Takeuchi et al. (1995) for k - θ curve of Kunigel-V1 bentonite. Additionally, from Cui et al. (2008), Ye et al. (2009) and Wang et al. (2013), a “U” shape for k - ψ relations of bentonites were addressed. These results do not correspond to the observations commonly made on non-expansive unsaturated soils, for which hydraulic conductivity increases in a continuous way upon wetting. This phenomenon may because of the microstructure evolutions of compacted bentonite during saturation. By MIP and SEM tests, Pusch and Yong (2006), Musso et al. (2013) and Romero (2013) indicated that, the microstructure of bentonite is dynamic with water adsorption. With the increase of water content, aggregates are expected to be divisible into particles (e.g., Musso et al., 2013). In relative dry stage, hydraulic conductivity was governed by the suction gradient. As the infiltration of water, suction decreases with increasing water content, leading to an increase in hydraulic conductivity. When approaching saturated state, aggregates were expected to break down into particles (Fig. 2). The hydraulic conductivity would be converted to be controlled by the inter-particle pores. As the saturation proceeds, the particle volume would expand, thereby compressing the inter-particle pores. The permeation channel would become smaller as the inter-particle pore decreases, resulting in a decrease in hydraulic conductivity.



3.2
X-Ray diffraction results

3.2.1
XRD profiles

Fig. 12
 shows XRD profiles of slices in vertical direction (Slice No. 1-No. 5 as Fig. 3
(b)) at some wetting durations. It is noteworthy that the Y axis in Fig. 12 is an arbitrary scale, not a specific scale. It can be easily found from Fig. 12, water content generally decreases when slice changes from No. 1-No. 5, when t = 4 h and 24 h. And when t = 240 h, water contents are in relative stable values. Besides that, from Fig. 12, one can readily inferred is the peaks exist in XRD profiles. As we can see from Fig. 12, for all three bentonites, when t = 4 h and 24 h, the peaks slowly move to the right when slice changes from No. 1-No. 5. When t = 240 h, peaks seem to occur in similar diffraction angles.

Fig. 13

As indicated in Fig. 13, water contents of slices generally increase as wetting duration rises. Regarding the peak position, from Fig. 13, peaks happen when 2φ = approx. 4–8°. A generally trend from Fig. 13 can be concluded that, peak moves from approx. 8° to approx. 4° as wetting duration rises. Another phenomenon can be found from Fig. 13 that, intensity of XRD profile seems grow as increasing wetting duration, which means that intensity of XRD profile might increase as the increase of water content. Another important ingredient can be observed from Fig. 13 is the state of water molecule arrangement in inter-layer space (L). As Wang et al. (2020) reported, d

Modifying KC equation to predict hydraulic conductivities

4.1
Introduction of KC equation
It is well known that hydraulic conductivity is affected significantly by pores system (Dixon et al., 1999; Gao et al., 2021). Kozeny-Carmen (KC) equation, which was proposed by Kozeny (1927) basing on Stoke's law and later progressed by Carman (1937, 1938, 1939), related saturated hydraulic conductivity (k

sat
) with saturated total porosity (n

total,s
