From some text books in geotechnical field (e.g., Demenico and Schwartz, 1997; Corey, 2003), the KC equation was considered to be approximately valid for sands and inadequate for clays. The reasons why they do this statement may because of the following two main limitations of KC equation (Carrier, 2003):
1. This equation based on a solid-fluid system, which needs the surface of porous material is relatively compacted and flat;
2. This equation assumed that there is no electrical-chemical reaction between fluid and porous material.
Regarding above two aspects, Carman (1939) and Zhai et al. (2022) ascribed that a thin water layer or “water film” would attach on the surface of soil minerals (Chapuis and Aubertin, 2003; Pusch and Yong, 2006) due to the negative charged soil minerals. Fig. 15
 shows mineral structures, water flow paths of kaolinite and illite. The thin water film would provide a soil mineral-fluid interface for water to flow between unit kaolinite and illite mineral layers (Zhai et al., 2022). In the case of kaolinite, although there would be some potassium cations existing in the inter-layer space (Mitchell and Kenichi, 2005), it is assumed that these potassium cations do not affect the flow of water due to the small hydration potential energy. Meanwhile, that thin water film may weaken the electrical-chemical reactions between fluid and soil mineral to some extent. Efforts were made by scholars to verifying the validity the KC equation to some non-expansive soils. Fig. 1
(a) presents the comparison between experimental saturated hydraulic conductivities of Kaolinite, Illite and Boston blue clay (Olsen, 1960), Champlain clays (Tavenas et al., 1983), and Kaolinite (Al-Tabbaa and Wood, 1987) and their prediction by KC from Chapuis and Aubertin (2003). It can be easily found from Fig. 1
(a), KC equation can predict saturated hydraulic conductivities of non-expansive soils well. However, KC equation was reported cannot predict saturated hydraulic conductivities of bentonites well (Chen et al., 2021). Fig. 1
(b) presents saturated hydraulic conductivities of some bentonites and their predictions by KC equation from Chen et al. (2021). It is apparently from Fig. 1
(b) that there are errors between predictive values calculated using KC equation and experimental data of different bentonites: Kunigel-V1 (Cui et al., 2008), GMZ (Ye et al., 2014) and FEBEX (Lloret and Villar, 2007).


4.2
Modifying KC Equation by Waters Flow Mechanism in Pores of Bentonite

Fig. 2 indicates the traditional structure of compacted bentonite. Bentonite is a mixture of non-swelling and swelling minerals. Regarding the swelling mineral in bentonite, montmorillonite is often viewed as the only mineral contribute to the swelling (e.g., Komine and Ogata, 1996; Komine and Ogata, 2004). Montmorillonite has a unique 2:1 mineral structure consists of two structural units: silica tetrahedron and alumina octahedron (e.g. Jacinto et al., 2012). Unit layers, which are negative charged (Komine, 2008), are often stacked one above another, composing particles. Unit layer numbers needed to form a particle is changeable and reported decreasing with rising degree of saturation (Chen et al., 2021). Besides that, several particles would form an aggregate. The microstructures of compacted bentonite are dynamic during saturation (Suzuki et al., 2005). Big aggregates/particles are expected being divided into small aggregates/particles with the progress of hydration (Romero, 2013; Chen et al., 2021). In the case of pores in bentonite, different categories were proposed (e.g., Gens and Alonso, 1992; Pusch and Yong, 2006). Among those classifications, a generally accepted one is (Fig. 2, referred from Pusch and Yong, 2006) that: 1) micro-level pores, pores between montmorillonite layers (inter-layer pores), 2) meso-level pores, pores between particles (inter-particle pores), and 3) macro-level pores, pores between aggregates (inter-aggregate pores).
Additionally, waters in compacted bentonite are categorized by their positions, as: a) water in inter-layer pore (inter-layer water); b) water in inter-aggregate pore (inter-aggregate water); and c) water in intra-aggregate pore (intra-aggregate water). Firstly, regarding the inter-layer water. Montmorillonite has much greater hydration potential than kaolinite and illite (Pusch and Yong, 2006). When montmorillonite layers meet water, the greater hydration force would attract the cations and water molecules into inter-layer pores (Fig. 2, Olphen, 1977). And, those cations and water molecules would be orderly arranged on the surface of negative charged montmorillonite layers, enlarging the inter-layer space (Yong, 1999b). Unlike the waters between kaolinite and illite unit layers, the inter-layer water of montmorillonite is viewed as immobile due to the much bigger attractive force between water molecule and unit layers from significantly greater hydration potential (Bradbury and Baeyens, 2003). Meanwhile, inter-layer pores were reported having negligible contribution to the flow of water in compacted bentonite by many scholars (Ichikawa et al., 1999; Suzuki et al., 2005; Pusch and Yong, 2006). Secondly, for the inter-particle water. Inter-particle water can be divided into free water and diffuse double layer (DDL) water (Tachi and Yotsuji, 2014; Chen et al., 2021). Free water is considered to be moveable (Appelo and Wersin, 2007). DDL water is resulted from the soil particle-water “osmotic” or “matric” interactions (Yong, 1999a). After soil particle encounters water, the osmotic potential generated by the movement of ions in the fluid would bring a thin “water film” on the surface of montmorillonite particles (Fig. 2). This “water film” can be regarded as the fixed layer of DDL to a certain degree, and designated as DDL water. DDL water has less mobility than free water and better mobility than inter-layer water (Chen et al., 2021). The thin “water film” or DDL water on the montmorillonite particle surface may provide a solid-fluid interface for free water to move (Fig. 2). Thirdly, inter-aggregate water is viewed as free water because of the permeable tunnel between aggregates is considerable.
In this study, another pores classification is proposed by Likos and Lu (2006) and Sedighi and Thomas (2014), as: 1) micro pore is defined as the inter-layer pore, and 2) macro pore is the pore excluding inter-layer pore (including inter-aggregate pore and intra-aggregate pore). With the discussions above, the water flowing mechanism by pores can be summarized as: macro pore is the flow path for moveable water (Fig. 2).
Additionally, basing on the aforementioned discussions, this study changed n

Comparisons between modified KC equation and testing data

Fig. 19
 presents saturated hydraulic conductivities of MX-80 (Pusch, 2001; Karnland et al., 2008; Komine, 2008; Komine, 2021), Kunigel-V1 (Pusch, 2001; Hasegawa, 2004; Komine, 2008; Sadamatsu, 2021) and Kunibon (Komine, 2008), and their predictions using traditional KC and modified KC equation in this study. Table 4

From Table 1 and Table 4, it was found that the physical properties values of testing materials in the literatures are somewhat different from those in this study, especially the montmorillonite content of MX-80. Although it is bentonite of the same name, the difference in physical properties brought by the difference in excavation site is usual. In this section, for better certificating the validity of traditional and modified KC with testing database from literatures, the properties values of bentonites from literatures as Table 4 were adopted. It is apparently from Fig. 19, for all three bentonites, modified KC equation predicts much better than traditional KC equation.

(a), modified KC equation predicts the testing saturated hydraulic conductivities of MX-80 from Karnland et al. (2008), Komine (2008) and Komine (2021) well in the range of total dry density. The modified DDL equation performs better in high dry density range (ρ
d > 1.6 Mg/m3) than low dry density range. However, neither modified KC equation and modified DDL equation can fit the saturated hydraulic conductivities from Pusch (2001) well. Regarding Kunigel-V1, in Fig. 19
(b), the predictive value from modified KC is bigger than experimental results of Hasegawa (2004), Komine (2008) and Sadamatsu (2021). And, predictive value is smaller than the results from Pusch (2001). The modified DDL equation predicts Kunigel-V1 saturated hydraulic conductivities from Hasegawa (2004), Komine (2008) and Sadamatsu (2021) well in high dry density range (ρ
d > 1.6 Mg/m3). In the low dry density range (ρ

d
 < 1.6 Mg/m3), the prediction from modified DDL equation is smaller than those testing data. Meanwhile, the modified DDL equation predictive value is much smaller than Pusch (2001). From Fig. 19
(c), both modified KC and modified DDL equations predict saturated hydraulic conductivities of Kunibon from Komine (2008) pretty well.

Fig. 11 reveals hydraulic conductivity changing with volumetric water content for bentonites, and its prediction by modified KC equation using new relative permeability (Θ

macro
). Herein, bentonites physical properties values in this study as Table 1 were used to verify the accuracy of prediction. It can be easily found from Fig. 11, for all three bentonites, experimental database show “Ո” shapes while the predictions exhibit more standard curves. This is due to the fact that the bentonite microstructure evolutions during saturation as introduced before was not taken into consideration. However, overall, the modified KC equation and new relative permeability can predict the hydraulic conductivities of unsaturated bentonites.


6
Conclusion
Both experimental observations and prediction modification were carried out in this study. A new multi-ring was used with the instantaneous profiling method to obtain hydraulic conductivity and basal spacing under confined wetting. Conclusions of this study includes the followings:
1) Hydraulic conductivities of unsaturated bentonites exhibit “Ո” shapes with the increase of volumetric water content.
2) Basal spacings of bentonites increase dramatically with the increase of wetting time in beginning wetting durations, and then enter into stable values. Basal spacing rises as degree of saturation grows.
3) A dual pore system was introduced as: i) micro pore (inter-layer pore); and ii) macro pore (pores excluding inter-layer pore). By the discussion of water flow mechanism in the pores of bentonite, it was assumed that water flows in the macro pore. A modified KC equation was proposed by changing porosity and tortuosity of saturated total pore to porosity and tortuosity of saturated macro pore in traditional Kozeny-Carmen (KC) eq. A new relative permeability was also raised to calculate hydraulic conductivity of unsaturated bentonite. Modified KC and new relative permeability can generally predict hydraulic conductivity under confined wetting well.


CRediT authorship contribution statement

Kunlin Ruan: Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Funding acquisition, Investigation, Methodology, Validation, Visualization, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing. Hideo Komine: Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Investigation, Methodology. Daichi Ito: Investigation, Methodology. Kentaro Miyoshi: Methodology. Takahiro Gotoh: Methodology.
Text.77:
1
Introduction
As the response to the Cenozoic ongoing collision between the Indian and Eurasian plates, the eastern Tibet is marked by eastward propagation and numerous blocks bounded by large-scale active left-lateral faults, such as Xianshuihe, Kunlun, and Haiyuan faults (Armijo et al., 1986; Harrison et al., 1992; Tapponnier and Molnar, 1977) (Fig. 1
). However, the deformation mechanism of eastern Tibet is a hot debate. The rigid block model predicts that the deformation of the plateau has dominantly been accommodated by the block boundary faults (e.g., Avouac et al., 1993; Tapponnier and Molnar, 1977), whereas the continuous model proposes that the strain is partitioned throughout the entire plateau (e.g., England et al., 1988; England and Molnar, 1997; Houseman and England, 1993). The major controversy of these two end-member models has focused on whether the role of intra-block faults in the deformation distribution of the plateau is major (e.g., Mériaux et al., 2004) or limited (e.g., Cowgill et al., 2009; Gold et al., 2011). Although decades of geodetic data reveal distributed deformation all over the plateau and seem to sustain the continuous model (Zhang et al., 2004), the stations are too sparse to well resolve the strain rate on an individual fault. Moreover, the geodetic rate only represents an inter-seismic present-day rate of far-field strain accumulation on an active fault (Donnellan et al., 1993). Emerging evidence of the considerable discrepancy of the fault slip rates over geological and decadal scales (e.g., Chevalier et al., 2005; Mohadjer et al., 2017) reflects that the late Quaternary activities of intra-block faults in the Tibetan Plateau are crucial to getting deeper insights into how continental crust deforms in response to outward motion of the plateau.
Eastern Tibet is characterized by clockwise rotation of the Qiangtang-Chuandian block around the eastern Himalayan syntaxis illustrated by the GPS velocity field (Fig. 1). The ongoing Sichuan-Tibet Railway traverses the Qiangtang-Chuandian block and crosses several intra-block faults (Fig. 1). These intra-block faults are also active in the late Quaternary and have undergone numerous strong earthquakes, such as the 1948 M 7.3 earthquake on the Litang fault and the 1870 M 7½ earthquake on the Batang fault (Fig. 1). The northern LCJF, one of the important intra-block faults west of Jinsha River (Fig. 1), runs across the railway south of Changdu City. But its detailed geometry and late Quaternary activity are absent. Knowing whether the northern LCJF has the seismic potential similar to large earthquakes on the Batang and Litang faults is vital to this major engineering design (e.g., Ho et al., 2020; Kanaori, 2000; McCalpin, 2009; Tiwari et al., 2021) and the understanding of the kinematic pattern of eastern Tibet. Therefore, it is imperative to study the late Quaternary activity of the northern LCJF and assess surface faulting hazards via a geological technique.
In this study, we use the interpretation of high-resolution satellite imagery, field observations, and shallow geophysical exploration to determine the geometry of the northern LCJF. Furthermore, we combine optically stimulated luminescence (OSL), radiocarbon, and terrestrial cosmogenic nuclides (TCN) exposure dating methods, and an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) survey of displaced landforms to constrain the fault slip rates in the late Quaternary. Finally, we explore the role of the LCJF in strain partitioning of eastern Tibet and assess the seismic hazards on the Sichuan-Tibet Railway. This work will provide essential quantitative data for seismic hazard assessment on the railway and enhance understanding of the Tibetan Plateau's deformation mechanism.


2
Regional tectonics and LCJF zone
Eastern Tibet is characterized by interior material eastward movement of the plateau and several blocks separated by large-scale strike-slip fault zones (Fig. 1). Among these blocks, the Qiangtang-Chuandian block was proposed as the most outward extrusion of the plateau's material. Its influence has even reached southeast Tibet and SE Asia (Clark and Royden, 2000; Tapponnier et al., 1982; Wang and Burchfiel, 2000). This block is primarily expressed by distributed faults and localized low-velocity zones in the mid-lower crust (e.g., Bai et al., 2010; Oskin, 2012; Royden et al., 1997). The northern and southern boundaries of the Qiangtang-Chuandian block are left-lateral Ganzi-Xianshuihe and right-lateral Jiali fault systems marked by strong shear structures in the Cenozoic (Fig. 1) (Allen et al., 1991; Bai et al., 2021; Bai et al., 2018; Chevalier et al., 2017; Wang and Burchfiel, 2000).
The Ganzi-Xianshuihe fault zone defines the northern boundary of the Qingtang-Chuandian block (Fig. 1). It is seismically active and has undergone over ten large earthquakes (M ≥ ~7) in the historical record (Bai et al., 2018; Wang and Burchfiel, 2000). For instance, the 1896 M 7 earthquake ruptured the Ganzi fault with a late Quaternary slip rate of 6–8 mm/yr (Chevalier et al., 2017), and the 2010 Yushu earthquake (Mw 6.9) produced a ~ 50 km long surface rupture zone (Chen et al., 2010) along the northern branch of Ganzi fault zone with a late Quaternary rate of ~4.1 mm/yr (Li et al., 2019) (Fig. 1). The Xianshuihe fault with a left-slip rate of ~10 mm/yr during late Quaternary (Bai et al., 2021; Bai et al., 2018) has been ruptured by a series of large earthquakes, such as the 1973 Luhuo earthquake (Ms 7.6), with a surface rupture of ~90 km long (Deng and Zhang, 1984), and 1955 Zheduotang quake with the re-evaluated magnitude of Mw 7.0 and a ~ 43 km-long surface rupture (Yan et al., 2020) (Fig. 1). The Jiali-Red River fault zone defines the southern boundary of the Qiangtang-Chuandian block. The Jiali fault is active in the Holocene via paleoseismic trenching (Wang et al., 2020) and has a dextral rate of ~3–4 mm/yr by the geodetic study of Zhang et al. (2021).
The LCJF west of Jinsha River is poorly investigated due to a deep incision. The regional geological investigations in the end of last century indicated that the fault zone consists of breccia, mylonite, and Oriented minerals (Ma, 1992). The dip angle of the fault is generally ~70°-80°, and striation data show a dominant lateral motion with a reverse component. Recent preliminary field observations for some engineering projects showed displaced Quaternary alluvial gravel in fault exposures. They suggested that the southern LCJF might have undergone strong activities in the Quaternary (Rongjun Zhou, 2020, personal communication). But the detailed geometry and slip rate of this fault remains unknown.
The entire LCJF zone underwent a low seismic activity. No large earthquake bigger than 7.0 has occurred since 1900 CE (Huang et al., 1994) (Fig. 1). The bigger earthquakes in the north part are the 1971 M 6.5 earthquake and the 1951 M 6.0 earthquake. The other two strong earthquakes along its southern part are the 1920 M 6 and 2013 M 6.1 Zuogong earthquakes. In addition, moderate earthquakes with magnitudes <6.0 occur occasionally. The focal mechanism of the 2013 earthquake indicates normal faulting with a left-lateral component (Fig. 1).
The northern LCJF primarily runs along the Lancangjing River (Fig. 1). Strong downcutting in the high-relief topography has removed the displaced landforms along the fault trace. However, east of Jitang Town, Changdu City, high-resolution satellite imagery reveals a clear faulted landform (Fig. 2
). The northern LCJF trends NW and consists primarily of two branches: the BLF in the north and YYF in the south (Fig. 2). The two branches probably merged eastwards onto the LCJF. This study focuses on these two fault branches and analyzes their activities in the late Quaternary.
The YYF locates on the upper reach of the flat Yu Qu (“Qu” means “river” in Chinese) basin (Fig. 2). The Changdu Bamda airport, known as the second-highest airport globally with an elevation of 4334 m above sea level in eastern Tibet, situates in this basin. No river terrace is developed along the braided Yu Qu due to little downcutting, whereas alluvial fans are generally distributed at the intersections of Yu Qu and its tributaries (Fig. 2). The BLF runs along the southern piedmont of Se Qu, one important tributary to the Lancangjiang River (Fig. 2). Numerous streams, such as Gongduoxiong (GDX) Qu, cut the mountains in the southwest and flow into the Se Qu. At least five terraces are well developed along the Se Qu, whereas only one terrace forms along these narrow streams.


3
Methodology

3.1
Survey of displaced landforms
Along the YYF, the fault cuts through the slope and alluvial fan. No terrace is developed along the stream channel. While along the BLF, terraces are well preserved along the main river. Strath terraces and fault scarps at each site can be identified and mapped in the field aided by Google Earth imagery. Terrace surfaces of different ages were designated numerically, with numbers increasing with age, such that the T0 surface represents the floodplain, with subsequent numbers (T1 through T4) indicating progressively older terrace surfaces. Therefore, numerous displaced alluvial fans and terraces can be used to reconstruct the fault offset.
In order to measure the fault offset, we adopt two techniques to survey the displaced landforms. For the sites with less vegetation, we introduced the DJI Phantom 4 RTK drone and photogrammetry with a centimeter-level accuracy to survey the areas of offset markers. The resolution (generally ~1–2 cm) of the UAV digital elevation model (DEM) is high enough to recognize microrelief features related to linear markers such as terrace riser and channel. For the sites with dense trees, the photogrammetry is not appliable. We conduct the survey of offset landforms by the Trimble R10 Real-Time Kinematic (RTK) GPS with the accuracy of 2–3 cm horizontally and 10 cm vertically in the field.


3.2
Age determination
To constrain the age of offset landforms, we use the following three dating techniques in this study. At some sites, multiple approaches are used to crosscheck the age.
OSL samples were collected by stainless steel tubes of 5 cm in diameter and ~ 20 cm long. The sampling sites were first dug deep into over 30 cm to avoid the possible post-deposition bleaching. Once extracted, the tubes were sealed immediately using aluminum foil and tape to keep moisture and avoid daylight exposure. The samples were treated at the Luminescence Dating Laboratory at the Key Laboratory of Crustal Dynamics, MEMC. To obtain the concentration of radioisotopes for dose-rate determination, ~20 g of sediment was ground into a fine powder for instrumental neutron activation analysis. Following the procedures of Lu et al. (2007) and Wang et al. (2010), uranium and thorium contents were measured by ELEMENT Plasma Mass Spectrometer. The luminescence signals were tested using a Riso TL/OSL DA-20 reader. All OSL signals were measured using a photomultiplier tube (9235QB). The equivalent dose (De) measurements were determined on multiple aliquots using the Simplified Multiple Aliquot Regenerative-dose (SMAR) protocol. Growth curves were fitted by exponential trend curves. Aliquots with >5% recuperation were not involved in the age estimations.
Radiocarbon samples were collected by a knife and packed with aluminum foil in the field. These labeled samples were then placed in zip lock bags and delivered to the Beta Analytic lab for accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS) radiocarbon dating. The related treatment sequences can be found on the link (https://www.radiocarbon.cn/beta-AMS-lab/). The final results were calibrated using OxCal 4.4 based on IntCal 20 curve (Reimer et al., 2020).
TCN Samples were collected from fan surface cobbles for Be-10 dating. Whole cobbles were taken because boulders on the fan surfaces were absent. The location, geomorphic setting, size, shape, and weathering characteristics of each sample were recorded. The inclination from the sampling site to the surrounding horizon was measured to quantify topographic shielding, which in most sites was generally negligible. Cobble samples were crushed and sieved to obtain a fraction of 250–500 μm size. The chemical treatments followed the procedures of Le Dortz et al. (2011) and Owen et al. (2011). Chemical treatments of samples were done at the Preparation Lab for Cosmogenic Nuclides, MEMC. AMS measurements were made at the Xi'an Accelerator Mass Spectrometer Center at the Institute of Earth Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences.


3.3
Slip rate estimation
The vertical slip rate of a fault can be calculated by the ratio of vertical offset on the terrace tread and associated terrace age. The horizontal slip rate often relies on a displaced terrace riser. The horizontal offset is generally obtained based on a detailed survey of displaced landform. We adopted Gold et al. (2011)’s method that uses the projection for each riser crest on the fault trace to estimate the minimum and maximum displacements. For the offset fan, we reconstruct the original shape of the fan and the typical features to constrain the fault offset. The reported offset includes the mean between the minimum and maximum values, with an uncertainty that is one-half the range.
Because fault slip rate estimates are also uncertain, we estimate slip rates and corresponding uncertainties by the Zechar and Frankel (2009)’s technique in which age, offset, and slip rate at each study site are treated and reported in the light of probability distribution. The slip rate is obtained by convolution via the probability distributions of offset and corresponding age. This approach has been applied to the estimation of well-constrained slip rates on numerous faults (e.g., Chevalier et al., 2017; Fletcher et al., 2011; Ren et al., 2013). Here, we introduce this approach to determine the fault slip rate and related uncertainty.


3.4
Audio-frequency magnetotelluric (AMT) exploration of active fault
In some sites, displaced landforms are clear, but the dip direction of the fault is hard to determine. In this study, we introduce the AMT method to detect the shallow structure of the fault zone. It can help us verify the location and slip sense of the fault. This technique is based on the distribution of electrical resistivity in the subsurface by relating simultaneous measurements of the naturally occurring fluctuations of the electric and magnetic fields ranging roughly from 1 Hz to 10 kHz at the surface (Chave and Jones, 2012; Nabighian, 1993). It has been widely used in shallow structure exploration of sediments and faults (e.g., Blake et al., 2016; Seki et al., 2021; Uhm et al., 2021).
In our field measurements, the data were collected at roughly 10–30 m intervals along the profile perpendicular to the fault trace. Only the horizontal electrical (Ex, Ey) and magnetic (Hx, Hy) fields were recorded due to field topography. The AMT data were measured using the Stratagem EH4 system manufactured by Geometrics, recording in a frequency range from 10 to 105 Hz. The data acquisition duration was about 20–30 min at each site. We used the software package IMAGEM (EH4) for data processing (Simpson and Bahr, 2005). Most of our data were high-quality with small error bars and low scattering, while few stations recorded poor data due to strong ambient and electromagnetic noise. Finally, two-dimensional inversion was carried out using the software of IMAGEM.



4
Late Quaternary activity of the YYF

4.1
Fault geometry
The WNW-trending YYF extends from Xieba Village in the east through Kongxie Village, Yangda Village, and Guoqing Town to Dumula Village and the upper reach of Wei Qu (Fig. 2). West of Wei Qu, the relatively clear fault trace becomes obscure. So, we infer that the YYF is ~80 ± 2 km long from Xieba Village in the east to Dumala Village in the west. The ~1–1.5 km wide stepover might be the boundary between the YYF and the fault farther west of Wei Qu (Fig. 2).
The eastern segment of the YYF extends along the Xue Qu and is expressed by shutter ridges, ly fault springs, and linear throughs (Fig. 3a, b). Especially west of Kongxie Village, the fault is composed of clear right-stepping surface ruptures and left-laterally displaced features (Fig. 3c). The rupture zone is bare or sparsely vegetated. In addition, clear free faces are developed along the fault trace (Fig. 3d). These features indicate that the last event on the YYF occurred not long ago.
In the west segment, the fault locates the piedmont on the northern side of Wei Qu and is marked by linear fault troughs on the slope and laterally offset gullies (Fig. 4a,c). The fault zone consists of sag ponds and fault scarps on the frontal fan (Fig. 4a,b). The sites of sag ponds are more vegetated and darker in the image due to local ponding providing good conditions for vegetation. At gully g3, two fans are well developed at its outlet (Fig. 4a). The older fan 2 is displaced left-laterally by the YYF and blocks gully g1-g2 forming typical shutter ridges. Based on the g3 channel, we can restore the left-lateral slip of ~400 m (Fig. 4a). To the east of g1, the fault comprises at least three linear troughs on the slope (Fig. 4a).
The central YYF crosses a series of alluvial fans (Fig. 2) and produces a distinct linear fault trace (Fig. 5
). West of Quoqing Town, a small pull-apart basin is expressed by a small lake (Fig. 5a). East of Guoqing Town, the linear fault trace is prominent because of the totally different tone on the surface, especially around the Gang fan. A small wetland is probably a sag pond due to the left-laterally displaced fan west of Gang fan. East of Gang fan, the fault runs through the mountain slope, which is marked by offset gullies, fault throughs, and filled sag ponds (Fig. 5a). East of Yangda Village, the YYF is characterized by a north-facing scarp on the Yangda fan (Fig. 5b).
On the whole, the YYF is characterized by distinct linear features. We mapped the detailed fault traces (Fig. 2). The central fault cut the Gang and Yangda fans and generated a remarkable displaced landform (Fig. 5) suitable for studying the late Quaternary activity of the YYF.


4.2
Gang fan site (96.9402°E, 30.7128°N)
At the intersection of the Gang Qu and Yu Qu, the flat Gang fan is well developed (Figs. 2, 5a). The YYF runs across the middle part of the Gang fan and produces a linear north-facing scarp. The northern side of the YYF is relatively lower and is presently occupied by a local swamp (Fig. 5a). The gullies on the southern side of the fault (Fig. 6b,c) suggest that the swamp could have been overflowed during wet seasons. The fault is clearly expressed by the boundary of the alluvial fan and swamp (Figs. 6a, 7a). Detailed mapping of the YYF indicates that the fault trace consists of right- and left-stepping surface ruptures (Fig. 6c). Interestingly, some cobbles on the fan surface are vertically oriented along the fault strike (Fig. 7b). In the surface rupture zone, we can see some sub-circular sand units on the extensional fissures. In addition, some ground cracks are still readily recognized and are sub-parallel to the main fault trace (Fig. 7c), implying that the most recent event on the YYF did not take place long ago.
Satellite imagery reveals that the well-preserved shape of Gang fan and the Gang Qu channel provide ideal piercing lines to reconstruct the horizontal displacement of the YYF (Fig. 5a). We restore the topographic cross-sections of the entire fan and channel features on both sides of the fault by back-slipping one side of the features relative to the other. To reduce the effect of the swamp, we conducted the UAV survey of the offset Gang fan in the winter (Fig. 6a).
Our interpretation of high-resolution UAV data reveals that the deformation zone on the YYF is generally <50 m. So, we produce the north and south profiles on both sides of the fault at 30 m distance from the central fault line to determine (Fig. 6b). These two topographic cross-sections are extracted to compare the shape of the Gang fan (Figs. 6b, 8a). The topographic cross-sections of the entire fan are restored at ~33 ± 5 m (Fig. 8b), and the reconstruction of Gang Qu channel yields a left-lateral offset of ~47 ± 4 m (Fig. 8c). We thus propose that the horizontal displacement on the Gang fan is ~33–47 m.
In order to determine the age of the Gang fan, we opened an exposure at the left bank of the Gang Qu on the northern side of the YYF (Fig. 6c). The strata in this exposure include four units (Fig. 8d). The uppermost layer (U1) is turf with plenty of grassroots related to the present-day swamp. Below U1 is a blackish peat layer (U2) ~75 cm thick, associated with the swamp. The lower parts are alluvial sediments of the Gang fan and consist of yellowish flood plain sand with pebbles (U3) and channel facies alluvial gravel (U4) (Fig. 8d), probably presenting the alluvial process of the fan. An OSL sample (YQO3) from an interbed sand lens in the upper part of U4 yields the age of 34.62 ± 4.17 ka, and another OSL sample (YQO4) from the bottom of U3 is dated to be 15.58 ± 1.83 ka (Fig. 8d, Table 1
). The organic sediment (YQC3) from the bottom of U2 is dated to be 12,720–12,660 cal BP, whereas another organic sediment sample (YQC2) from the same layer of sample YQO4 yields an age of 15,920–15,650 cal BP (Fig. 8d, Table 2
), in accordance with sample YQO4. The consistent crosscheck and the good stratigraphic order of these dates demonstrated that our ages are reliable. Because the fan was abandoned after the deposition of U4 and subsequently covered by U3, the age of Gang fan predates U3 and postdates U4 (Fig. 8e). So, the Gang fan formed at ~15.92–34.62 ka. Given that the samples (YQC2 and YQO4) from U3 are closer to the top of alluvial gravel (U4) than sample YQO3, we infer that the age of the Gang fan might be closer to ~15.92 ka.
Four TCN samples were also taken at the Gang fan site (Fig. 6c). Among them, three cobble samples (YQB1-YQB3) were collected from the fan surface. These sampling sites avoid eroded areas such as gully valleys and swampy zone to reduce the effect of possible erosion and subsequent cover. One sample (YQB4) was taken from the active streambed of the Gang Qu to estimate the inherited component (Fig. 6c), as illustrated by Brown et al. (1998). Sample YQB4 yields a high 10Be concentration for the active channel (Table 3
), indicating that the inherited component for the flat and gentle fan like Gang fan may not be ignorable.
Given that the pre-depositional history of the cobbles from the present streambed is comparable to that of the cobbles taken from the abandoned Gang fan surface during aggradation periods, we propose that the inherited components from the streambed and fan surface might be similar, as described by Le Dortz et al. (2011). We subtract the inherited component of the streambed from the 10Be concentration of the samples on the Gang fan to estimate their exposure ages. Our final dating results indicate that samples YQB1 and YQB3 are apparently younger than sample YQB2 (Table 3).
Because the slope wash from the upper reach of Gang Qu will continue to erode the fan surface after the fan formation, this process will make the north side of the YYF more eroded. This may be the reason that sample YQB1 is obviously younger than others (Fig. 6c). But samples YQB2 and YQB3 lie south of the YYF, where the flow from the upper reach would be blocked by the fault scarp. The south side of the fault would be protected from the slope wash from the upper reach. With the distance away from the scarp, the slope wash will be stronger (Fig. 6c). Given that sample YQB3 is close to Gang Qu, and a big gully (Fig. 6c), the site of sample YQB3 is more readily to be eroded than that of sample YQB2. This may address why sample YQB1 is a little younger than sample YQB2. So the result of sample YQB2 (18,390 ± 1642 yrs) might represent the age of the Gang fan (Table 3), in line with the inference from the exposure in Fig. 8d. Therefore, we propose that the Gang fan probably formed at ~18.39 ± 1.64 ka.
It is to note that the northern and southern sides of the YYF have different deposits (Fig. 7). Its southern side is exposed by alluvial gravel, but the alluvial gravel on its northern side is mantled by alluvial sand and subsequent marsh deposits (Fig. 8d). This should be related to the vertical activity of the YYF. When the fan was abandoned and uplifted above the water level, the displacement of the fault began to be preserved. The southern side of the YYF was uplifted, whereas its northern side was relatively subsided. The local lowland on the northern side would start to pond and deposit the peat, and alluvial sand on the south side would be removed by slope wash (Fig. 8e). Thus, the vertical displacement of the YYF on the Gang fan might be 115 ± 10 cm constrained by the thickness of the units above U4, and the thickness of U3 in Fig. 8d. Given the possible erosion on the south side of the fault, this vertical displacement should be the minimum value.


4.3
Yangda fan site (97.0456°E, 30.6871°N)
East of Yangda Village, the YYF crosses the Yangda fan and generates a WNW-trending linear strike-slip fault trace (Fig. 5b). Similar to the features at the Gang fan site, the fault trace is marked by the main scarp accompanied by a fold on the southern side of the fault (Fig. 9
). The ground cracks on the axis of the fold can be identified in the field.
On the east side of the new road from the photovoltaic power station to Yangda Village, a fault exposure indicates that the fan deposits consist of six units near the fold axis (Figs. 5b, 9). The bottom part (U6) is brown alluvial gravel with horizontal bedding. U5 is composed by brown coarse-fine sand with gravel clasts and horizontal bedding. The lower part of the exposure (U5-U6) represents the deposits of the Yangda fan. U4 is the poorly sorted gravels probably attributed to post-faulting rapid colluvium from alluvial gravels. U3 is the yellowish-green silt that might be related to a post-faulting ponding. U2 is a poorly bedded, grayish gravel layer and is possibly associated with a flood event. The top part (U1) is the widespread turf. An OSL sample (YQO5) from the lower U5 yields an age of 30.69 ± 6.33 ka, and another OSL sample (YQO6) from the central part of U3 is dated to be 7.89 ± 1.69 ka (Fig. 9c, Table 1). The fault planes are characterized by oriented clasts (Fig. 9b). The fault zone is composed of several faults (f1-f3) and forms a small graben. These faults obviously displaced U3 (Fig. 9b), indicating that YYF underwent surface faulting after ~7.8 ka.



5
Late Quaternary activity of the BLF

5.1
Fault geometry
The NNW-striking BLF crosses the area with high relief and deep valleys. It goes through the western slope of the Se Qu from east of Xieba Village through Jitang Town and merges with the YYF eastwards onto the LCJF (Fig. 2). Farther north of Lezhu bend and southeast of Lezhu bend, the fault is characterized by linear fault troughs (Fig. 10
). It is hard to identify the continuous fault trace similar to the YYF.
The BLF crosses numerous northeast-trending ephemeral streams that drain into the Se Qu. Although laterally offset landforms along the BLF become inconspicuous due to strong downcutting of these streams (Fig. 2), the scarps on bedrock interfluves define the fault trace. Terraces are not well developed in these gullies, and only terrace T1 is available in most channels. Our field investigations indicate that offset landforms in the Gongduoxiong (GDX) Qu and at the Lezhu bend (Fig. 2) are well developed, offering datable displacement markers for late Quaternary slip rate of the BLF.


5.2
GDX site (97.3301°E, 30.7098°N)
The GDX Qu is a tributary to the Se Qu west of Jitang Town (Fig. 2). Terrace T1 is preserved only on the left bank and is presently occupied by farmlands (Fig. 11a). The flat flood plain (T0) on the left bank is wider than that on the right bank. Additionally, talus fans are developed on the right bank because of its steeper slope.
The BLF cuts the GDX Qu and produces distinct displaced landforms (Fig. 11). On the right bank, the fault cuts a talus fan and generates a pronounced scarp on the fan surface (Fig. 12a). On the left bank, the fault is marked by apparent scarps on T0 and T1 (Fig. 11a, c). Moreover, the T1/T0 riser is sinistrally offset by the fault (Fig. 11a).
We employ RTK to survey the offset landforms at the GDX site because of its dense trees and high-relief topography. The topographic profile on T0 yields a vertical offset of 1.1 ± 0.2 m, and that on T1 shows its vertical displacement of 2.6 ± 0.3 m (Fig. 11b). Due to human terracing, the T1/T0 riser was too modified to determine the accurate locus of the riser. Here we use the middle line of the T1/T0 riser to estimate the horizontal offset of ~4 ± 1 m (Fig. 11a).
In order to determine the ages of T1 and T0, we dug two pits at their frontal risers. The T0 deposits consist of 4 units (Fig. 12b). The bottom alluvial gravel (U4) and overlying alluvial sand (U3) constitute the alluvial sediments of the GDX Qu and are covered by subsequent grayish loess (U2) and cultivated soil (U1). A charcoal sample (SQC14) from the lower U1 yields an age of 285–0 cal BP, and two charcoal samples (SQC13 and SQC11) from the middle and lower parts of U2 were dated to be 540–505 cal BP and 655–535 cal BP (Fig. 12b, Table 2), respectively. The age of the lower part of U2 is 660–645 cal BP based on the radiocarbon dating of sample SQC10. An OSL sample (SQO13) collected from the lower part of U2 yields an age of 0.64 ± 0.07 ka (Fig. 12b, Table 1), consistent with the radiocarbon ages. These dating results are in good stratigraphic order and demonstrate that T0 formed probably at ~0.66 ka.
The T1 deposits have similar features to T0 (Fig. 12c). The lower two layers (U4 and U3) are alluvium of GDX Qu, and the upper two layers (U2 and U1) are subsequent loess and cultivated layer. An organic sample (SQC8) from the bottom of U2 yields an age of 1390–1300 cal BP, and another radiocarbon sample (SQC9) from the middle of U3 is estimated to be 1410–1310 cal BP (Fig. 12b, Table 2). Thus, we propose that the age of terrace T1 is ~1.4 ka.
The exposure of the talus fan on the right bank of GDX Qu uncovers the fault plane (Fig. 12a). The fault displaced the interlayer (U2) of sand with gravel and is characterized by orientated clasts. The locus of the fault plane is consistent with the scarp on the talus fan (Fig. 12a), suggesting that the faulting occurred after the formation of the talus fan.


5.3
Lezhu site (97.2404°E, 30.8429°N)
At the Lezhu bend ~15 km NW of Jitang Town, the northeast-trending Se Qu turns northwest and forms the big Lezhu bend (Figs. 2, 10). Four terraces are developed on the right bank of the Se Qu, and only two narrow terrace treads are preserved due to lateral erosion on its left bank (Fig. 13b).
The BLF crosses the southwest shoulder of the Se Qu and crosses the river. Several gullies from the slope flow into the Se Qu. On the right bank, the BLF cuts the interfluves and generates shutter ridges (Figs. 13b, 14a). At the convex bank of the river bend, terraces T3 and T4 are well preserved, and several alluvial fans from the gullies on the right slope cover these terraces (Fig. 13b). The BLF displaced terraces T3 and T4 and the overlying alluvial fan and formed distinct linear scarps (Figs. 13b, 14). Due to the cover of the subsequent fan, the scarp height decreases toward the river channel (Fig. 14a). In addition, the T4/T3 riser is sinistrally and vertically offset by the fault (Fig. 14b). High-resolution topographic data show that the scarps on T4 and T3 are ~9.8 ± 0.3 m and ~ 5.8 ± 0.4 m, respectively (Fig. 14c). The high-resolution satellite image indicates that the T4/T3 riser was left-laterally displaced by ~12 ± 2 m (Fig. 13c). It is to note that terrace T3 close to the BLF on the southern side of the fault is poorly preserved due to narrow tread and bank sloughing.
In order to date terrace T4, we dug a pit on the tread (Fig. 14b). The pit reveals a typical alluvial sedimentary sequence. Its upper part is composed of yellowish alluvial sand, and its lower part consists of alluvial gravel with the sand lens. An OSL sample (LZO1) from the uppermost lens of alluvial gravel yields an age of 7.94 ± 0.99 ka (Fig. 14b, Table 1). We did not take any dating sample from the alluvial sand layer. Because the upper sand is only ~15–20 cm thick, it is not appliable for OSL dating. The abundant roots make it unsuitable for radiocarbon dating. Terrace T3 consists of alluvial gravel, which makes us hard to seek the datable material. Our dating result of terrace T4 is consistent with the regional terrace sequence of Lancangjiang River (Wei, 2016). Based on the above statement, we propose that our dating result could represent the minimum age of terrace T4.
To determine the existence and dip direction of the BLF, two AMT sections (WT1 and WT2) were conducted across the possible fault trace. Section WT1 was along a ridge southeast of the Lezhu bend, and section WT2 was on the flood plain of the left bank (Fig. 13b). Both sections reveal that the BLF fault at the surface is characterized by a similar electrical structure and a sharp contrast of electrical resistivity at depth (Fig. 15
). The similar surface lithology is consistent with the geological features (Fig. 2). The deep structures discover that there is a fault with a SW dip direction, coinciding with the downward projection of the surface trace of the BLF determined by displaced landforms (Fig. 13b) and the dip direction of fault exposure at the GDX site (Fig. 12a).



6
Discussion

6.1
Slip rate of the northern LCJF and associated seismic potential
The northern LCJF consists of two branches: YYF and BLF. The YYF is primarily a left-lateral strike-slip fault with a minor reverse component, whereas the BLF undergoes a left-lateral and reverse motion. We employed the measured offsets and marker ages to determine the fault slip rate. At the Gang fan site, the fan age (~18.39 ± 1.64 ka) and horizontal fault displacement (33–47 m) yield a sinistral slip rate of ~2.2 + 0.6/−0.5 mm/yr for the YYF. Additionally, the vertical displacement of the fan is ~1.15 ± 0.1 m, revealing a vertical slip rate of ~0.1 + 0.0/−0.0 mm/yr for the YYF.
For the BLF, we conducted two sites for slip rate estimation. At the GDX site, the ~0.66 ka flood plain (T0) was vertically displaced by ~1.1 ± 0.2 m, indicating a vertical rate of ~1.7 ± 0.2 mm/yr. The ~1.4 ka terrace T1 and its vertical offset of ~2.6 ± 0.3 m yield a vertical rate of ~1.9 ± 0.3 mm/yr. Meanwhile, the left-lateral offset on the T1/T0 riser is 4 ± 1 m. Considering that the GDX Qu has limited flux, we use the age (~1.4 ka) of terrace T1 as the riser age to calculate a horizontal slip rate of ~2.9 + 0.8/−0.7 mm/yr. At the Lezhu site, terrace T4 was dated to be ~7.94 ± 0.99 ka. The ~9.8 ± 0.3 m scarp on terrace T4 yields a vertical slip rate of ~1.2 + 0.4/−0.2 mm/yr. If we assign the age of terrace T4 to the T4/T3 riser, the left-lateral slip (12 ± 2 m) on the T4/T3 riser will generate a horizontal slip rate of ~1.5 + 0.6/−0.4 mm/yr for the BLF. Given that the T4/T3 riser should be younger than terrace T4, and the offset on the T4/T3 riser is smaller than the true offset due to lateral erosion of the riser on the northern side of the BLF, this horizontal rate should be a minimum value.
Of particular note is a big difference in the horizontal slip rate at the two sites for the BLF. The rate at the GDX site nearly doubles that at the Lezhu site. Two reasons may address this difference. Firstly, large earthquakes on the BLF might fit a cluster model rather than a quasi-periodic model. The T1 age (~1.4 ka) is within the last active period where the BLF will have a higher slip rate, whereas the age of ~7.9 ka includes multiple active and quiescent cycles, as illustrated on other faults via morphotectonic and paleoseismological studies (e.g., Benedetti et al., 2013; Martín-Banda et al., 2021). The rate at the Lezhu site may represent a long-term slip rate on the BLF, and the rate at the GDX site is a short-term rate. Secondly, the short elapsed time since the last event may increase the short-term rate. The scarp on T0 indicates that the last faulting on the BLF occurred after ~0.66 ka. Considering the ~1.4 ka age of terrace T1, the younger age of the last event will add the rate as the general method of slip rate estimation. If we subtract the scarp height of T0 at the GDX site from vertical offsets on T1 at the GDX site and T4 at the Lezhu site, then the long-term vertical slip rate will be estimated to be ~1.2 + 0.4/−0.2 mm/yr for the BLF. Similarly, its long-term horizontal rate can be calculated at ~1.2 + 0.5/−0.3 mm/yr. These new estimates are a little slower than those by the general approach. Thus, these two reasons might together have increased the estimated slip rates. We propose that these new rate estimates might represent the long-term rate of the BLF.
The northern LCJF zone comprises the NWW-striking YYF and NW-striking BLF that merged eastwards onto one main fault trace (Fig. 2). Generally, the BLF strikes N40°W, and the YYF strikes N75°W, whereas the BCJF has a strike direction of N55°W. At the triple junction of these faults, we assume a balance of slip rate vectors (Fig. 16
). The YYF is a left-lateral strike-slip fault with a horizontal rate of ~2.2 + 0.6/−0.5 mm/yr and a negligible vertical rate of ~0.1 mm/yr. The BLF undergoes an oblique motion with a sinistral rate of ~1.2 + 0.5/−0.3 mm/yr and a vertical rate of ~1.2 + 0.4/−0.2 mm/yr. Vector analysis of the slip rates on the YYF and BLF indicates that the northern LCJF zone has accommodated a primarily left-lateral slip of ~3.5 + 1.1/−0.8 mm/yr with an NNE-vergent reverse component of ~1.6 + 0.4/−0.3 mm/yr (Fig. 16).
The projected Sichuan-Tibetan railway crosses the Holocene YYF and BLF (Fig. 2). Thus, the seismic hazard on the railway might sustain from large earthquakes on these two faults should be taken into account. The distinct surface rupture of the YYF can be traced to be ~80 ± 2 km long. If this length is entirely ruptured in the next earthquake, the empirical relationships between quantitative parameters (surface rupture length, coseismic offset, and so on) and magnitude for a strike-slip earthquake (Cheng et al., 2020; Wells and Coppersmith, 1994) will yield a magnitude of Mw ~7.2–7.3 and a left-lateral coseismic offset of ~1.8–2.0 m for the YYF (Table 4
). Because the BLF locates in the area of deep downcutting, it is hard to map the fault length. Thus, the empirical relationship is not applicable to the estimation of coseismic offset displacement of large earthquakes on the BLF. It is to note that the T0 age at the GDX site is ~0.66 ka, which is too young to include one more seismic cycle. The T1 age approximately doubles the T0 age, and the scarp height on T1 is roughly two times that on T0, suggesting that the BLF might have undergone two events since the formation of terrace T1. Thus, we suggest that the scarp height (~1.1–1.3 m) may be the vertical coseismic slip of one event for the BLF, and its left-lateral coseismic offset is ~2.0 m, equivalent to the earthquake of Mw ~7.3 (Wells and Coppersmith, 1994) (Table 4).
The evident surface ruptures suggest that the last events on the YYF and BLF are not too old. A recent trench at the Gang fan and radiocarbon dating showed that the last earthquake ruptured this YYF at ~1270 ± 30 cal BP (Rongjun Zhou, 2020, personal communication). The T0 age at the GDX site shows that the last fault event on the BLF occurred after ~0.66 ka. The accurate age of the most recent event on the BLF needs future trenching work to determine. In addition, because the record of strong earthquakes (M ≥ 6) in this area has been complete since 1915 CE (Huang et al., 1994), there is no record of the last events on the YYF and BLF. But these two faults have the potential of earthquakes of Mw 7.2–7.3. Therefore, more attention should be paid to the seismic hazard on the northern LCJF.


6.2
Tectonic implications of the LCJF zone
As mentioned above, several active faults are distributed within the Qiangtang-Chuandian block. The NW-striking Litang fault is a dominantly left-lateral strike-slip fault with a late Quaternary left-slip rate of ~1–4 mm/yr (Chevalier et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2005), and the NE-trending Batang fault within the block undergoes a dextral rate of ~2.0–2.7 mm/yr in late Quaternary (Zhou et al., 2005) (Fig. 1). Another NE-striking Lijiang fault undertakes a sinistral motion with a slip rate of ~3.8 ± 0.7 mm/yr in the Holocene (Fig. 1) (Xu et al., 2003). The Jiali fault as the southern boundary of the block has a dextral rate of ~3–4 mm/yr via geodetic analysis of Zhang et al. (2021). Our results reflect that the northern LCJF is also primarily sinistral and has accommodated a strike-slip rate of ~3.5 + 1.1/−0.8 mm/yr and a vertical rate of ~1.6 + 0.4/−0.3 mm/yr in the late Quaternary, comparable to the Litang fault and other major faults in the Qiangtang-Chuandian block. Therefore, the LCJF zone should take an important role in accommodating the eastward motion of eastern Tibet. However, the main LCJF does not reveal a clear fault trace on the satellite imagery. We propose that the following two reasons might account for its faint fault trace. (1) The LCJF runs along the upper Lancangjiang River, where it is characterized by a high elevation of over 4000 m and high relief. Extensive alluvium, glaciation, and slope processes may erode or cover the fault trace. (2) The most recent surface-rupturing earthquake on the LCJF occurred so long ago that the subsequent surface processes and good vegetation could subdue and obscure the surface ruptures.
As described above, the deformation of eastern Tibet does not focus on the block boundary faults. A series of intra-block faults, such as the LCJF, Litang, Batang, and Lijiang faults, have absorbed an essential portion of regional tectonic deformations. Neither the rigid block model nor the continuous model is applicable to the deformation mechanism of eastern Tibet. Thatcher (2007) proposed a sub-block model in which the distinction between these two models becomes obscure with the decrease of block size. Subsequent sub-block models and geodetic data have been constructed to resolve slip rates of major faults within the blocks of the Tibetan Plateau (e.g., Loveless and Meade, 2011; Ren et al., 2013). The role of the intra-block faults such as the LCJF can be illustrated in these models. Thus, the deformation mechanism of eastern Tibet probably conforms to the sub-block model.
An interesting finding is that the YYF displaced several bedrock units in the geological map (Fig. 2). At Langda and Kongxie Villages in the eastern YYF, the east boundary of Jurassic strata was sinistrally offset by ~11 km. Around Yangda Village, the NW-striking Paleogene strata were probably left-laterally displaced by ~10 km (Fig. 2). Our results show that the YYF has a late Quaternary left-lateral slip rate of ~2.2 + 0.6/−0.5 mm/yr. If we assume that the slip rate on the YYF keeps constant over time, then the ~10–11 km displacement suggests that the YYF formed at ~5.9–3.9 Ma, which may represent the initiation age of the LCJF.
In fact, several tectonic events occurred during this period. The Red River shear zone as the southern boundary of the Qiangtang-Chuandian block underwent a sinistral ductile shear at ~36–17 Ma (et al., Leloup et al., 1995) and was transformed into a dextral motion in late Miocene (~5 Ma) (Leloup et al., 1993; Schoenbohm et al., 2006; Wang et al., 2016). The modern pattern of strike-slip and normal faults has initiated during ~8–4 Ma and has accommodated clockwise rotation of crustal fragments around the eastern Himalayan syntaxis (King et al., 1997; Wang et al., 1998; Wang et al., 2016; Zhao et al., 2021). Exhumation history suggests that the onset of motion along the Litang fault occurred during ~7–5 Ma (Zhang et al., 2015). Most geochronological studies reveal that the Xianshuihe fault has been active since at least 12–10 Ma (e.g., Li and Zhang, 2013; Roger et al., 1995; Wang and Burchfiel, 2000) and propagated southward toward the Xiaojiang fault at ~5 Ma (Wang et al., 2012; Zhu et al., 2008). The superposition of these events suggests that significant regional tectonic changes occurred in eastern Tibet from mid-Miocene to late Miocene, associated with the establishment of the present-day strain pattern and the onset of crustal thickening. Therefore, the initiation of the LCJF is probably associated with the significant regional tectonic changes in eastern Tibet.



7
Conclusions
Based on the interpretation of high-resolution satellite imagery, field observations and AMT exploration, we first map the detailed trace of the northern LCJF zone. We also use high-precise topographic surveys and multiple numerical dating of displaced landforms to constrain the fault slip rates in the late Quaternary. The study has led to the following conclusions.

(1)
The northern LCJF zone consists of two branches: the NWW-trending YYF and NNW-striking BLF, which merged eastwards onto the main LCJF.


(2)
The YYF undergoes a dominantly left-lateral motion and has a sinistral slip rate of ~2.2 + 0.6/−0.5 mm/yr and a minor vertical rate of ~0.1 mm/yr. The BLF undergoes an oblique motion with a left-lateral rate of ~1.2 + 0.5/−0.3 mm/yr and a northeast-vergent reverse rate of ~1.2 + 0.4/−0.2 mm/yr.


(3)
The northern LCJF zone may accommodate a primarily left-lateral slip of ~3.5 + 1.1/−0.8 mm/yr with an NNE-vergent reverse component of ~1.6 + 0.4/−0.3 mm/yr.


(4)
The YYF and BLF across the Sichuan-Tibet Railway have a seismic potential of Mw ~7.2–7.3 that will produce ~1.8–2.0 m sinistral slip on the YYF, and ~ 2.0 m horizontal and ~ 1.1–1.3 m reverse slips on the BLF.


(5)
The LCJF has played an important role in strain partitioning of eastern Tibet. The formation of the LCJF took place at ~5.9–3.9 Ma and is related to the significant regional tectonic changes in east Tibet during the late Miocene





Data and resources
The earthquake catalog from the China Earthquake Networks Center is available at https://news.ceic.ac.cn/index.html?time=1626007765 (last accessed July 2021). Geologic data are from the public geological map (scale: 1:250,000) (http://www.ngac.org.cn/DataSpecial/geomap.html, last accessed June 2020). The satellite imageries are from the Google Earth (last accessed June 2021). Focal mechanism data are from the Global CMT Catalog (http://www.globalcmt.org) (last accessed July 2021). The satellite images are from open sources (Google Earth and Bing). The shapefile version of the YYF and BLF (WGS 84) in Fig. 2 can be downloaded in Supplementary material.

Junjie Ren: Conceptualization, Investigation, Writing – original draft. Xiwei Xu: Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Writing – review & editing. Yanwu Lv: Investigation, Methodology, Writing – review & editing. Qixin Wang: Visualization. An Li: Investigation, Data curation. Kang Li: Investigation, Data curation. Jinlai Zhu: Investigation. Juntao Cai: Writing – review & editing. Shao Liu: Investigation.
Text.86:
1
Introduction
Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS) is a recent development (last decade) of fiber optic technologies. DAS records acoustic waves, measuring the variations of Rayleigh backscattering of a laser pulse due to an axial strain of the fiber subjected to elastic vibrations (Fernández-Ruiz et al., 2020; Soga and Luo, 2018).
The methodology showed high potential in different applications. The most common application is probably for deep seismic explorations through Vertical Seismic Profiling (VSP) (Binder et al., 2020; Luo et al., 2021a; Titov et al., 2021; Wilson et al., 2021; Wu et al., 2017).
Seismic passive monitoring at the ground surface is a DAS application with an increasing range of usages in terms of operational conditions and scales. For example, DAS is applied in glaciated terrains to record microseismicity (Walter et al., 2020), as well as for seismological surveys when exploiting the measurements from underwater “dark fibers”, even if fiber optics exhibit higher sensitivity to S-waves than P-waves (Cheng et al., 2021; Lior et al., 2021). Other applications include the passive monitoring of volcanic earthquakes to infer the subsurface geological structures (Nishimura et al., 2021). In addition, passive acoustic acquisitions by means of fiber optics are effectively utilized for near-surface characterization of shear-wave velocity distributions (Dou et al., 2017; Luo et al., 2021b; Yuan et al., 2020).
An issue while using DAS for seismological surveys lies in the impossibility to retrieve the absolute ground displacement as inertial seismometers. The transfer function between ground vibration and fiber optic strain needs to be calibrated, as presented, e.g., by Lindsey et al. (2020). On the contrary, common applied geophysical surveys do not require the knowledge of the absolute ground displacement. This characteristic is in common with traditional geophones used for engineering geology characterizations, which record relative ground vibrations as voltage amplitudes.
The present work focuses on a pilot test in the context of a near-surface geophysical survey for a civil engineering application. We explore the possibility of using DAS for assessing ground elastic parameters in a construction site and we compare the results against traditional geophones receivers to assess the capabilities and the limitations of the DAS technology. The investigated construction site is characterized by an artificially stabilized ground.
Ground stabilization is an engineering application (Firoozi et al., 2017) that faces an increasing demand for exploiting areas with poor bearing capacity. Generally, it results in large financial savings compared to alternative methods. In many cases, ground stabilization is the only practical and economically viable possibility. Ground stabilization is very attractive also from a sustainability perspective regarding natural resources: firstly, it is possible to utilize local material that would otherwise become a landfill problem, and, secondly, it saves valuable raw materials in the form of natural gravel or crushed rock. Utilizing local materials also reduces the need for transport, thus, in turn, it contributes to decrease carbon dioxide emissions. In the case of surface stabilization, a binder is milled into a layer of ground material (usually the shallower decimeters). Once the binder is hardened, quality control is required and, in this respect, seismic measurements can be used as non-invasive and non-destructive testing (Donohue and Long, 2008; Lin et al., 2017).
Clearly, the applicability of the proposed methodology can be extended to monitor, for example, the long-term performances of roads and pavements (Wang et al., 2013). In these cases, the durability assessment should not be limited to what can be inferred from the surface – e.g., by means of the falling weight deflectometer (Coni et al., 2018; Coni et al., 2021) or core drilling (Miskiewicz et al., 2018) – but it should also include information deduced from inside the structure and via sensors located at exactly the same positions during the long-time monitoring (Kara De Maeijer et al., 2019).


2
Methodology
In the present research, the geophysical survey has been performed on top of a slab of stabilized ground, on an active construction site. We acquired acoustic data simultaneously by employing fiber optics and geophones as seismic receivers. The data acquisition has been extended outside the ground-stabilized area with the aim of having also reference measurements on the natural ground.

2.1
Experimental site
A construction site has been selected for conducting seismic surveys both via DAS and traditional geophones acquisitions. The experimental site is in the municipality of Lund (Sweden), where the European Spallation Source (ESS) facility was under construction (Fig. 1
). We focused the experimental test on an area where a slab of stabilized quaternary deposit was constructed through the mixing of natural material and lime cement. The stabilization procedure consists of alternating layers of natural material – excavated from adjacent areas – and lime cement. The improved mechanical properties are supposed to be obtained through mechanical compaction and artificially increased moisture content, necessary for facilitating the chemical reactions of the binder.
The natural material consists of a clayey-silty till deposit on top of a metamorphic crystalline bedrock. The Quaternary sediment is structured in layers with variable granulometric size distributions, where sand or silt-clay could be predominant. The depth to bedrock is around 10 m from the topographic surface and presents a top layer of weathered rock with a thickness of about 1.5 m. The geological information is collected from geotechnical drilling placed about 100 m south of the site and the topographic elevation at the drilling location is about 1 m higher than the investigated area.
The stabilized material covers an area of approximately 30 m by 20 m (Fig. 1) and is characterized by a thickness of about 1–1.5 m. The stabilized slab is covered by an artificial layer of about 0.5 m composed of nearby natural glacial sediments.
A geophysical profile of 90 m has been designed with the aim of investigating both the stabilized and the natural ground (Fig. 2
). Along the profile, a 30 cm deep trench has been excavated to install the fiber optic cable within the ground (Fig. 3
). This procedure is essential to ensure a good coupling between the cable and the surrounding material and is crucial for the transmission of acoustic energy from the ground to the cable. The fiber optic cable was placed in the ditch on a 2–3 cm bed of medium grain sand to avoid damage to the fiber. Damages might happen during the filling operation if the cable is in contact with large cobbles that might be present in the glacial material. The trench has been backfilled with an analogous thin layer of sand and the material previously excavated. The backfilled ditch has been compacted by the wheels of a heavy machine.
The geophones were placed on top of the installed fiber optic cable and they resulted to be precisely collocated as it is clear from the differential GNSS coordinates acquired along the fiber optic cable and at the geophone locations (Fig. 4A). By checking the elevation of the sensors (Fig. 4B), the position of the cable in the ground is about 0.30 m from the surface, across the entire profile. In addition, the higher elevation of the artificial ground compared to the natural condition is evident.


2.2
DAS system
DAS is a technology that enables real-time measurements of strain and acoustic vibrations along the entire length of a fiber optic cable. The instrument utilized in the experiment is the Carina Sensing System technology (Silixa ltd), which includes an iDAS v3 interrogator and an engineered (“constellation”) fiber.
The iDAS is a time domain, single-pulse, phase-based DAS instrument. It works by emitting a pulse of laser light into the optical fiber. As the pulse of light travels down the optical path, interacts within the fiber material resulting in backscattered light reflections. Variations in the amount of backscattered energy are determined by strain events within the fiber, which, in turn, are caused by localized acoustic energy (Lindsey et al., 2020). The time synchronization of the laser pulse allows the backscatter event to be accurately mapped to a fiber distance. The result is the continuous acoustic sampling along the entire length of the optical fiber with a frequency range from a few mHz to over 100 kHz.
The particular type of fiber (“constellation”) applied in the present work is developed by Silixa ltd in the attempt to increase the Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR). Engineered bright scatters are implemented along the fiber to enhance the amount of reflected light without introducing significant excess loss in the forward propagating scattered light.
The Carina Sensing System technology was selected for the experiment since the near-surface engineering application needed high spatial resolution to resolve the shallower layers of the ground, which is the main goal of the survey. The other possibly available technical solutions would have not provided the same SNR at such a short spatial resolution.


2.3
Traditional geophone-receivers' system
The traditional geophone-receivers' system consists of a Summit X One seismograph (DMT Group) with a maximum number of 98 4.5 Hz-geophones. Half of the receivers measure the vertical component (GEO-V), whereas the remaining sensors record the horizontal component aligned with the profile direction (GEO-H). The vertical and horizontal geophones are located as close as possible in order to obtain 2-component soundings.


2.4
Survey
The survey was performed on the 4th of September 2019. The source of active acoustic waves consisted of an accelerated weight drop (ESS100 Turbo) applied vertically on a metallic plate. This kind of source was necessary to transmit enough energy into the ground and limit the detrimental effects of environmental noise. Coherent noise sources mainly consisted of nearby active construction activities and of heavy vehicular traffic along Highway E22 (visible in the northwest corner of Fig. 1).
Along the investigated profile, we acquired three datasets by using three geophone layouts; each of them characterized by different locations and spacing intervals of the receivers. Contextually, the performed DAS acquisition always involved the entire profile with fixed spatial parameters. Table 1
 summarizes the parameters of the acquisition for both acoustic techniques (geophones and DAS).
Layout 1 and Layout 2 are characterized by 2 m inter-geophone spacing for a total length of 88 m (45 2-component receiver stations were deployed); this length was enough to cover both the portion of stabilized ground and the area of natural ground (Fig. 2). Layout 2 is analogue to Layout 1; the only difference is that Layout 2 is shifted by 1 m forward, along the profile. This provides the possibility to combine the two layouts and eventually obtain a profile with a 1 m resolution. The integration of Layout 1 and 2 has been done via stacking the seismograms with the same source location, after careful processing and adjustments of zero time. For comparison, also the fiber optic data have been stacked.
Layout 3 has a geophone spacing of 0.5 m for a profile length of 24 m (49 two-component receiver stations) and it is entirely located on the slab of stabilized material.
The DAS surveys are characterized by a characteristic Gauge length, which is the length of the fiber used to calculate the difference in the phase of the backscattered light. The recorded signal is thus averaged along a stretch of the fiber that is centered around the receiver position (Hartog, 2017). The spatial resolution is directly proportional to the Gauge length (Titov et al., 2021; Alfataierge et al., 2020) and, in the specific case under investigation, it equals 2 m.


2.5
Data processing and inversion
Following a quite standard procedure for the extraction of the dispersion curve from the seismic data recorded either with the geophone or with the fiber optics sensors (e.g.: Lai et al., 2002; Socco et al., 2010), the dependence of the Rayleigh wave velocities on the frequency can be deduced via a 2D Fourier transform of the collected seismograms. The result of the Fourier mapping between the time-distance space into the frequency-wavenumber space is usually called FK spectrum. The approach based on these integral transformations ensures the retrieval of more robust information; however, in the attempt of capturing the lateral velocity variations, alternative approaches have been recently developed (e.g.: Vignoli et al., 2011; Bergamo et al., 2012; Vignoli et al., 2016). In our specific test, as we assumed no significant lateral changes along the acquisition lines, after splitting the profile in stabilized and natural ground (Fig. 2), we made full use of the most common technique. Hence, the dispersion curves have been extracted via a simple picking, frequency-by-frequency, of the maxima of the FK spectrum. Dispersion curves describe the dependence of the surface wave (group and/or phase) velocities on the frequencies (and, in turn, on the investigated depth); so, they can be inverted by using 1-D forward modelling algorithms (Park et al., 1999) to infer the shear-wave velocity profile beneath the acquisition location (in principle, phase velocities depend also on the compressional velocity and density, but, in the vast majority of the practical cases, that minor dependence is seldom exploited – see i.e. Xia et al., 1999).
Like many other inversion problems, also retrieving the shear-wave velocity profile is an ill-posed problem and the associated ambiguity is usually tackled by including a regularization term in the inversion process. Basically, the regularization term formalizes the prior information – different from the one provided by the collected data – about the physical system under investigation. In this way, through the proper choice of the regularization term, it is possible to select – among all the possible solutions compatible with the data – the unique and stable model that is also consistent with our expectations (described by the regularization). Thus, the regularization term plays a crucial role in the selection of the final result (in our specific case, the shear-wave velocity profile).
Despite its importance, usually, invocating a – perhaps, misinterpreted – Occam's Razor principle (Popper, 2005), the regularization term is chosen in order to favor smooth solutions (Zhdanov, 2002).
However, this choice can be often in contradiction with the actual nature of the subsurface, in which, for example, the presence of sharp boundaries can be possibly well-known; in these cases, the use of smooth regularizations would lead to incorrect results (even if perfectly compatible with the measurements).
In the present research, since we knew that, by construction, the subsurface consists of blocky targets and abrupt changes in the physical properties, we coherently adopt a tunable regularization term based on the minimum gradient support stabilizer (Zhdanov et al., 2006; Vignoli et al., 2015). The main characteristic of the adopted stabilizer lies in the capability of providing solutions (equally compatible with the measurements) with a tunable level of sparsity (Vignoli et al., 2021). The adopted tunable stabilizer, s(β), has the following expression:
